reviewText:
My experience so far is that while still a fun game it seems that everything done with the cars is done wrong. When I played the beta I just kept telling myself it's just a beta." Boy was I wrong. Let tell you of my frustrations as well as what needs to be updated.

-The car selection seems like someone obsessed with American muscle as well as DuPont catalogs. I don't want to street race in Ferrari and koinsegg (spelling). While I understand a few of these cars in the game it seems stupid for half the roster of a street racing game to be these kinds of cars. And there are 2-3 versions of old and new muscle. We have about 3-4 actual tuners to play with. Who made this car selection?

-Pre-order bonus. Well I pre ordered the game for the Mini Cooper personally. Because I own one in real life. Was horrified to see that the pre order cars can only be used in street spec. Making them utterly useless.

-The specs oh oh the specs. Advertised your game to be able to switch out specs on our cars on the fly for different race types. Reality sets in when you realize only a handful of starter cars can do every spec as well as only 1 truck having dirt spec. I'll say that last part again
date: only ONE truck in the game has dirt spec. Even the Hummer doesn't have a dirt spec. Once again WHAT WERE YOU THINKING. Is this a bug?!!!!!\n\n-Customization. If you thought the crew was gonna have the best customization since need for speed underground

reviewText:
So, The Crew:

Basically they took the idea of NFS Rivals and improved it, added a storyline, and optimized it better. The idea is that the game is always online. Any time you play it you will be able to see other people and even CO-OP with them.

So is it better than NFS Rivals? Two words: Hell yes! It is better optimized for the PC, more customzation, and it has an actual story line.

Some people are complaining that the map is not big enough. Well think about it - Fitting thousnds of miles/kilometers of roads and hundreds of cities into a game is pretty damn hard. Not to mention that if they did so, you'll probably get a game that will weigh over 100 GB's, and probably won't run on most PC's. So they took the best of what there is, and put it in the game.

My only complain is that the game lacks some cars, for exmaple: Subaru Impreza WRX STI, or Toyota Supra. I expected to have those cars in a street racing game. I truely hope they add these cars sometime.

And another thing, and this is aimed towards people, not the game itself: You complain about unrealistic physics in an ARCADE RACING game?! Are you serious?! An Arcade Racing game is supposed to have unrealstic physics.

If you're looking for sims: Go for something like Assetto Corsa. Because this is not a Sim. This is an ARCADE RACING game.

reviewText:
In General The Crew is a baby of Test Drive and Driver : San Francisco with a little touch of NFS series
The game have all the Digital Petrol Head wants fast cars stunning views and twisty mountain roads and ofc. Bonneville flats, the game world feels crowded and alive from bison packs running across the roads wolfs and bears lurking in the woods. One of the strong points of the game is the freedom and open world saw something interesting at the horizon you actually can go there. you can drive there on the road in you Street spec car or switch to something off rowdy and go in straight line trough woods and over the mountains.

Every car got its own feel to it they all handle differently, from straight line muscles to agile japan tuner cars, and the crew brigs it back you love a car A here take it drive it, your car A is short on power and cant outrun a faster cars here put some power in it, oh you don't like the stock looks no problem in that compartment either.
Not like allot of other driving series oh you Hate car X! Here drive it!!!! , Oh you love your car A sure drive it but only until you progress and then you will have to drive car X!
game puts decision back in gamer hands i love car A i drive it, not like the other games you have to drive cars XYZ

the Handling model cant say is brilliant but its fun, its somewhere in between arcade and simulator.
From me Game gets solid 8,4/10 but its score for the beta. But definitely see you on the road.

reviewText:
If you enjoy racing games and not just racing Sims and you ever played MCO from EA and have always been looking for a replacement this is as close as there has been.

The driving still needs some work cars float too much but overall the game will be a nice change from every other online game currently available.

1/1/15 Update

After spending quite a few hours learning and fine tuning a number of cars I've dicovered that the handling isn't as bad as I had previously assumed. Before I hadn't done much adjusting of the settings but now that I have I can deifnitely confirm the handling is fine just the defaut handling gets you off to a bad start.

I now have a 1299 car of all but Raid spec which is much harder to grind the parts on. There are certian cars for certain races. Races in the Mountain range on snowy roads are better in a Ford Focus than a Ford Mustang.

The game has alot going for it but they really need to work on expanding the Map maybe DLC's that add more cities into the map would be a quality start.

They really need to work hard on more cars ASAP there are tons of cars that could be added to this game that would really give it a lot more life. Not everyone wants a Ferrari or Lamborghini and while the Koenigsegg Agera R is an awesome car it's just not realistic to use on a US map.

Car models I'd love to see added to the game would be more upper class but not super cars. Lexus, Audi, Cadillac and Acura. There are just a lot of cars left out that the game really needs.

I really enjoy the game and there is nothing that would make me quit playing it. Weekly missions in game need to happen more often and there should be some type of end game which right now the only end game is racing other players.

reviewText:
The Crew is an okay game, it offers such a wide variety of feats. Skill challenges, Races in PvE and PvP and now including The Summit with stunts and freedrive challenges in it's latest expansion. In return however, the game has so many pet peeves that can bother a player to stop playing forever. Like a finish line delay that could lose you some seconds while playing with people outside your region, the ability to exploit some obstacles to gain seconds and a slightly messed up balance between vehicles.

People hope for the best experience in every little aspect of the game, but The Crew is so massive that it can not offer this. As a result, The Crew does just about average in everything. You're not supposed to like The Crew because of sounds, amount of cars, customization, graphics or handling specifically. It expects you to like the wide selection of literally everything it has. Would it do better for players liking specific feats if the game chooses to minimize it's offers? Yes. You'll leave other people disappointed however. It's up to the developers to offer the best experience out of everything it has. You can see they 'slowly' improve on some stuff, but with each pro comes it's cons.

I like The Crew because of it's variety and I try to look through the well-known pet peeves to enjoy an actual fun game. So far I think I'm doing a good job at it.

Should you buy The Crew, the Season Pass, the Wild Run expansion or anything named together for the full price? No. Wait for a 50% discount. This will cause you less annoyance, but still have a jolly good time in a fun open-world racing game.

reviewText: The Crew features an open and persistent world for racing and free-roaming across a scaled-down recreation of the contiguous United States. The map is split into five regions: The Midwest, East Coast, Mountain States, West Coast, and The South. Each region has its own unique geographical features. Six main cities (one in each region, two in The Midwest) are featured in the game: Detroit and Chicago in the Midwest, New York City on the East Coast, Miami in The South, Las Vegas in the Mountain States, and Los Angeles on the West Coast. Various other cities, such as San Francisco, Seattle, Salt Lake City, Dallas, New Orleans, Washington D.C., and St. Louis, are also featured in the game. Over thirty smaller cities and towns line the countryside like Nashville, Norfolk and others. It takes approximately 45 minutes in real time to drive from coast to coast in-game. The single-player campaign is 20 hours long, and entails infiltrating criminal groups with protagonist Alex Taylor (Troy Baker). Players can also participate in mini-games called skills challenges that are peppered across the world. They are triggered when a player drives through them and it involves completing challenges such as weaving through gates and staying as close to a racing line as possible for a period of time. Players' scores are automatically saved so friends can try and beat their scores, in similar fashion to how Autolog works in games of the Need for Speed franchise. Missions can be played alone, with friends, or with online co-op matchmaking. The multiplayer mode lets a maximum of eight players to compete in races and other gametypes. There are no in-game loading screens or pauses.

reviewText:
Welp here is my kinda quick who gives a damn about spelling review on the crew, Even though everyone gave this game ♥♥♥♥ before it had even come out due to ubisoft and how they are but This is coming from someone who is max level and finished the story,
Pros- The game looks really nice,cars are very nice to look at and sound very nice, the map feels very large and has lots of different terrain and weather which does effect the handling which is good. The story is rather enjoyable for a racing game and it is an adult level story not some dumbed down kids friendly story that makes me want to cry (Test Drive 2 im looking at you), The cars handle well for what they are and upgrading does actually make the cars feel better to drive.

Cons- (ohboiherewego.jpg) Welp this game does have its fair share of cons so far. The whole name of the game is the crew, which is funny conisdering me and my friends cant join each others crews, and the fact most of the time you are playing you never see anyone else driving around, and teleporting to friends to see them doesnt help because they never show up on your screen. Another con would be the huge lack of support with these problems and how none of the devs seems to care about the connections problems (Which isnt good considering this game is apparently an mmo, and an mmo with connection issues isnt a good thing). The last few cons would be gameplay based, the other ai racers in this game are either so stupid they drive into rivers or they are so rediculously op that they cant be caught even by the best of drivers in the best of cars, and the last con would be im having a problem where the game seems to take control of the car and ♥♥♥♥ you up at the worst of times.
Final thought: Even with this extensive amount of cons i would still reccommend this game as the majority of these cons will be fixed within the next few days (hopefully) and the game is rather enjoyable otherwise.

reviewText:
I bought this game on release (no pre-order) and played it for a week and had to stop because my laptop couldn't handle the detail in the game. It let me play it but fps would drop frequently. Fast foward to 2016 and a used gaming pc running GTX 550I and i got NO ISSUES with the game.

Ever since I began playing it on a desktop computer with a real graphics card i haven't had time to play anything else let alone watch some anime. Ended up completing the campeign within 2 weeks durring my free time and i must say i love it! I even bought a xbox one controller with usb cord to play the game--and it plays superb with the controller. The wheel has mixed reviews but its not for everyone, i know that sometime this year i will for sure buy a wheel/peddle combo for this game.

The custimization of the cars is handled well withe the fact that when you make it to level 50, you gain the opportunity to earn more custimzation such as more front bumpers or more rims.

PVP is fun as well however if one player has bad internet connection it will interupt the game for a few seconds only as the match reconnects everyone.I do not ( i have googlefiber) so I always hope that whenever i enter pvp lobby that everyone has decent internet.

Now that my storyline is done i had a day where i wasn't sure what to do but then i remembered the wild run expansion and the endless possiblities (until this time i had focused on campeign) and now im pumped again!

The updated graphics were a must for the game and now that they have done that  i do say all the landscape looks amazing! I'm getting the Wild run expansion and i can't wait to drive a monster trick up the side of a mountain or thru las vegas :P

Ever since i finished the campeign i have been planning on what story to write as i continue to play 'The Crew'. Whatever story i choose to write and drive thru i will sure as hell have hours upon hours of fun!

Who knows maybe if i end up driving and writing the story i might publish it as a fanfic :P but thats months away i bet!

Conclusion:
The crew was good at release but since the Wild Run Expansion and upgradted graphics mainly, it has gotten far better than I could have imagined. Granted there are still some hiccups such as the pvp lobby intrupting gameplay (pausing it for 5 seconds) if a player has pretty bad internet connection. Otherwise they have worked hard on improving the game since release. An Xbox One Controller works great with the game and i can't imagine myself playing it on a keybored ever again! (unless i didn't have access to a controller!)

Even though on steam this game has alot of mixed reviews i hope we as a gaming community can give this game the support it could use to really inspire the developers to greater hights with this game. The potential of it is without limits. Let's hope they never stop adding to this wonderful game.

oh yeah, and its fun!

reviewText:
Alright, with quite a bit of beta play and about 20 hours of release version play (despite steam's counter reading 14 at the time of writing), I think I'm able to give some preliminary opinions on this game.

First off, this game is not perfect. There are little graphical and gameplay quirks that happen here or there, such as the cockpit view getting a little glitchy past 200mph, and annoying car resets after what should have been seamless, on the fly missions that place you exactly where you were, but stopped. Not to mention, the server system seems a little flaky.  One second, I am online with a dozen players, and after completing a mission, I am completely alone. However, this is a brand new release, and with Ubi marketing this as more of an MMO, I'm holding out hope that those things will be taken care of in the future.

Those hangups aside, the game has proven to be quite enjoyable. Physics wise, on road car handling almost reminds me of the good old days of the 1st Need For Speed: Most Wanted. Perhaps, just a little grittier, but fun nonetheless. In my honest opinion, off the road is where this game really shines, though. For anyone who's played the game FUEL, off road vehicle handling should feel awfully familiar to you. I was excited to hear that a few devs from the FUEL team worked on this game, and you can certainly notice the influence they had.

As far as gameplay? Missions aren't all that much to talk about, none are particularly outstanding, but they pace them well, and I've yet to get bored. Car customization was not nearly as in-depth as I had hoped, which is dissapointing. Certain cars can't even be modded in ways that would seem to make sense. For example, you cannot take a Ford Raptor truck, and convert it into the rally car / prerunner - esque Raid" type. Meanwhile
date: feel free to do that to your Nissan Z! The whole MMO aspect
recommended: I'm not so sure of yet... mainly because it doesn't seem to be working correctly yet.\n\nIn short
hoursPlayed: the game has a LOT of potential
voteText: and I'm enjoying it so far despite it's quirks. However
helpfulPercent: there are some improvements that are needed to make this game really shine."

reviewText: This is an amazing racing game. Huge open world, tons of races and hidden events to find, and an awesome customization system for your cars. The handling is a little weird and takes some time to get used to, but isn't bad at all. Imagine Burnout Paradise but with customization of cars. The map is so much fun to explore just beacause of the simple fact that you can just drive right off the road at any point and blaze your own path to the next goal/start point/car dealership/whatever you may be wanting to drive to. I feel this game will get a bad rap just because of the use of uPlay, but I will put up with uPlay anyday of the week to play this game, it's that good. I find myself forgetting what I am suppose to be driving to, and just driving around looking at the world change. It is also nice that it runs well (note that at this time I am writing this during the beta and the game is capped at 30fps. But no crashes or game breaking bugs). All in all, this game is really awesome. I have had a ton of fun in my first 10 hours and I can't wait to keep playing.

reviewText:
So, here we go.
I can see alot bad recommendations about it, but in my opinion its a great game. Lets start with a big map, i dont have seen so big map without loading points before, map is minilized version of real life Michigan, New York, Florida and California. There are also alot of cars with awesome classes and tuning, from stock to circuit, 5 classes in total. There are cars, pickup trucks and so on. (Season pass gives even more) Map is quite living, with citizens walking in cities and animals living in wild, trains move, aircraft, alot of traffic vehicles, emergency vehicles on duty and so on. Story is quite interesting, but little, but after finishing it, there are also alot of skills to do... and then awards (Each class of awards done gives you special nr plate). There are also landmarks, what locate an historical building or place with quick review of it from real life, i really liked to do these. (242 on total)  Cars have standalone levels to 1299, you unlock parts doing missions or skills, and then there is player level, up to 50. Snow mountains, where it gives your car more slippery, and fun to drift... also alot of racetracks and interesting places from real life US states, Salt lake drag strip and so on...  Cop chases are quite hard. Also each state has its own 20 car wrecks to collect, to get an hidden car for free.
So... bad things about this game, you might meet some players in your session at each state.
Crew invitation is still glitching around sometime, wont let somebody join... and PVP takes forever load, so... basically you drive alone... also friends i have in uplay, i never dont have seen them in my session, if only joined my crew.
8 / 10.

reviewText:
Hmm, The Crew.

This game received a lot of criticism at launch, and its not like it didn't deserve it; the game was lacking in a lot of aspects and had so much potential to be more than what it was.

Fast forward to now when the Wild Run expansion has released and brought a slew of changes to the game visually and gameplay wise. I would actually recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the Test Drive Unlimited series which were also made by some of the developers of this game! If a huge map, exotic vehicles + customisation, and the freedom to drive around is what you want then this game has it all and plenty.

I mostly played The Crew prior to the Wild Run update. It was actually a lot of fun going through the to be honest meh storyline, but that isn't what anyone bought this game for. The selling point was obviously the fact that the map is a scaled version of the United States, and good grief is it amazing.

For what it is, it has plenty of detail (and now looks stunning as well thanks to the update) and nothing will beat the road trips you take solo or with friends, perhaps strangers on the road also playing their own game (so to speak because its a quick drop in/out lobby system for lack of a better phrase) between the various states. Putting my phone on a speaker dock next to me, setting up my Logitech DFGT, turning off the HUD, going to cockpit view and cruising along the freeways at night is just so wonderful I can't even describe it. And it's not short road trips either, getting across the states will take an actual hour or 2, maybe more, depending on the route. Super easy to lose time in this game like that.

Speaking of, car physics. It's pretty arcadey, but everyone expected that (right?). They've definitely improved it since launch and its fine to play now for the most part IMHO.

Customization is handled pretty well. The UI could with quality-of-life tweaks but the modding of each vehicle it self is pretty well fleshed out (looking at you, NFS 2015). Should be noted, that all the vehicles do not have all the specs available to them. You can imagine my disappointment to the lack of a raid Murcielago :( still, Fiat 500 Monster Truck.

Music selection in this game is nice, didn't agree with a few songs but hey, I just play my own while playing now so. Car selection is also pretty good.

I cannot speak much for the events and the Wild Run exclusive Summit"
date: but I hear good things. PVP races are prone to being glitchy occasionally (maybe they fixed this now
recommended: can't tell for sure) but they have definitely balanced the vehicles you can use for the races now as compared to pre-Wild Run (the LaFerrari was the go to car if you wanted any chance at winning for example in the Perf-spec)
hoursPlayed: so thank you devs!\n\nSo there you go
voteText: my thoughts on The Crew. Would 100% recommend if you love cruising around the USA."

reviewText:
After clocking in 36.1 hrs in this game. i have come to the conclusion that this is the first and LAST time i EVER buy a game from Ubisoft. This was a huge let down in many aspects. While i try my best to focus on the good of the game ( will be stated lower down), from time to time i find my self regretting the fact that i went against my instincts to not buy the game ( reason being deep down i felt like this game would be a total let down after ACU: Assasin creed Unity reviews).

Pros( may or may not state all)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+Huge map
+driving never really feels repetitive unless doing specific races
+open world
+fun skill challenges, races, and faction races
+being able to make crews between friends and or people you don't know ( Chance to make friends online).
+Earning money is not a struggle therefore buying cars aren't a headache
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Cons ( to many to list)

-Crew are limited to only 4 people

-very low car selection from since launch

-Car modeling is sub par for a next gen game

-Street cars and circuit cars have a fetish for driving offroad

-when turning corners in any class of car, it feels like you're slamming the vehicle to the left/right

-driving dirt cars feel like you're constantly drifiting on ice

-not much to do with friends besides races, missions and more races just pvp this time

-Story line is a little to predictable ( not a deal breaker)

-driving against AI constantly feels like the game is trying to recreate a movie scene where the race ends in NECK&NECK
-IF MY CAR HAS A RATING OF 900+ THERE IS NO REASON OR SENSE FOR AI CARS RATED AS 600 AND BELOW TO HAVE THE ABILITY TO KEEP UP WITH ME.

-Cop chases feel like you're car weighs 5 lbs and the cop cars have the wieght of an Airbus A380 jumbo Jet. when they hit you, you're car gains the speed of a bullet and goeing into the direction you're hit too, how ever when you hit the cop car that looks like it can be taken down easily, u still gain the speed of a bullet and fly into the opposite direction you hit the car into.

-Cop cars that aren't exotic or have have the potential to go past 200MPH should NOT be keeping up with my Lambo. thats is Blazing by on the highway @ 245MPH. I swear, this game makes police chases feel as if some of the cop vehicles have magnetic propulsion systmes in them.

-Graphics needs to be boosted up ( a bit apauling for a next gen game)
i also felt like more effort were placed into using shaders and other techniques to mask the bad graphics.

-For a game that has such a huge scale map, the entire world feels empty to some extent; eg: the only place civilians are prevalant are in medium to large cities in states such as like NY, LA and Illanois. And despite their presence in these locations, their numbers are outstandingly low leaving a feeling of deserted city with just civilian vehicles going in and out of.

-THE DRIVING PHYSICS, HANDLING & everything else involved with the movement of cars are ABSOLUTLY APPAULING. ( driving games like NFS underground feels alot more bearable than this in my honest opinion. countless times while driving circuit cars, i begin to get the feeling like im driving my car on ice when moving at high speeds (it feels like im moving a lamborghini at rocket speeds on ice while trying to stare).

-Accident situations are just wacky. by that i mean if i get careless while racing and make a mistake, and go offcourse i just have to hold B on the controller and i will respawn OR sometimes when im 150 mph+ & i am about to hit a tree or a car i sometimes just slide to the side like nothing was there. If im not lucky that happnes then i must endure a mandetory cutscene of my crash that sometimes happens in the wierdest ways. (cutscene can be skipped once 1 or 2 seconds have passed its bearable).

-The speed of the cars are just all over the place. exotic cars can have the tendancy to bearly feel different ater leveling them up to 1299 ( max level ) in their respective classes ie street, dirt, raid & Circuit. for example. i bought a lamborghini Mercealago after spending some time doing races, the car top speed in full stock was 219MPH , currently i have leveled the car up to 1230, the max speed i have reached with this car is 249 MPH with NOZ blowing out the exhaust pipes like the mouth of a dragon.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

There are much more CONS, however you the reader should get an idea by now.
In conclusion i felt completly let down by this game. i haven't bought a racing game since the new NFS most wanted was released in 2012. I Thought Ubisoft was going to really dilever on this game but i was WAY out of the ball park with my expectations. I was fooled by the CG Trailors of the game they were releasing to hype this game up. To me there is limited fun to have in this game so therefore i will not recommend this game to anyone as of this moment unless this game undergoes heavy amounts of fixing.

reviewText:
8/10 - Fun, addictive game with lots of growth potential.

I gave it a 8/10 instead of a 10/10 because the game isn't easy to learn or it's not user friendly and it needs more cars; there are only a little more than 200 cars available in the game.  That said once you learn how to play, this game is amazing.

'The Crew' reminds me of my beloved racing game Gran Turismo, but much better and with traffic, an open world and random weather.  I played Gran Turismo 1-5, I'm familiar with the game and engine, this game is most definately built off the same platform.  The vehicle modifaction system has been changed and the game has a story with a plot as well as being massively multiplayer.  You're allowed to play all the game's different modes in a Crew" or a 4 man team of your friends.

When you start out you have a choice of cars available at the Detroit car dealer.  As you unlock the game by beating story missions
date:
there are 5 car dealerships and 1 motorcycle dealership.  I recomend starting with either the 2011 Mustang GT or the Nissan 370Z as they have several different specs the vehicles can be tuned to.  Much like Gran Turismo the vehicles are rated based on what 'The Crew' calls vehicle levels or Gran Turismo players know as performance points.

There are several different spec's a full stock car can be tuned to.  The game comes with 5 specs.  To unlock 'extreme specs' you need to purchase the 'Wild Run' upgrade.

Standard Specs:
1 - Street
2 - Dirt
3 - Performance
4 - Raid
5 - Circuit

Wild Run 'Extreme' specs:
A - Monster Truck
B - Drift
C - Drag
and a new vehicle type: Motorcycles... which kick ♥♥♥ by the way.

Each spec a vehicle is tuned to can level up by unlocking parts via challenges

reviewText:
Find some people on Steam to play with and form a Crew. I have made 3 great new friends in the past 2 days from playing this game. Having people to play/cooperate/compete with makes this game so much fun, and you will always try to beat each-others records on trials and watch their tail during races. It is co-op, so if the objective is (for example that we found) to, say, finish 3rd or higher, and only one person in the event achieves it, you all get rewarded. I usually am the brute in our Crew, I drive a Dirt or Street spec'd Ford Raptor. I will keep the AI drivers at bay by ramming and cutting them off, and my friends will use their Skyline or Charger to win the race(Though the Raptor can perfectly keep up if I want!). We all have a role that we use to emerge victorious as a group, and the game really rewards teamwork.
--
There is so much I would like to write about, but I am tired (from playing so long). The driving isn't Asetto Corsa level, but if you want to have a blast driving, this game does it. I have had some times where the others went off line, and I just drove, and drove, and drove, and went to the coast, traveled to the mountains and hot-swapped for my Dirt-spec ride and tore up the ground all the way down the mountain.
--
If you have a steering wheel with force feedback, The Crew uses every ounce of it. I was a beta tester, and I was surprised that they had full support for my wheel, the Logitech Driving Force GT. It's not a mainstream wheel, it was designed for the PS3, but it works on PC with 900 degrees of rotation and force feedback. All the buttons work, I have not had to tweak anything. It just, WORKED.
--
Ask me anything you like in the comments, I would be happy to answer questions you have about the game.

reviewText: I loved the beta for this game. Tons and tons of detail were put into this and alot of time well spent. I let my friend who rarely plays racing games drive with a pc steering wheel I got and from him destroying the city we found some minor bugs. I really wanted to point out how getting from one place to another actually takes you onto the highway for a REAL cruise sometimes. These trips aren't 2 seconds down the road. When I wanted to get to NY City it took me a decent amount of time to get there by highway (probably about 15 minutes). I very much enjoy this aspect of the game because constantly racing your car and bashing through telephone poles in a racing game doesn't make me respect that racing reality. What really gets you to appreciate your car, in The Crew and in real life, is when you can drive it on the highway for a trip - destination after destination. When I got onto the highway in The Crew I felt even more confident in this game.

reviewText: First of all I would like to start off by saying that I have played approximately 20 hours of the game.  This has basically put my most of the way through the campaign.  My background with the game started earlier this summer when I got invited into the closed beta.  (Played about 6-8 hours)  The very first problem with this game is that you can't just use steam, on top of steam you have to use UPlay(Only works about half the time and takes forever to get into the game)  The next problem is that once you get into the game (assuming you have an internet connection) it tends to be rather buggy.  There seems to be an issue with optimization because my computer is rather capable and more than meets the minimum and recommended specs.  As with most AAA titles lately if you have AMD hardware you definitely need to beware  (my laptop with Nvidia hardware runs the game much better)  The main problem seems to be around the cities(Lots of buildings and poor optimization).  All in all this fits together to be a rather poor title but the one thing that keeps nagging me is the physics of the game itself.  I could probably get past the online all the time (Wasn't explicitly stated that you have to be) or even the sometimes poor framerates.  But the poor and might I add inconsistent physics and handling between cars is terrible.  Now I can personally say that I have never driven most of the vehicles in-game, but last time I checked a 600-900 horse Ferrari should be able to drift much better than an off-road Chevy Silverado(Actually have driven this).  However this is not the case all the muscle cars that people have been sliding around for years and years are impossible to drift.  The only game mode that seems remotely realistic is that of circuit racing.  I wasn't expecting this to be Forza Motorsport realistic but I at least expected it to feel something like Dirt 3 or Grid (Something sim-cadeish).  Finnally about the physics we are looking at the terrible bug where sometimes you will be cruising along and hit the same curb or patch of dirt you have hit 100 times with no consequence and now all of a sudden you are tossed into the air and are placed miles behind your competitor.  All in all I am extremely dissapointed with the crew as I have been waiting for a U.S. playground for cars for years.  Guess I am still waiting.

reviewText:
Jacko Rating
7/10
The Crew is the first MMO to do something different and use cars and driving instead of the usual aray of fantasy characters.
It is an enjoyable mix of arcade/sim style racing with the added online benefits - namely being able to join and crew up with as many as 4 of your mates to race and cruise all over the USA.
Strengths are definately the enjoyment you get out of messing about with your friends whilst in your hotted up car, the graphics are good for next gen but for the PC it could be better, 60 FPS on PC runs smooth enough, the sound effects from the cars are nice and beefy and last but not least the size of the map and drivable area is absolutely massive.
The weaknesses are - its gets a bit laggy from time to time, there are not nearly enough visable players online making it not really feel like a MMO (at least not yet), not enough races on offer and the button mapping system is frustraiting when trying to really customize it.
The final verdict after 42 hours of playing time is despite its flaws it is an addictive driving game especially when cruising around with mates but no substitute for a real racer (wait for Project Cars).  This is well worth your money if you intend to play with friends online and like a massive map of the USA to drive around but if you want a hardcore racer to post times and compete against mates then this will only annoy you.
Pretty Good Game but could have been much better.

reviewText:
I've clocked almost 50 hours in The Crew - an obvious recommendation. I am currently level 27 and still exploring the first of 5 regions (more about that later). Why is it fun?

The Crew has a huge map, a huge number of difficult races and skill challenges, reasonable AI, the longest races I have ever seen in a computer game, a varied selection of cars right from the start, and a good system for levelling up cars, doing PvP, and doing co-op PvE with or without friends. It is a bit of a cross between FUEL (its game world is bigger, but emptier) and NFS:World (which has a more crowded MMO-feeling, but is pay2win and not as social). It has Burnout Paradise's ability to initiate challenges right in the game world without going to an instance, so you may be driving along and see a car flying through the air because you're passing a jump challenge and someone's doing it; or see everyone else's police pursuits (join in if you like).


The level cap is at 50, there are 5 regions, you can go anywhere at any time, but the events and cars of a new region unlock every 10 levels. So in theory, since my main focus is still the first region (Mid-West - of course you start in Detroit), I shouldn't be over level 10, upgrading my car with level 1-10 parts won from skill challenges available in that region, and generally having a good time; and I should be able to level out of that region by following the storyline missions, if I like, which I probably am. But the game also provides other ways to level up: you can grind story missions (even accidentally, if you want to improve your score from bronze to gold; and the game also makes you, because other player will invite you on coop runs - of course you can decline), you can do faction missions once you are level 10 (out of curiosity), or you can do PvP (a dozen races was enough to get me from level 21 to 27). This will unlock other car types (good) and the parts sets that come with the level (bad, because I now could just buy me all level 20 parts for my car and skip the East Coast region altogether, and with a bit more PvP, skip the South, too). Maybe The Crew should have taken a slice from GuildWars, where you're a) PvP-ready from the beginning with competitive gear (but you can use your own high-end PvE gear as well), and b) levels and player capabilities are adjusted on the fly depending on the level of the region you're in so that co-op works well.

Right now, I exercise some restraint and explore and do the skill challenges and the exploration anyway, and the nice thing about The Crew is that even though my cars are somewhat overpowered for the zone (what with the stat boost levelling up gives them -- why, exactly?), the challenges are still tough to get golden. At the rate I'm going, there'll be many more hours of fun in this game.


If I could do it over, I would play each story mission only once and stay away from anything social (PvP, Factions, co-op) until level 40 at least. Recommended.

reviewText:
I have been playing The Crew for about 2 hours.

From a racing simulation point of view, the game lacks in various areas such as handling, physics, drivetrain, shifting. All vehicle handles nearly the same, with more or less understeer. Gearbox is odd, and slow while shifting/down shifting, handbraking is slow. On road, cars rarely spin out, but when pushing them to the limit, the cars will throw the rear end out, but refusing to turn. There are three modes of driving: All Assistance, Sport, Hardcore. All assistance would include ABS, Traction, steering stability, etc. Hardcore has less traction and less steering stability. Drifting is a pain in the ♥♥♥ on keyboard, but manageable on Sport and Hardcore mode.

Tuning is simplified and a lot easier for the general audience, nothing too complicated. Parts are found during runs and story events, Gold, Silver, Bronze, each adding x amount of additional car level. Level cap for players is at 50. Level caps for cars are at 1299.

From a car enthusiast point of view, for those who just wants to collect and drive the cars, and tune (not in-depth tuning), this game is great. Graphics are beautiful, damages to the vehicle is mildly realistic, environment is great. You wont be able to run over people though, just like that in Driver San Francisco, they would jump away with Level 9001 reflex skills. Engine sound effects on the cars come close to that of real cars, but only when not in cutscenes. Engine sounds from cutscenes souds like that of a muscle car, V6/V8. Collecters will still need to play the game and some events to make money, in order to mod the car. Game is Pay to Win or Play to Win.

The R34 GT-R is left hand drive, which does not exist, and makes the petrolhead in me heartbroken.

The Street Car upgrade in game gives a wheel (rim) which resembles 5Zigen Noir, which makes the Purist in me cry. Other recognizable brand of wheels (for those who care) includes: BBS (:D), HRE (:D), ROTA (D:), Volk Racing (:D) and of course, Original Equipment Manufacterer (OEM) wheels.

All Street Cars are stock height, which makes me Iacrophobic.

Game cannot be played with no internet connection, from what I've seen.

Best part about the game is that they have a replica Pike's Peak Uphill/Downhill sprint run in the Midwest. Very fun to do a tandem drifting run up/down with a friend.

Rate Game 6/10. It's not bad, but it's far from perfect. Definitely recommend for car lovers. Definitely a great game to go cruising around with friends and racing around town.

reviewText:
The Crew is everything I have hoped for in a racing game for years. It combines the fantastic customization options of Need For Speed: Underground with the thrill of the high speed chases of Hot Pursuit, as well as including more serious racing environments for fans of series like Forza and Gran Turismo, and even putting heavy focus on rallycross and extreme offroad racing.

The storyline (at least as much of it that was included in the beta) was interesting the whole way through, even if it seemed like it was lacking in dialogue every now and then. The Crew offers a break away from the typical racing game storylines while still keeping you in the spirit of racing the whole time.

The open world is enormous and has a lot of exploration and events to offer. The beta version included only the United States map, and I only had time to explore from Chicago to the east (and not even all of the east!). I don't know how much of the rest of the world will be included in the full release, but I am eager to find out come November.

All in all, I give the game a SOLID 9/10. I'm nothing short of absolutely thrilled for the full release of the game, and would HIGHLY recommend it to anyone with remote interest in open world or racing games.

reviewText:
Best Racing game of the year. Ubisoft has done it this time and at last.

I've been really mad at Ubisoft cause of it's crappy policy and marketing strategy, Watch_Dogs , Far Cry 4 and Unity. These games were expensive and not good as they look like. I was thinking about how worse Ubisoft can be, but even though I have these thoughts, still I made no prejudgement and watched stream on steam, talked with some friends about buying and forming our crew, and there I am driving across USA from East Coast to West Coast while feeling freedom and joy. I was a racing-game lover when I was a kid. Played Midtown Madness, Most Wanted a lot and  loved those games. And here, in The Crew , gives me that joy. You can free ride all over the Usa, discover hidden car parts that unlocks a hidden car ( each from different regions ) or landscapes and antennas , similar to Creed Franchise. Then you can do challenges to receive car upgrades to increase your car level just like in MMO's , and the best part? Forming your own crew and driving together. I hope Ubisoft won't ruin this game and keep it updated with new cars, new stuff. The Crew is highly recommended for racing-lovers, people who used to play racing games and who likes Forza Horizon.

Oh , forgot the best part. While driving around in L.A. and sun sets, it's best to listen to Arctic Monkeys - Do I Wanna Know , and hit it, One for the Road.

10/10 Ubisoft makes me wanna cry.

reviewText:
I followed this game for quite a while before it came out. I was super psyched for a racing game with car customization in an open world, something Need for Speed has not done for a while now. However, I will admit that once it came out, I never really heard anything about it. It seems like I basically forgot. Then, a friend of mine got it and I ended up buying it on sale. Clearly, as you can see from my hours, I really have enjoyed this game. However, it has some serious quirks to it, and they aren't necessarily good. So, here's what I enjoyed about The Crew, and not so much.

PROS:
The Open World - I didn't realize just how big the map was until I really got into this game. It has, by far, the largest map out of any racing game I have played. I cannot compare it to FUEL simply because I have not played it, but it is bigger than every NFS game. And best of all? The map is not repetitive. You can drive from the swamps of the south to the deserts in the west, and have different scenery and small towns/cities in between. It mainly revolves around 5 major cities, and they are New York, Chicago, Miami, Las Vegas, and L.A. The developers certainly did their homework when it comes to the cities, and I applaud them for it. Even after 260 hours of gameplay, I still see places on the map I have not been, making the open world my favorite part of the game, by far.

PvP - I find that the PvP is well done. You play in a lobby with up to 8 players at a time, who all choose exactly what event they want to do, and then the game randomly picks one of them. This includes events with any of the 5 specs. Some events are elimination, others regular races, and others a king of the hill" type game. What's even better is the amount of in-game money you get from PvP. Even if you get last place

reviewText:
The Crew is one of those racing games that you just have to play even if it has Ubisoft's name on it. Let's get all of the BS rumors out of the way by saying UBISOFT DID NOT DEVELOP THIS GAME!!!! Ivory Tower developed this game with the ability of having 60 FPS at the start and yes it does have micro transactions but earning in-game cash is super easy. This game isn't tanted with Ubisoft's bad pc port mojo. This is a super stable game and I occasionaly experience a crash once or twice a day.

So gameplay, how is it? Well the gameplay is well how any Need for Speed from Underground 2 through Carbon but with a twist. This game has RPG elements thats similar to Need for Speed World but is not purposly asking you to empty your wallets into a pay wall. It is open world and the world is really huge. It is close to 50 in-game miles and it will take you a long time to get you there. You have a level (50 is a max) in which you level up by doing story missions (yes it has a story), skill challenges, PvP events, and faction missions. The story missions is what it is labeled as, missions that's part of the story. The skill challenges offer a way to gain car parts (more on that later) and get some experience for doing it. There is also a leaderboard so you can compete against a person's ghost and see if you can get to the top of the leaderboard. PvP events are what it is labeled. You go against other players and you can choose to fight for your faction or just free-for-all. Faction missions are where you get a lot of money, faction experience in which that adds everyday you login, and some chunk of experience. They also have one hour long races and one that goes up to 4 hours

What are these car parts you mentioned above? Well those car parts give your car a level as well ranging from 0-1299. The car parts consist of a motorcore, air system, diff, tires, weight reduction, and more. There are five classes of cars and each car class is different to each other: There is Street, Dirt, Performance, Raid, and Circuit. Street is your step above stock. Dirt is something you would see from a World Rally Championship. Performance is your step above Street but is almost stripped out. Raid is something you see from the Dakar Rally and yes they have trophy trucks. Circuit is something you see from Grand Touring ot 24 Hour Le Mons racing. The car is completely stripped down with weight saving and high performance in mind with the ability to take corners.

Well since this is a driving game, how are the physics? The physics can be odd but if you work around them, you can win a lot of the races. Drafting is a thing so use it when you can. The cars will tend to bounce off of things like bumper cars and it focuses a little on drifting.

Hows the car customization? It is what you would expect from a Need for Speed Most Wanted and Carbon game. You can customize the interior with your choices of aluminum, carbon fiber, mixed aluminum, and mixed carbon fiber. You cannot place stickers anywhere you want to though. They have presets which look cool IMO.

Car selection? How big is it? Well IMO it is small but it will slowly expand with DLC. The car list consists of 58 total cars but at least they have trucks.

Final thoughts? Well I am enjoying the game. I am enjoying every bit of time I have put into the game. I would recommend everyone getting the Season Pass since they are going to add more cars. January 2015 is going to be their first DLC which should be an interesting one. I did wish they have given us the ability to move around the stickers rather than give us presets and working mirrors in the cockpit (yes a working cockpit). This game I believe will set a new standard on the illegal arcade street racing genre that was leaving a sour taste in my mouth because of the way Need for Speed has been going and from the look of things, it isnt going to get any better. You just have to play this game to know what I feel about this game. I have been dying to play a game thats open world with similar car customization as Need for Speed Most Wanted and Carbon but isn't trying to make your wallets screem and this is the answer my friends.

UPDATE: Next Tuesday of updating this review, they are adding three more cars into the game if you don't count the Mini Cooper non-street edition we got at launch. I havent experienced any big crashes. Loading the game will freeze your computer if you are using a controller with XInput. I still would recommend this game. The AI can have some stupid rubber banding but AI can be difficult in a racing game.

The Crew is an open world, online multiplayer arcade racing game that lets you crew up with people to challenge others all over five major areas in the United States. reviewText:
TL;DR - I'd recommend picking it up when it goes on sale or if you know you've got friends to play it with, as the campagin is hopelessly short and there's not much endgame content without the Wild Run DLC. Still incredibly enjoyable if you like cars, exploration, or customization.

-Cars. There's a lot of them, a wide variety of real life brands, and there's some pretty extensive visual customization for almost all of them.
-Microtransactions exsist, but almost all of them are shortcuts that you can eventually reach in the base game, or are simply visual components.
-It's always online, but I've never experienced any server difficulties.
- Geography is completely boned up, but many of the cities or landscapes capture the essence of the town they smulate. Someone living in San Francisco won't recognize many streets, but it still feels like the city.
- Game sometimes can seem empty. Civilian foot traffic is low in cities, and occasionally traffic is sparse.
-Devlopers are still actively involved and relasing content, so that's pretty cool.

The storyline is the video game equivalent of a wet piece of toast - bland, uninspiring, and so generic that you completely forget about it. There's some pretty cringey dialogue, some pretty bad voice acting, and your protagonist is an unrelatable walking cliche. Once you hit the cap of level 50, it's a short MMO-style grind to max out your car, and then it seems like you're done with the game.

This is when the Wild Run DLC becomes a lfiesaver. It introduces weekly and monthly challenges against other people, inspiring you to come back again and again. It adds real end game content, and I highly recommend it.

reviewText: I highly reccomend this game just from playing the closed beta! It really feels like Test Drive Unlimited on steriods(which is good, because some of the original TDU devs worked on this game!). You get a good selection of radio channels, including a fantastic classical station, and a full interior view in beautiful detail. The world is obviously not a 1:1 scale of the US, but it is still immense, and you really can't get bored with this game from just driving around. Instead of TDU, where you just drive around Hawaii and look at pretty palm trees, this game has vast deserts, snowy mountains, and sprawling cities. I got to Las Vegas, and I was amazed by how much thought was put into the city's design. It is almost like the devs actually cared about making the game feel as good as possible. As of yet, I cannot speak of the car selection very much, but it seems like it shouldn't be too lousy. If you like open world games, or just want to see the good ol' USA, buy this now!

-TONS OF CARS.
-The game not stands for full singleplayer, You can make a crew (A some sort of group that will join your missions.)
-Pvp (NOT ONLY RACING, Theres a lot of multiplayer pvp mods !)
-Upgrading and modding your car... Oh man.. This part. You just need to see the customization. (Ps. Made me poop myself when first saw).
-You can have a driving test before getting a new car
-Theres Voice chat and a regular chat. (Also whisper, crew chat and etc)
-Theres a lot more honestly just. idk less important for this review (You should also taste by yourself you know.)

So ofcousre after Pros. I should hit with the Cons !

-The biggest con by my opinion. Is the crashing system.
Crashing into cards happends a lot (Even if you are not bad like me.) Lets say you gotta race inside the city and theres a turn left or right doesnt matter. Sometime, Because its a city after all, Theres cars waiting for that green light. Yea, In that moments youll find cars all over the road except to the right direction.
I find it really annoying. Playing Perf spec (I guess the most fast cars in the game) On a road which is not straight inside the city totally can caus your death. (I did played a mission like that, i wanted to punch my screen, AND I CONSIDER MYSELF A CALMED PERSON.)

[Woah thats a big con]^

-When you buy a car, No refunds. You cant really regret it. Same with specs.
-When theres a chat notification you dont really get it, You need to open the chat box, unless you make it visible the whole time, Which kinda disturbs.

I must say, By my opinion once again, There is not a lot of cons to the game. Just really basic things. Handling isnt even bad. (Just on peft spec cars. Well thats because its ♥♥♥♥ing hard.) But yet the game extremely fun, and enjoyable.

I really hope you enjoyed my review. Make sure to like it if it helped you so other can see it aswell.

*SORRY FOR BAD ENGLISHHHHH*

Peace and love sugars.

reviewText:
This game has got a massive amount of negative reviews... and to be honest is the best racer i have ever played.
I did get the Gold version on sale so am reviewing at about a $40 price tag.

Pros:

Enough content to keep you playing for life (Skills/PvP/Faction and Story Missions.)
Graphics - Buttery smooth on my setup
Open World (US scaled by Autodesk)
The satellite animations zooming from map view to car and vice versa is damn sexy
Upgrading of cosmetics and performance for cars is pretty
Skill level upgrading - driver and performance parts upgrading for cars

Cons:

Main problem I have is that at the moment servers are packed with players but if UPlay or the Crew servers are down, you cannot play until they are back up. Physics of 'barriers' on collision can have the strangest effects at times like space shuttle launch type strange :)

First impression: Bought a Camarro... took it out on the street thinking it was going to be me and some ai doing missions. Came across these 3 Russian dudes doing donuts in a side street... They invited me to their Crew and we finished the Story missions together and are working on faction missions. There is no language barrier for burning rubber and nitrous fumes.

Each has their own impression ... for me this is 11/10 and supercedes NFS and Grid series with drawing me in and return value to the game.

reviewText:
THE CREW REVIEW
Image of the in-game options[cloud-4.steamusercontent.com]
Image of more in-game options[cloud-4.steamusercontent.com]
Image of the World Map[cloud-4.steamusercontent.com]
Image of an in-game event[cloud-4.steamusercontent.com] The Crew is not a good game.

While the concept of the game sounds great, Ivory Tower fails to execute it well. The cars all feel similar (the performance cars all feel the same as each other, the raid cars feel the same, etc) and don't control as good compared to other driving games. The game borrows many ideas from previous Ubisoft releases that don't really translate that well in a car. The online community for this game may as well not be there. There is a chat in-game but in the 20+ hours I've put into this game I've yet to see one person use it.. which can make it hard for people to find a Crew to party with in-game. Invites to races and events other people usually go unaccepted. While a large portion of the Crew relies on having a Crew, the game doesn't have a whole lot to offer for people looking for a single player experience.

The map for this game is huge and allows you to drive from the east coast of the United States to the west coast. In between are rocky mountains, open plains, wildlife darting across the road, cops, pedestrian vehicles getting in the way, little towns at the end of dirt roads and huge cities. In between all these are hundreds and hundreds (it seems like) of events. There's a handful of events such as staying in between the lines, smashing through 'gates', going as fast as you can, mountain climbing, and more. Completing these events (and other races) reward you with a score based on how well you did and are rewarded with different car parts than you can equip to cars; increasing their overall stats. Instead of climbing towers to unlock portions of the map; making you work a little for your progress, the Crew has you drive up to the satellite dishes located by a blinking aura on your map and GPS.

The story is extremely dull, laughable and perdictable.You play as Alex, a man wrongly jailed for the death of his friend. You have the chance you redeem your freedom as FBI Agent Zoe sends you information on the man who killed your friend, and she believes the police officer, Coburn, who arrested you is working behind the scenes with Shiv. You must race your way to the top, earn your ink, and take down Shiv. The music is subpar, instantly forgettable and I found a hard time finding something I enjoyed listening to in-game.

If you're interested in the Crew to get your racing game fix I would suggest looking elsewhere. There's plenty of other racing games out there that are multiple times better that'd you actually enjoy. Also, uPlay sucks.

reviewText:
Although i don't have as much playtime on this as some others, there is a lot to be said about the first impression of the game.

Pros:
Maps are richly detailed, i actually had to turn down settings so it wouldn't lag as much.
Cars are nicely detailed, drivers side view allows you to look from side to side just like in real life.
Good number of players around
Racing is fun, although this has its own mechanics and an entirely arcade feel. It essentially feels like an early NFS title in how it handles. Think Underground 2 or Hot Pursuit 2.

Cons:
Glitchy! Sometimes you can ram a car hard, and the game will act like it was just a scratch, other times you will tap a car on the side lightly, and crash as if you rammed them. Speed of hit does not seem to matter.
Microtransactions : YES, this does have microtransactions, although i do not see the need to buy cash unless you want to progress faster. It isn't quite as bad as i have seen in many games with a pay2win aspect.
Not worth the base value. I waited for this to go on sale, do not buy this at full price. I don't think this is worth $60 let alone $85 for the Gold.
Uplay: You must log in via Ubisoft's Uplay platform seperatly or make an account with them.
Hackers and Griefers: Don't bother with the leaderboards.
Handling: Normal racing mechanics do not seem to apply in this game.

If you can get past the cons, there is some fun to be had in exploring and doing missions. Personally, i enjoy what i have played so far. Get it on sale.

reviewText: The Crew has quickly become my favorite racing game ever. Let me first qualify by saying that I am not a racing sim fan but prefer arcade-style racers. Previous favorites have been Burnout: Paradise and Flatout: Ultimate Carnage. I also enjoy the DIRT and Forza series of games. With that said The Crew has an engaging story with a cinematic feel. I was able to play through the story at a casual pace in about 15 hours. The cut scenes are very well done and really draw you in. Once you finish the story there really isn't much that ties the campaign to the rest of the game however. I hope Ivory Tower (the developer) finds a way to create new missions which allow you to see what Alex and the 5-10s are doing instead of the player just running around the US doing races that don't connect with the story.\nOther than the disconnect from the story, once you make it to V8" status then the open world really affords you many choices. In addition to the option to go back and re-race any of the campaign missions (to win better car parts) you can also run skill events. You must do wither of these to get better parts for your car(s) before you will have a chance in the PvP section. You can also race in Faction events which earn bucks that you can use to repurchase parts you have already won for cars you haven't yet upgraded or to buy entirely new cars.\nSpeaking of cars
date: The Crew actually uses licensed cars from a wide variety of car makers including domestic and foriegn. Most of the cars are available to purchase with the bucks you earn in the game but others are only available if you pay real cash. The cost is relatively low and the season pass can make them even more affordable to buy all together. Each car has a variety of "spec" ratings from Full-stock
hoursPlayed: Performance
voteText: Dirt
helpfulPercent: Raid and Circuit. Not all cars support all specs such as a Ferrari wouldn't have Dirt or Raid but many such as the Mustang GT have all so you can get really crazy with your builds. You can also customize the exterior and interior appearance of your rides and with the daily and monthly challenges you are encouraged to enhance your cars to earn more bucks. The variety of car looks and builds is pretty amazing. I rarely see the same configurations more than once when playing PvP.\nI could go on and on about this game but one of the things I like the most is that the developer
votesHelpful: Ivory Tower
votesTotal: keeps enhancing and updating the game to make it better. Recently that added a league rating system and they routinely release new cars
votesFunny: tracks and events. The fact that this game continues to grow really makes it a great value. Unlike my past favorites I am always able to discover new things in this vast vehicular playground. Whether you buy The Crew on sale or at regular price you won't be dissappointed. This is one of the most fun and engaging racing games ever.\nOh and did I say that there is a huge expansion coming in the fall: Monster Trucks

reviewText:
I really like this game, and i see people comparing The Crew with TDU2 (Test Drive Unlimited 2) and these are not compareble because they are very, very different. The Crew is about your crew, its about exploring the world, its about driving your fully tuned circuit spec through the desert at 400+ km/h. Its about the community, beating records, driving together and completing insane faction races. But it is sertainly not without flaws, the AI is either the best driver ever completely ignoring the laws of physics like not needing to brake and drive 300+km/h through a 90 degree corner, or it will drive into every car and object available.

Cons and pros

Cons:

- Bad/unpredictable/unreliable AI
- Few cars and brands
- Bugs causing the game to crash (example: while browsing your collection theres a high chance of crashing)
- Uplay (Let us choose between steam or Uplay)
- Can be extremely difficult due to AI
- And some minor stuff like: no big rewards

Pros:

- Great handling cars (trucks vs muscle vs sport cars etc feel very different)
- Great graphics (though there's a bit too much lensflare sometimes)
- Amazing attention to detail, lots of npc's and wildlife
- Massive world to explore
- Lots of stuff to do when you're not running through the campain
- Different types of vehicle specs
- Random moments which make you laugh your ♥♥♥ of with your friends

If i were to rate it i'd give it 8/10.
Even though there are bugs and the AI is a bit weird, its a great and fun game to play with your friends

Hint: Ubiflop, if you delive anything less than 6+ cars when you release the dlc, i will nuke your ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
I do like this game but there are still way to many things to fix. Cop AI isn't very bright, but when they are driving on your sides, you're screwed. There is no way out of that the cop cruisers refuse to move, not like a car would act normally.

Also the difficulty for some missions is so artificial is angering. Most of the time, your car level needs to be well over the recomemded level because there are always 1-2 cars that just fly ahead of you and stay ahead of you. Also i noticed when a friend of a much higher level helps a much lower, the opposing racers are on par with the high level friend. Wait what?! At this point the lower level is better off on his own. The opposing AI car levels still have a low number but match speed with the high level pretty much throughout the whole race.

I know the big map is great and all, but its not 20 miles from Miami to Chicago. At least make it more reasonable.

Amidst all this backlash, I still recomend this game. For those who play it like a game not like something of a speed run. Which is what about half of the other people are complaining about. Campaign to easy or too small. That's because you dont know how to play a game.

reviewText:
The Crew is the 2014 textbook definition of polarizing, even before it released. On the one hand, it is an open-world racing game, giving you the opportunity to drive from one end of the United States to the other. On the other hand, Ubisoft.

This polarization extends in-game as well. One minute, I could be screaming at the screen because I failed a raid mission for the fifteenth time: My car had forgotten how it was supposed to work and a tiny rock about two pixels in size sent it careening sideways into fifteen trees like the world's worst lumberjack. The next, I would be driving through the snowy Rockies with the sun shining on my face as I drifted through a corner, pondering whether it was possible to operate the steering wheel with my massive erection.

It's a beautiful game with an adequate roster of cars (58 cars including Season Pass, possibly more to come) and wonky physics and I've loved every second of it.

reviewText:
The Crew is a very fun game, spiritual successor to Test Drive Unlimited 1 and 2. A very unique racing game. You're given some missions, money and access to a ton of cars where you can freely drive around a giant open world with a lot of variation. You have snowy area's complete with a lack of grip, the Nevada desert and the urban areas of NYC. All this while meeting a ton of players along the way which make roadtrips very fun.

However, there are definite downsides. The game is pretty arcadey, steering wheel support is not that good, there's some really weird things. For example: bikes can push cars out of the way.

All in all I'd still recommend the game for it is truly a unique game.

reviewText:
I was really excited for the release of this game, and I NEVER take the time to review games, ever. But this one enraged me to the point I have to let people know to NOT buy this game. no doubt I will combust any moment for wasting my hard earned money on this pile of pixles so Ill just keep it simple and make a list of the issues. only 3 for me, because I only got past the TUTORIAL. And dont get me wrong, Ive spent more time messing with settings than playing the game to know my issues are real.

1. FIVE times before you get into the gameplay they make it very apperent they want you buying wildrun DLC, this is stupid, was my 30 dollars not good enough?. 5 times I got advertisments shoved in my face before playing. not the point of a game.

2. the camera snapping back uncontrollably to the forward position anytime W is pressed, now I understand why this is needed, GTA did a good job of this, smooth transitioning back to front view. the crew snaps you back when your trying to look left or right and it freaks out when you try to look anywhere but directly forward. This is a car game. I want to look at my car, and look where I want to go. not just straight. this was a game breaker for me 100%.

3. after spending even more time tinkering with the steering controls, I for some strange reason couldnt tell I was driving a Camaro. I thought I was steering a bus.

Game was unplayable for mydelf due to these very annoying features, dont get me wrong if these 3 things dont bother you, I hope you enjoy the game. Im just trying to save peoples time if they share my opinion.

reviewText:
Decided to buy it for the multiplayer, stayed for the singleplayer.

I really enjoy open world games, where you can decide to just ignore missions and goals, and go do something else. This game is in some sort of identity crisis. It wants to be a MMO title, but its really not. I had a great time playing this with one of my friends, like a co-op experience. The problems starts when you want to get a group of people together. It worked just fine up to a group of 3 friends. The weird stuff started when we filled a crew with four people. Most of the time, the 4th player is invisible. You can se the players nametag, and you can race through his car, but you cannot see him. When we gathered two full crews, the same problem just expanded. You can see 3 players from your crew, but the rest of them are just nameplates.

The full-on PVP races is just stupid. The cars are scaled up / down to match each other, so it does not matter what car you drive, or what surface you race on. Its also impossible to properly queue up crew VS crew without the other crew being a bunch of random players.

Multiplayer aside: the rest is great, and this is why i stayed for the game.
You can decide to ignore the races, and just cruise around in this huge beautiful detailed world. All the cars feels different to drive, so it actually makes sense to buy different cars. I really enjoy just driving around the huge map. Driving from one corner to the other, can last for between 30 minutes - one hour (depending on your car) with full speed. its great fun. And its really fun to race in the open world with 3 friends from A - B in the USA.

I did experience a couple of bugs when playing. Sometimes after the race ends, the game crashes, and when i stream a video / watch a video with software on my other monitor, the game randomly crashes.

Do i recommend this game?  Well, yes. I do. As a single player open world racing game, its great. As a MMO it really really sucks. So it really depends on how you want to play the game.

reviewText:
If you are a fan of cars and racing games definitely pick this up. The handling seems a little arcadey and needs to be adjusted a bit in the settings and of course like all racing games a controller is always nice. But honestly the game will give you hours of fun upgrading your favorite cars, testing you skills in pvp or on solo/crew missions, and roaming around a toned down map of the USA. (with multiple race tracks to find might i add). The only possible downsides is that upgrading the cars can feeling like endless grinding to get the part you want, BUT it really isn't bad, also that the cop chases are pretty sub-par and lastly you need uplay.

Closing note about the negative reviews:

Most seem to be about the difficulty of the game and how some missions might need multiple people.
Honestly all I have to say about the difficulty is git gud :p I had no problem with the game at all (not to mention a little challenge is always fun!)  and in terms of the missions that may need multiple people, there is an option before the mission inviting all people that you can see to help you, so finding multiple people is easy!

Please do not let the negative reviews put you off from this game and remember to read them carefully!

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews, but Ubisoft announced a large expansion for this at e3 today and I want to see them continue that kind of support.

My initinal impression: 7/10
My current thoughts: 9/10

My cousin and I preordered this game and started playing it as soon as it was released. I'll be honest, it's not what I expected at all. I was hoping for another Test Drive Unlimited, so for the first while playing it I didn't like it much. We ended up stopping for three months before picking it up again and now it is one of my favorite games. They've made a lot of changes and fixed a lot of things, but I also like the game for what it is now, not what I wanted it to be.
I've spent hours just driving aimlessly to see what I can find, more than half the time I'm not even on a road, I'm using a RAID spec vehicle (think offroad racing truck type of vehicle) to drive where there aren't even roads because the team even put detail into those parts of the map.

Speaking of Specs, that's what makes this game so cool. Currently, I am using a 1969 Camaro for all races. I have a version that is basically an offroad buggy meant for driving where there aren't roads, another that is a high-performance circuit racer, a street racing version, a dirt track version, and a NFS-type high-performance street race version. The same car becomes 5 VASTLY different cars, each handling differently and meant for different types of races and terrains. You simply can't drive a Circuit car in a RAID race, that'd be like driving a formula one car in a rally, it just doesn't work. The same is true vice versa. But you can use the same car as both specs if you want.

The story mode is pointless, I won't disagree with that, but this game is meant to be an MMO, the story doesn't really matter. It's only there to introduce you to the different specs for PVP events. It is still fun with a crew of course, but pretty boring by yourself. My cousin and I never even finished it. We got as far as unlocking the last SPEC and then focused on PVP events and faction events. PVP events and faction events are what's the most fun. They are races of all types across the US. My favorite race is a RAID race going down the side of a snowy mountain, it's high speed and there are no roads. Faction events can vary in length between less than 10 minutes to over an hour. That seems crazy at first but with a crew it is fun.

The entire map is covered with challenges like speed, escape, jump, raceline, etc. to get upgrades for your car like loot drops in an MMO. It's a great way to keep just driving interesting as well. But most of the time you will probably avoid them if you're just driving because really, this game makes just driving feel great.

I'm looking forward to what is planned to be added to this game, they said they will support it for a long time and I really hope so. This is the kind of game you can drive for hours without even doing anything and still enjoy yourself, whether or not there is even a road in visible distance of you.

reviewText:
I expected better of you, Ubisoft. I'm going to have to give a thumbs down for this game, and I doubt you'll ever see another penny coming out of me for your incompetence for a horrendous buisness practice (in-game cash shop after buying an AAA title game) and trying to force everyone to use your bad game launcher (UPLAY)

I bought the game being hyped when everyone saw the amazing CGI Cinematic Trailer The Crew showed off when it was first released on youtube, everyone really thought we were gonna have fun, join together as one with a Crew, with those being huge in the car culture, the trailer really represented us gamers what we really wanted and expected out of The Crew, to no avail tho the game itself was not like the trailer... sadly.

The Game was okay at the time, bought the gold edition that included seasons pass and had unlocked most of the sweet cars, seemed like a sweet deal. Despite the fact that the CGI Trailer was no where near close to how the game itself really was, The Crew was overall a game that had more pro's than cons at the time of it's release

Ubisoft then decided to be money hungry, and not only did they change the way how end game worked by reducing the chances of farming rare parts through skills (pushing for people to buy in-game currency and or pvp for them (again low chance), and ADDED a DLC which was not INCLUDED IN A SEASON'S PASS (which I also bought) and the DLC didn't contribute to anything that The Crew was at first, it didn't even make me want to come back to the game, all they did was add a competitive content that had barely ANY interactions between players, a bunch of monster trucks and motocycles that had basically nothing to do with the game as well. Drifting was a nice addition and was probably the only good thing out of the DLC, Drag racing was somewhat of a pointless feature in the game.


All in all with current status of this game.

The Crew is now in my opinion one of the worst car racing MMOs to date with the recent updates. I have to say.. Good job Ubisoft you finally surpassed EA in being the worst publisher and game developer ever existed in the gaming industry, it's like you ACTUALLY WANTED recognition for it and ♥♥♥♥ people off with your half made games that aren't even complete, even your game launcher is WORSE than Origin. JUST HOW can you not learn from your mistakes?

Again, not one penny out of me until I see things improve with you guys.

reviewText: So as you can see i have almost 1000 hours of gametime on The Crew.  I have played since the game was officially released and own almost every spec of every car.  When this game was released it got all kinds of terrible reviews but even at that time in it's incomplete state it was a good arcade style racing game compared to any NFS-type game before it.  Since that time they have added cars, stickers, colors, pvp options, graphics, race modes, bikes, monster trucks, 3 new specs (monster, drift, drag) in addition to the 5 already available (street, dirt, perf, raid, circuit), freedrive challenges, and tons of other things!  Some people will sit here and cry and complain about some technical issues with crashing, which is there from time to time, but with the amount of options they're adding to the game it's totally worth it.  Need For Speed is completely inferior to this game.  I have spent 125 dollars on this game including game, expansion pack, and season pass... I don't regret this at all because this game has been worth it!  There is no better open world arcade style racing game on the market right now (may 2016).
