reviewText:
If you liked TDU or TDU2, you'll like this. It's essentially TDU2.5; i.e. flawed, but still the most ambitious open world racing available. It's just plain fun.

GOOD. The world alone makes this game easily worth the asking price. The open world is AAA, the best in a racer to date, capturing a lot of diversity and the feeling of cruising in a big open-world. You might expect cities, highways, beaches, snow covered mountains, forrest trails, canyons, and (sadly only a few) in-world racetracks. But you're still likely to be surprised by the diversity here; swamps, dunes, salt flats, etc. The Crew's world is just a fun place to drive.

NOTSOMUCH. It's always online, which I might like just to reduce cheating, but requiring always online and not providing dedicated servers seems janky. One poorly connected player can effectively pause a race on and off through the whole race. Running into random players in the world is a core concept that I like, but again, poor implementation means the open world is VERY sparsley populated. I'm hoping they can fix this, but as it is, one of the biggest features in the game feels half-arsed.

Handling is on par with the TDU series - a better feel than full on cartoony arcade stuff like Burnout, but still very much (too much) cartoon racing. Also, the story is pretty cliche. But seriously, who cares about that in a racer?

Some things fall short of what this team pulled off in the TDU series. The great weather and bouncy baja-esque mountain roads from TDU2 are gone. No motorcycles. The car selection is mediocre at best. And the ability to instantly challenge other players is missing.

BOTTOM LINE. I'm still hoping for a talented developer with a serious budget to release a racing world like this with proper handling and a more polished take on seemlessly-integrated multiplayer. Until that happens, I guess this is as good as open world racing gets for now.

reviewText:
So after reading some of the top reviews for this game I want to throw in my 2 cents.

IS DIS A SIM RACUR?
No, the driving mechanic is very realistic, but it is very much an arcade racer, don't knock it for not being a sim when it's not trying to be.

AMURICAN UGLEH MUSCLE CARZZ!!!!!211211!!!!
The game is kinda based in America though.

DA MAP IS SO TINEY!!!1!
It took me over two hours in real life to drive across it, and that was the fastest route I could take, no detours.

DA STORYLINE IZ bAD!!!!
It's a racing game, has any racing game ever had a decent story?

I KANT KUSTUMIZE ME CHARACTR
Yeah, because you can customize the ♥♥♥♥ out of your car

TDU2>CREW
Lol are you kidding me? And TDU2 had such a GREEEAAAT story. And such a GREEEAT physics engine/handling model. That game was a joke, I'm starting to wonder if people launched that on accident.

UBI$OFT MICROTRANSACTIONS HURRRRRR
Everything you can get from microtransactions is attainable with in game money, obviously DLC cars won't be but almost every game has that even. You can complain about microtransactions all you want, they aren't going away.

SURVURS ALWAYZ DOWN!
I haven't seen the servers down once and I've been playing since launch day, I also played in the closed beta, never saw it then either.

I'm not saying it's a perfect game, I'm saying everyone is expecting a full fledged simulator when The Crew never set out to be that, it's revolutionary in the fact that there are so many different ways to customize your car, street, offroad, etc etc etc. I mean seriously somebody listed no working turn signals as a con, that's so petty.

Yeah, the mirrors don't have reflection and some of the shifting animations are fudged, sometimes the character will act like there's a paddle shift and there isn't which leaves him changing gears by swatting the air. As far as I can tell not enough people even use manual transmissions in game to care about shifting animations.

Overall this is an incredibly fun game with enough to keep me coming back for a while. I paid full price for it and I don't regret it.

EDIT: 12/17
I saw the servers go down once a few days ago, they were down for all of 15 minutes. Yeah I was butthurt but it was pretty quick. I'm still enjoying the game but there are a couple more annoyances.

PvP is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, everybody has full driving assists on and never even has to think, they go careening off walls and guard rails and beat you by 4+ seconds while you're taking care to not hit anything.

The factions are odd, there's 5(I think) factions in the game but only 2 or 3 actually have people. I just so happened to put myself on one of the ones with a significant lack of people and it takes me 20+ minutes to find a PvP match for the faction v faction mode. I honestly don't see why they put so many factions in the game.

Uplay's drivehub" is showing me news from 1-15-2015 lol

EDIT NUMBER 2 12/17

reviewText:
Are you looking for a Next Gen racing experience? Go look somewhere else.

UPDATE: 01/11/15
After nearly 3 months after launch there were only 2 patches correcting minor stuff but not a single commitment from Ubisoft on addressing wanted features in the game.
The Steam user satisfaction dropped its recommendation from 96% to 77% and it will continue to go down as more people figure out how little this game offers after 20 hours - which is a ridiculous little time for a MMO. --- CONTINUE TO STAY AWAY.


I've pre-ordered The Crew Gold +Season Pass expecting that all publishing on hard working to bring a new concept of game would be delivered. After my first 8 hours with the game I'm never ever buying Ubisoft games at launch anymore (As I'm already doing with Assassin's Creed franchise since Brotherhood).

The game isn't an evolution from what we've seen on the Beta phase, it is just a stability" upgrade in all aspects. To be honest
date: the only thing I've seen implemented from what was asked on forums during closed and open betas was the ability to change the gear faster while on manual shift
recommended: almost everything requested by the community was ignored.\n\nTo review the game I've used a Nvidia GTX-780 + i7-4770K overclocked
hoursPlayed:
my personal impressions below:

- Are you ready for Ubisoft concept of MMO?
It was confirmed by Ubi Community Manager that the "bug of few people per map" is in fact working as designed since they believe 8 player per map is OK.
For a game where the selling point is "Massive open world" this is a flaw.

- Don't expect to be able to play multiplayer
voteText: cause it isn't working as it should. It took me about 50 tries to be able to do 1 single coop mission since the message "There is no one in your session" was constantly been displayed even while I could see about 10 players on the map screen.\n\n- Do you like driving from cockpit and using the rear mirrors? Hopefully not cause they we're NOT implemented at all you will see is a gray piece of junk that since it isn't showing your rear shouldn't even be there. Surprisinly and adding "more fun" to the randomness of this issue
helpfulPercent:
when you put your view in 3rd person mode (behind the car)... TA DA! The mirrors magically start working! W-T-F!!!
Lets pause for a little reflection:
Since 1987 we have working rear mirrors thanks to Test Drive 1 but not in this advanced "next gen" title? There is no other racing series considering doing the same crap.

- Anti-Alising is so horribly implemented that even downsampling from 4K resolution to 1080p you will notice the jadded edges everywhere.
Specially when you're wandering inside cities hopefully you will not bother on blinking edges in general scenario elements like fences and light lamps

buildings and cars as you will be near to have a convulsion. Surprisinly AAs seems to had worked a lot better with "wild nature" elements so trees and vegetation don't suffer in the same heavy way cities do;

reviewText:
This game is amazing: despite the Ubisoft logo.
The map is 3x larger than GTAV, me and a friend measured Seattle to the Miami Keys and it's roughly 98.9 miles.
Other than that, flawless launch from Ivory Tower, very good optimization for a game designed for high end pc's.

It runs fine on my 750 Ti SC. My favorite parts is Death Valley, the Black Hills, even though I've only discovered only 6% of the map. I can't praise Ubisoft and Ivory Tower enough for The Crew. It is a huge check mark in the positive coloum for PC gaming. It's far from them earning their reputation back, but it's a very good start. Glitches and bugs are expected since this game is brand new.

WIth nice little easter eggs and salutes to past racing game legends like Need For Speed World, Hot Pursuit 2010, Burnout Paradise, Shift 2 Unleashed, Test Drive Unlimited 1 & 2 and many more, The Crew is a hotbed of MMO racing that just feels right. How many other games out there can you tune a Ford GT to 700hp, and wreck a Koenigsegg Agera R? I can't think of many.

Another huge check mark is the fact that the devs actually watch the forums; someone suggested that a free roam cam be added, like the one in NFS World, and within 12 hours someone from Ubisoft responded saying that something like that is in the works...

Now that's rare now a days.

reviewText:
I would like to start off with the biggest reason I even recommend this game is because it is the closest thing we PC gamers have to Midnight Club L.A.

I love and hate this game!
What is does right, it does right! What is does wrong, it really does it wrong!

I will only list the things wrong and missing in the game. It has everything else in my opinion!

1. This is possibly the biggest one for me and I don’t really know why! The side and rearview mirrors don’t work! WHAT THE HELL WERE THEY THINKING! Almost every racing game has working mirrors!
Racing games on mobile, last gen systems even the PS2 AND PS1 racing games had working mirrors!
This seriously needs to be fixed!

2. Not enough races or race types! There are plenty of street challenges… -_-
There are so few races that I forget I’m playing a RACING GAME sometimes!

3. Damage on cars are overdone in some places and underdone in others!
If I hit a leaf, my whole front end looks like I hit a tree at 200mph! But glass wont break or even crack even if I roll my car! This just seems lazy!

4. Textures look good on your cars and most of the environments. It’s not what you would expect from a next gen graphics game, but they look good. And with the size and scope of the game I would think they look amazing! Where is the bad? EVERY SINGLE PEDESTRIAN CAR AND THE PEDESTRIANS WALKING DOWN THE STREET! I have seen better textures on the PS2! I swear I am not exaggerating! They look horrible!!!
I can’t even begin to figure out why they thought this was OK!

5. Now on to the little things. No neon lights. Why is this a big deal? It is and isn’t. I like neon’s, what can I say? But in a game that is supposed to be an MMO, you need to have more customization!

6. No window tints.

7. Very limited on body parts.

8. The game has a lot of rims to choose from, but 90% of them all look the same!

9. Cant paint parts different colors.

10. The performance parts system is kind of wack! Look it up on YouTube.

11. Not a lot of cars to choose from. But at least they had my Skyline!

12. Its structured as a F2P type game. Now that wouldn’t be such a problem if it weren’t for the fact that they are selling it for $60. Plus I have played some F2P racing games that felt more complete than this game that had WORKING MIRRORS! (Sorry, but I’m not going to ever let that go till they fix it).

At any rate, the game is fun, not worth what I paid, but fun.
Buy it on a sale, a BIG sale! Anything over $20 is way too much! But if you really want to play a game that kind of reminds you of Midnight Club L.A. then this is the game for you….Kind of.. -_-

So yes I recommend it, even though is sucks!

reviewText: Fantastic game. Each spec you unlock changes how you play, and upgrading your vehicle is rewarding and challenging. Community events, plans for additional vehicles and features, and a strong fanbase/developer relationship means that The Crew has a bright future. The only downside is that a constant internet connection is required to play due to the MMO aspect, but considering no one seems to complain about World of Warcraft needing a constant network connection to play, I find it difficult to justify that complaint. If you're looking for a racing game that goes beyond what any Need for Speed title, especially the soon to be discontinued Need for Speed World, The Crew is just what you're looking for.

reviewText:
The Crew Review
This review will contain some stuff i love, like, dislike and hate about The Crew
Prepare yourself

---

Things I LOVE

- The Map
The best map I have EVER seen in a racing game, and not the biggest, but the most diverse map I have EVER played on. It's that good. It would take a large amount of hours to completely explore the map. I still haven't completely expored it in my many hour playtime. It takes about an hour (if you are going very fast) tho get from one side of the map to the other. It just such a fun map to drive around, to take a road trip, and to see all kinds of fabulous landmarks throughput your journeys.

-Everything about the cars
All the cars have lots of detal, interior and exterior. They are all different to drive, and unique in their own ways. Also, all the sounds for the cars are the legit real life sounds, recorded from the cars in a sound studion. SO nice.

---

Things I like

-Customization of car
The customization is quite good, especially compared to most of the recent need for speed games. The only problem is the customizations seem too concrete, there is no ability to add your own imagination or personal touch. Some stickers have different colors, but you can't change the color of a specific sticker. Also, each sticker goes on a certain, unchangable place on the car. You can make your car different than others, because there a large number of aesthetic parts and stickers.

-Car specs
I really like how the car can utilize many different utilities by changing the spec. There are 5 specs: Street, Dirt, Performance, Raid, and Circuit. They are all fun to experiment with. Some are great for the racetrack, while others are great for offroad trails. My only gripe about specs is that very few cars have the full 5 specs, most have 1-3 of the the specs. The starter cars all have the full 5 specs, so you will be able to have them all in at least one car.

-The story
It is surprising for a good story to be in a racing game, but in this case that surprise came true. It may seem cheesy and cliche to some people, but I thoroughly enjoyed it.

-The graphics
They aren't amazing by any means, but they are good. They capture american geography well (with a few minor hiccups) but there are many current racing games that have better graphics. They are definitely not bad though, they still make the game nice looking. The best graphics in the game are seen in some of the cutscenes. Legitimate movie quality cutscences.

---

Things i dont like

-The mmo" aspect of the game
Only 8 players in your session

reviewText:
Finally a good old Need for Speed like game!
This game is a really good game. The Crew is a Open World Racing Game with MMO and Coop features.
You get into the role of a racer named Alex who gets pretty much trouble with the group 5-10 of his brother. After his death you are on the way to get revenge!

Pls dont be too angry to me and my language. I´m not the best in writing english, but i want to tell you my opinion of this game, because it deserves to be telled of :)

Short Version
- Graphics: 7 / 10
- Performance: 10 / 10
- Storytelling: 7 / 10
- Possibilitys: 10 / 10
- Server-Onlinetime: 9 / 10

► Total Grade: 9 / 10


Long Version

Graphics
The Graphics of this game are pretty good and well done for a racing game being that big. But compared to other titles released today not the best and detailed one. Not saying that they are almost perfect for a game like this, its still not the best it could be.
Shader is well done, also the Antialising. Textures are well but not that detailed and a little bit spongy" if you are looking close to them. However
date:
its a well done composition of textures and it´s nice for the eye.
7 / 10

Performance
Due to the fact

reviewText:
If the Need for Speed franchise is tyring to get back to their roots (and I have completed the newest game) they really need to look to these guys for inspiration as this game does a much better job of mixing a good motive to get you started as well as keeping to many of the gameplay elements that made older need for speed games legendary. Having domination and customization at its core. As well, This game is ambitious to say the least, mapping the entire U.S.A to a scale that offers a surprizing veriety of locations to visit and scout. After a year they looked to reinvigorate the game by releasing a sort of overhauling DLC, adding new mechanics, game modes, and vehicle types, Even updating the graphics with new textures and weather effects. the DLC costs $30 but the base game has been reduced putting the whole game with the new overhaul somewhere around 40 - $50, which is well worth the entry for a great example of how to handle an aging brand without pumping out another game within an unrealistic deadline. The mechanics and physics are not on par with the best of the old Need for Speed arcade type open world racer, they feel very loose and a bit unpredictable at times, but for the overall experience the handling gets a pass by me. the open world and storyline feel overarcing and important, something we sorely lack in AAA titles these days, A sense of importance. One problem that holds this game back is the fact that it is set up as an MMO, which means microtransactions, which means spiked economy costs for things that a singleplayer would allow within much more reasonable values, if it were a singleplayer game it would probably have a much longer story and a much bigger payoff to upgrading cars and progressing, but instead we have every car roughly as fast as eachother and performance upgrades unlocking in a random loot counter sort of setup wich makes buying upgrades almost pointless. Just one example of how MMO is most often not the way to go with your game. I think the game would have greatly benefited on being singleplayer focused while having the same online components it already does, the MMO features in the core game are like any other AAA game that tries to go MMO, theyre pointless, its immerssion breaking, its economy stifling, it simply doesnt work.

So I give this game a 7/10 (Buy instead of that new NFS)
For a person whos played just about every racer under the sun, its a good game to have around if you want to play around in, from time to time, or just see the sites of the U.S in game form.

reviewText:
So last year after playing for 80 hours I gave this game a bad review. I said easy fix, let us make a race and do our own checkpoints. Then i forgot about this game and a friend of mine gave me the DLC as a gift, and behold, exactly what I suggested happened.

I put about another 40 hours into it already with my friends trying to increase our ranking in the wild run.

The only thing i don't like about this game is what they call SMART LOOT. You pretty much are forced into getting gold  just to get an upgrade to your car that only adds a point or 2 to the specs when you can get platinum which should be a better part. Sometimes smart loot gives you a part, but mostly a new color paint job that if i wanted I would buy. But with limited tuning that seems to not matter in the end with a mini cooper with the same specs as a hyper car. It wouldve been fine to cap off lower end cars, it would have made the game more fun to get faster cars and actually made the season pass worth it.

7/10 with friends
5/10 solo

reviewText:
There's not too much to say about this game, but I feel obligated to write a review after enjoying ~150hrs of it.

The Crew is an open world arcade style driving game with nice graphics and a whole lot of space to cruise around. There are around 70+ cars I believe, and that number increases every month.

The game has minor updates pretty regularly, with a large update happening every few months.

I'd say it's worth the $30 price tag, assuming you don't mind the lack of realism, but ideally you'll want to wait for a sale.

I'm willing to answer any further questions in the comments, and will update this review if necessary.

reviewText:
There are few games I actually like enough to write reviews about (and they mostly suck in quality too) but this game desereves an honest review.

Ofcourse a lot of people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about the season pass not including the Wild Run DLC but I never bought a season pass or the wild run, I just bought this game on sale because I wanted to play an good looking open world racing game and this one was worth the 14 euros I spend on it in a sale.

So lets start with the story

Many racing games lack a story entirely or just have a basic one.
This game is no difference, although the game has a lot more effort in giving a race an purpose, every race has a few lines of voice acting giving the context why you do it. so its not just why did I just ram some random car off the road" in which the game responds "because OH HEY LOOK REWARDS!"

The story itself to spoil the least
date:
Alex Taylor is a racer that wants to join the 5-10's but on the day he would get his ink his brother gets shot by Shiv and then you pretty much try to raise yourself in the 5-10 ranks to get revenge. (again im pretty much just explaining it bare bones there is a lot more to it).

For a racing game story i'll give it a: 7/10
For a general game story its a: 5/10 characters dont get any in-depth story

Graphics

The Graphics in this game are really good. shadows look great. cars super detailed. first person driving looks great too. Rain is stunning.

Night time is a little bright if you aren't in a shadow or if it' s raining. the world itself is detailed and there are people on the streets just walking around
recommended:
some carrying stuff. (i even hit some hobo with a shopping trolley once) there is also wildlife running around from squirrels to moose. (Ofcourse it being a ubisoft game there is no senseless killing so you cant actually hit the people or animals) The forests feel dense and real.

There is even an in-game photo mode which allows you to take your own pictures in a higher resolution then you actually run the game. I have made a ton of screenshots using it and I even have a few new Computer backgrounds thanks to it.

There are a few pre-rendered cutscenes. Which im actually still trying to figure out if they are real recordings with the character models 3d rendered into them or if they are actually modelled so well that they look photo realistic.

The bad few things include:

A few floating rocks and tree's in forest areas off track.

Character faces in game up close are really ugly compared to the rest of the game.

short draw distance on cars (detailing like spoilers dissapear if they go a little far away even on ultra). wheel tracks also do not stay long
hoursPlayed:
in the ending cutscene the camera pans into the distance following your car which is outside of the draw distance so it isent visible. Dust trails are really small (so small that if you look behind yourself in first person you dont see any dirt/dust kick up)

Mirror's have no real time reflection. (only like GTA V does. reflects low res world but no cars or anything) No option to enable a HUD rear view mirror.
AI cars in photo-mode dissapear after a short while due to the fact that the game is online and the cars drive on going beyond draw distance and de-spawning.

Graphically for a racing game this is the prettiest game I have played. 9/10 (compared to other racing games like Need for speed)


The Gameplay

First the biggest thing I like is the fact that there are more then 2 cars on the road. on highways in major cities you can actually end up just rushing past a continous row of cars. so driving on roads feel actually used instead of the ghost roads you drive on in games like Need For Speed.

Cars handle pretty good
voteText: feel heavy and in control. I barely drove any other cars then the forced cars and the starting car you pick though. (yes you can easily complete the whole game with the starting car)
helpfulPercent:
I've only had 3 occasions of physics doing weird and getting launched at crazy speeds. a few AI cars also glitch sometimes but there is nothing massive as far as i noticed.

The special thing about this game is the always online world.

So far as i noticed the map is devided in section servers. Major cities have a special server and the country around those cities have seperate servers. I personally have a good internet connection and the server crossings have been seamless. no lag
votesHelpful: no freezes
votesTotal:
no "connecting to server" stuff.

Ofcourse if you are like me you coulden't care less about the online stuff and rather don't have any online stuff.
there sadly isen't a offline mode. but the game plays pretty much single player
votesFunny: nothing online is forced on you
commentsCount:
you could play it as if it were a single player game. Every race can be done solo (meaning you and AI).

The AI is easy. As far as I noticed there is no difficulty curve (but this could also be because racing might be one of the game types im decently skilled at) The difficulty is addaptive to your cars level. so if a mission says its hard it's most likely easy if you actually know how to drive well. I even ended up having a 10 second split time on a hard mission.

I should also not forget to mention that this game is not your generic "buy parts in the shop to upgrade" type. you unlock the parts after every race depending on how well you did. so being first doesent mean a gold part.  once you reach level 50 (the max level) you get platinum ratings which use "smart loot" as far as i noticed its not that smart and is just an fancy name for "randomized loot"

There are also on road skill challenges a few are:

Speed: drive on the road as fast and far as possible
Jump: Jump over a ramp into a landing zone
Precision: squeeze through gates that become smaller and smaller
Slalom: drive around posts

These also use the bronze
column16: silver
column17:
gold loot system.

The Bad

This game also features Cops. Which are no threat at all and barely worth mentioning except for in the "escape from the cops" missions.
They barely do anything. you can speed past them at 300 Kmp/h and then wont do a thing.
The only few times i've gotten in a chase was when I purposely rammed the cop car or rammed a bunch of AI cars and objects.

If you do manage to get into a chase. well they arent that good either. if you want to have a good chase your better off playing Need for Speed Carbon or Most Wanted 2005.

You can get 6 stars which only changes how many cars chase you. at 4 you get a helicopter after you (which is the only hard enemy to lose) Road blocks are mostly 1 car and a police sign or on highways like 3 cars and a sign so easily avoided and they will not use Spike Strips or anything like that.

You can't disable the road skills meaning you either have to go around or start it and then close it via your phone.


I still rate gameplay an 8/10 due to how good the cars felt


Soundtrack

Not so much to say about the soundtrack. most missions have a special soundtrack which is mostly dramatic orchestral and a bit electric.

The in-game radio stations aren't that great either. I mainly listened to 2 of them
column18:
Koda boom for in the city and Sine wave digital for the countryside.
There is a "custom" playlist option which means "pick songs from our radio stations!" and no importing of your own music.
(a huge thing that bugged me was how the power glove songs (from Far cry 3 blood dragon) still had the in game sound effects in them. You made the game how do you not have a clean version!)

In races where there was no special soundtrack I would open my steam overlay and just look up some other music.

So the music in this game gets a 4/10 you might like the tracks in the game though. It's just a matter of taste.

Story. Graphics. Gameplay. sountrack. that's about everything I think
column19:
and im running out of Review space.
Well for the TL:DR people:
its a good racing game that is worth playing if on sale.

rating 8/10"

reviewText: The Crew™ is probably the best car game I've ever played! There are a lot of cars to discover and drive. You can tune and customize your car almost just as you want. I bought the Gold Edition becuase i have seen the game on YouTube and knew that this game was made for those who both like good stories and cars. The story in The Crew™ is probably something I've never seen before. With a lot of action in this game, I could easily give this a 10/10! And for the extra feeling of driving a real car, buy the Logitech g27 Racing Wheel. I highly recommend this beautiful game.

reviewText: Fantastic game. Each spec you unlock changes how you play, and upgrading your vehicle is rewarding and challenging. Community events, plans for additional vehicles and features, and a strong fanbase/developer relationship means that The Crew has a bright future. The only downside is that a constant internet connection is required to play due to the MMO aspect, but considering no one seems to complain about World of Warcraft needing a constant network connection to play, I find it difficult to justify that complaint. If you're looking for a racing game that goes beyond what any Need for Speed title, especially the soon to be discontinued Need for Speed World, The Crew is just what you're looking for.

reviewText:
Finally a good old Need for Speed like game!
This game is a really good game. The Crew is a Open World Racing Game with MMO and Coop features.
You get into the role of a racer named Alex who gets pretty much trouble with the group 5-10 of his brother. After his death you are on the way to get revenge!

Pls dont be too angry to me and my language. I´m not the best in writing english, but i want to tell you my opinion of this game, because it deserves to be telled of :)

Short Version

reviewText:
The Crew Review
This review will contain some stuff i love, like, dislike and hate about The Crew
Prepare yourself

---

Things I LOVE

- The Map
The best map I have EVER seen in a racing game, and not the biggest, but the most diverse map I have EVER played on. It's that good. It would take a large amount of hours to completely explore the map. I still haven't completely expored it in my many hour playtime. It takes about an hour (if you are going very fast) tho get from one side of the map to the other. It just such a fun map to drive around, to take a road trip, and to see all kinds of fabulous landmarks throughput your journeys.

-Everything about the cars
All the cars have lots of detal, interior and exterior. They are all different to drive, and unique in their own ways. Also, all the sounds for the cars are the legit real life sounds, recorded from the cars in a sound studion. SO nice.

---

Things I like

-Customization of car
The customization is quite good, especially compared to most of the recent need for speed games. The only problem is the customizations seem too concrete, there is no ability to add your own imagination or personal touch. Some stickers have different colors, but you can't change the color of a specific sticker. Also, each sticker goes on a certain, unchangable place on the car. You can make your car different than others, because there a large number of aesthetic parts and stickers.

-Car specs
I really like how the car can utilize many different utilities by changing the spec. There are 5 specs: Street, Dirt, Performance, Raid, and Circuit. They are all fun to experiment with. Some are great for the racetrack, while others are great for offroad trails. My only gripe about specs is that very few cars have the full 5 specs, most have 1-3 of the the specs. The starter cars all have the full 5 specs, so you will be able to have them all in at least one car.

-The story
It is surprising for a good story to be in a racing game, but in this case that surprise came true. It may seem cheesy and cliche to some people, but I thoroughly enjoyed it.

-The graphics
They aren't amazing by any means, but they are good. They capture american geography well (with a few minor hiccups) but there are many current racing games that have better graphics. They are definitely not bad though, they still make the game nice looking. The best graphics in the game are seen in some of the cutscenes. Legitimate movie quality cutscences.

---

Things i dont like

-The mmo" aspect of the game
Only 8 players in your session
date: and they players continually switch to different players
hoursPlayed: yeah

Other racers

-Customization of your character
Nonexistent. Hopefully you are okay with the way you look

---

-ubisoft in general

reviewText:
There are few games I actually like enough to write reviews about (and they mostly suck in quality too) but this game desereves an honest review.

Ofcourse a lot of people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about the season pass not including the Wild Run DLC but I never bought a season pass or the wild run, I just bought this game on sale because I wanted to play an good looking open world racing game and this one was worth the 14 euros I spend on it in a sale.

So lets start with the story

Many racing games lack a story entirely or just have a basic one.
This game is no difference, although the game has a lot more effort in giving a race an purpose, every race has a few lines of voice acting giving the context why you do it. so its not just why did I just ram some random car off the road" in which the game responds "because OH HEY LOOK REWARDS!"

The story itself to spoil the least
date:
Alex Taylor is a racer that wants to join the 5-10's but on the day he would get his ink his brother gets shot by Shiv and then you pretty much try to raise yourself in the 5-10 ranks to get revenge. (again im pretty much just explaining it bare bones there is a lot more to it).

For a racing game story i'll give it a: 7/10
For a general game story its a: 5/10 characters dont get any in-depth story

Graphics

The Graphics in this game are really good. shadows look great. cars super detailed. first person driving looks great too. Rain is stunning.

Night time is a little bright if you aren't in a shadow or if it' s raining. the world itself is detailed and there are people on the streets just walking around
recommended:
some carrying stuff. (i even hit some hobo with a shopping trolley once) there is also wildlife running around from squirrels to moose. (Ofcourse it being a ubisoft game there is no senseless killing so you cant actually hit the people or animals) The forests feel dense and real.

There is even an in-game photo mode which allows you to take your own pictures in a higher resolution then you actually run the game. I have made a ton of screenshots using it and I even have a few new Computer backgrounds thanks to it.

There are a few pre-rendered cutscenes. Which im actually still trying to figure out if they are real recordings with the character models 3d rendered into them or if they are actually modelled so well that they look photo realistic.

The bad few things include:

A few floating rocks and tree's in forest areas off track.

Character faces in game up close are really ugly compared to the rest of the game.

short draw distance on cars (detailing like spoilers dissapear if they go a little far away even on ultra). wheel tracks also do not stay long
hoursPlayed:
in the ending cutscene the camera pans into the distance following your car which is outside of the draw distance so it isent visible. Dust trails are really small (so small that if you look behind yourself in first person you dont see any dirt/dust kick up)

Mirror's have no real time reflection. (only like GTA V does. reflects low res world but no cars or anything) No option to enable a HUD rear view mirror.
AI cars in photo-mode dissapear after a short while due to the fact that the game is online and the cars drive on going beyond draw distance and de-spawning.

Graphically for a racing game this is the prettiest game I have played. 9/10 (compared to other racing games like Need for speed)


The Gameplay

First the biggest thing I like is the fact that there are more then 2 cars on the road. on highways in major cities you can actually end up just rushing past a continous row of cars. so driving on roads feel actually used instead of the ghost roads you drive on in games like Need For Speed.

Cars handle pretty good
voteText: feel heavy and in control. I barely drove any other cars then the forced cars and the starting car you pick though. (yes you can easily complete the whole game with the starting car)
helpfulPercent:
I've only had 3 occasions of physics doing weird and getting launched at crazy speeds. a few AI cars also glitch sometimes but there is nothing massive as far as i noticed.

The special thing about this game is the always online world.

So far as i noticed the map is devided in section servers. Major cities have a special server and the country around those cities have seperate servers. I personally have a good internet connection and the server crossings have been seamless. no lag
votesHelpful: no freezes
votesTotal:
no "connecting to server" stuff.

Ofcourse if you are like me you coulden't care less about the online stuff and rather don't have any online stuff.
there sadly isen't a offline mode. but the game plays pretty much single player
votesFunny: nothing online is forced on you
commentsCount:
you could play it as if it were a single player game. Every race can be done solo (meaning you and AI).

The AI is easy. As far as I noticed there is no difficulty curve (but this could also be because racing might be one of the game types im decently skilled at) The difficulty is addaptive to your cars level. so if a mission says its hard it's most likely easy if you actually know how to drive well. I even ended up having a 10 second split time on a hard mission.

I should also not forget to mention that this game is not your generic "buy parts in the shop to upgrade" type. you unlock the parts after every race depending on how well you did. so being first doesent mean a gold part.  once you reach level 50 (the max level) you get platinum ratings which use "smart loot" as far as i noticed its not that smart and is just an fancy name for "randomized loot"

There are also on road skill challenges a few are:

Speed: drive on the road as fast and far as possible
Jump: Jump over a ramp into a landing zone
Precision: squeeze through gates that become smaller and smaller
Slalom: drive around posts

These also use the bronze
column16: silver
column17:
gold loot system.

The Bad

This game also features Cops. Which are no threat at all and barely worth mentioning except for in the "escape from the cops" missions.
They barely do anything. you can speed past them at 300 Kmp/h and then wont do a thing.
The only few times i've gotten in a chase was when I purposely rammed the cop car or rammed a bunch of AI cars and objects.

If you do manage to get into a chase. well they arent that good either. if you want to have a good chase your better off playing Need for Speed Carbon or Most Wanted 2005.

You can get 6 stars which only changes how many cars chase you. at 4 you get a helicopter after you (which is the only hard enemy to lose) Road blocks are mostly 1 car and a police sign or on highways like 3 cars and a sign so easily avoided and they will not use Spike Strips or anything like that.

You can't disable the road skills meaning you either have to go around or start it and then close it via your phone.


I still rate gameplay an 8/10 due to how good the cars felt


Soundtrack

Not so much to say about the soundtrack. most missions have a special soundtrack which is mostly dramatic orchestral and a bit electric.

The in-game radio stations aren't that great either. I mainly listened to 2 of them
column18:
Koda boom for in the city and Sine wave digital for the countryside.
There is a "custom" playlist option which means "pick songs from our radio stations!" and no importing of your own music.
(a huge thing that bugged me was how the power glove songs (from Far cry 3 blood dragon) still had the in game sound effects in them. You made the game how do you not have a clean version!)

In races where there was no special soundtrack I would open my steam overlay and just look up some other music.

So the music in this game gets a 4/10 you might like the tracks in the game though. It's just a matter of taste.

Story. Graphics. Gameplay. sountrack. that's about everything I think
column19:
and im running out of Review space.
Well for the TL:DR people:
its a good racing game that is worth playing if on sale.

rating 8/10"

reviewText:
Got it on sale for $40 - Gold Edition. Then it is worth the price. Screw paying $80, no matter how good.

And this game is great :) The world across the US is amazing. Cities feel familiar and the modelling is excellent. Mini challenges always keep it fun. Story line is great, much better than NFS franchise (another EA horse beaten dead). The PVP lobby system not that good. My cars went from 200 through 800 during the story game and get matched up with 1200 cars. No point in racing even. Guess the lower levels are playing the story game.

Driving is excellent and feels good handling. There quite a few neat tricks to learn. The different kind of cars drive great (street, dirt, perf, raid) and you get to upgrade the visuals to get amazing cars.

I'll keep coming back to get a few 1200 rides and kick some PVP ♥♥♥. Well done guys, great game.

reviewText:
This is a fun game for what it is. It is by no strecth of the imagination what the developers told us it was going to be and unless you feel ok with mucking around with router settings the never drive alone" tag-line will be a confident slap in the face.

But it is still a fun arcade racer that looks good and offers some really nice open world play with a lot of things to do from jumps and slaoms to classic exploring. Also once you get it to work PvP multi-player is fun and frantic. Same with the co-op part of the game. It is far from perfect but it is still one really good ride.

That being said... It has some very shifty multiplayer and use som peer2peer solution limiting how many players you can run at the same time.

It also have DLC and pay-only cars out the tailpipe."

reviewText: This game can be very fun, and it definitely has a lot of options, both for single/campaign mode, as well as online mode. I'm definitely not a big fan of online gaming, but I did give it a try on this game and I will admit that I did enjoy it. What PISSES me off about this game is the fact that for certain challenges (in story mode) they computer AI CHEATS LIKE A MOTHER F*@#ER and it drove my blood to boil a lot of times, to the point that I almost threw my controller at the computer monitor. I wish they would 1, allow for different difficulty modes, especially for those people that are more about story line than gameplay, and 2, that they would allow for the use of trainers/cheats for the campaign only part of the game. I thought the visuals were pretty stunning, particularly the settings. I really loved the whole continental US map which you can freely drive to your heart's content. I wish they would have an update that would allow for a road trip to Alaska, that would just be AWESOME! Anyway, I do recommmend the game, however be warned you will lose your cool at some point... If you're that type of gamer that hates it when the computer AI cheats both the physics, and the fact that the other drivers are always faster than you, despite having a higher levle car than the suggested level on screen.

reviewText:
1st let me say I have never written a review for any game before.

Now I ama racing game lover but for the last 5 years or so I haven't found a racing game that can hold my interest for more than an hour at a time.  I bought this game with a friend and he and I mostly play together and that is extremely fun.

The story is just ok, not great but who cares this is a racing game.  There are not a lot of cars in the game at the moment but that is ok all of the cars in the game a really nice.  I drive from inside the car with the dash board view, unless I am doing the missions where you run through a banner as you go because it takes you off road and you are usually running through brush and you just can't see from inside.

I really like this game and came into it with no preconceived notions about what to expect.  My buddy and I just spent 2 1/2 hours just driving and unlocking more of the map occasionally doing fun side races.

This brings me back to the old original test drive games way back when.

I really really like this game and the only con I have at the moment is I do get discord and it takes 15 to 20 minutes to get back on.

This is an Mmo but just like most new mmo's you don't have to play with other people.

reviewText:
While the story is somewhat entertaining, the gameplay is really quite boring. There's literally nothing to do but race around, and while it is a racing game, the trailers hinted at other forms of gameplay and much more exciting cinematics. It's not a bad game, but its not a good game either. The story is pretty minimal compared to most games, and trying to tie this story into a continually running server-based platform makes for some really annoying drive times.

Also we were promised the whole country, as though that would be to scale. Nope. Everything has been scaled down so that most of the cities are a third of their actual sizes. I threw down a lot of money for this game because I thought I would be getting a lot out of it. Really, because of the setup we actually got, I say this game is worth no more than $30. If the animations and the LOD look right up your alley, you might be inspired to pay $40. But never is it ever worth the full AAA studio pricing.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

So now that we have Wild Run, I guess the only thing I can say is WHY didn't I get it with my season pass? Considering it adds modes like DRAG racing, DRIFTING, etc. that most racing games have from the start, I think it should have been a free update. I won't be wasting my money on Wild Run though. The gameplay as a whole is still really boring.

reviewText: What The Crew gets right is its stylised and scaled-down version of the entire continental USA. Cities are shrunken caricatures, but the truly vast sweeping tracts of land between them means traversing it really does capture the spirit of a cross-country, city-to-city road trip better than any driving game before it. Plenty of racing games curate a bunch of different backdrops into their track selections, from urban street races in major American metropolitan centres to icy blasts across snow-swept mountains, flat-out sprints across the baking desert, or muddy expeditions through giant Sequoia forests. The Crew admirably does all this in a single game world you can drive across in one lengthy session.\nThis girth has come at a cost, though. It’s a world that looks fine whipping by you at speed, but it favours sheer size over the kind of granular detail we now expect in modern open world racers. Cities are smattered with recognisable landmarks but don’t really seem built to stand up to stationary scrutiny. Combined with low-detailed NPC cars (complete with entirely black, opaque glass), some forgettable effects (splashing water is especially dire), no weather, and the fact that the models of the 40-or-so cars are in a league below those of contemporaries like Forza Horizon 2 or Driveclub, The Crew struggles to shake the look of a game several years older than it actually is.

reviewText:
MUST NOT BUY for following major reasons:

1. EXTREMELY BUGGY since the launch of game. Unacceptable issues has been brought up with almost every month's patch which makes us nearly think they're here to make the game worse: how the car viewing angle turned 90deg with chase cam when your car's overlapping another opponent's car in no collision race (solved), stuttering issues for high-end PCs (NOT SOLVED AFTER A YEAR), nitrous not working for online races with manual without at least 1 car reset since Wild Run, NOT SOLVED WHAT THE... , and this March patch what has just turned up? ATI and Nvidea graphics users might not even able to start the game and game crash straight away.

2. RUBBISH car physics. Even by arcade standards the physics are pure trolls, EVEN AFTER WILD RUN. For god sake Ubisoft your game engine is based on Atari's Test Drive Unlimited 2. How the hell  could you possibly make it so much worse than that game what the FU*K? O_O TDU2 at least has friendly controls while still retains bit of realism, if by no means much ... but you Ubi, bikes that can go to complete stop from 350km/h/220MPH in less than 2 seconds plus hit the wall at almost 90deg and still no crash, catch-up mechanics and INSANE AMOUNT of slipstream that can allow a car to override top speed by 70km/h and TOTALLY ruins online competition, collision physics that allows your car to skid" past traffic even when u hit them head on
date: race cars that can go 420km/h with those huge wings+corner 50% faster than in reality ... it's honestly disgusting in its own way. I rather have something even more detached from reality (e.g. Burnout
recommended:
Ridge Racer) than experiencing your half-♥♥♥♥♥ efforts trying to go for poor extents of realism.

2.5. Extra steering rate for non-DirectInput controllers and steering wheels. Ehm yes ... if u uses either 1 of them you have an unfair advantage of being able to steer the front wheels so much at any speeds and the car can still response to such even at likes of 300km/h because of bullsh*t overpowered tire physics.

3. Poor online structure. In simplest terms
hoursPlayed: The Crew uses some of the worst multiplayer connection programming which results in players in the same lobby who're not host to have latency. This often ends up with the host "off-sync" from his actual positions causing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ stuff including both palyers slipstreaming each other on their own screens and the 3th place host player in a close finish ended up 1st in result screen. "Summit" tracks also lacking checkpoints real badly

reviewText:
The Crew tries to be a driving game with something for everyone. You can team up with a group of friends for an epic road trip filled with fast-paced illegal activities, and seamlessly explore a massive map of the U.S., from the tip of Maine, all the way down to Miami, over to Los Angeles and back again, passing through other iconic cities along the way. Though it's true that all of this is possible, the experience isn't all that it's made out to be. The Crew tries to do a lot, and while it technically delivers the features it promises, it frequently stumbles over itself. There are brief moments of joy within, but just when you start to think the game's turned a corner, a bump in the road sends your joyride careening off course. When the best thing a racing game has going for it is the variety of environments it has to offer, you know something's amiss.

You start off in the streets of Detroit, but it's not long before you're rolling through mountains, everglades, and forests. The huge maps and its colossal number of activities is intimidating at first, but that's great: the more places to go and things to do, the merrier. Story missions, which take you through a trope-filled campaign that plays out like a Fast & Furious sequel, send you from one region of the country to the next, and missions emerge out of the blue along the way. You street race, smuggle contraband, take down competing criminals, and tackle bite-sized emergent challenges that test your abilities behind the wheel while you're on the go. There are hundreds of things to do, but only some are truly fun. The problem? With so much ground to cover, The Crew feels and looks like it's stretched too thin, and it's evident from the start. The Crew's world may be massive and varied, but it's not good-looking. It's constantly plagued by texture and geometry pop-in, and looks generally outdated. People, buildings, the environment, and most importantly, the cars, are represented by disappointing models that suffer from an unsightly amount of aliasing.

Keep in mind that if UPlay, PSN, or Xbox Live is down, you can't play The Crew, even if you just want to go solo. During my time with the game, I was booted due to server or connection issues on a daily basis, which was very frustrating. The most enjoyment you get out of the game's connected world comes from player-vs-player competitions, but even they have issues.

reviewText:
Introduction:An open world MMO racing game. For what was presented and explained the game is great and got the job done. For how much devs were needed to created something like this a lot of things should have been different. Seems like they took more time on the map than the cars what you can do with them.

Pros:Great graphics
Huge map
Great wheel settings
Good netcode
Good story/SP missions

Cons:Not a good amount of cars to choose from (compared to Forza Horizon 2 and others)
Low max level
Once you're done with the campaign there isn't much to do except race others and try to get other cars
Money is too hard to get compared to how much cars cost
Sometimes you won't see another player for 1+ hours

Conclusion:Overall it is a solid racing game but there are some things that I would have liked to see. Maybe wait for discounts.

For more reviews check out  Original Curators Group

reviewText:
I will write a quick, straight on review for those who are wonder how the game is.
This come from 33 hours of gameplay, story done, top 90th in pvp some days ago.

There are things that bothers me about the game:

-Customization part is that there aren't really many hoods, bumpers and stuff to chose from they mostly have little details changing between them, and they are usually tied to a spec, so this mean, no Skyline stock hood on a Perfomance spec Skyline! Bumpers and the rest are usually repetitive, not to mention the vynils You can't change their colours.

-MMO feeling, this is the misleading part. In your world (your session) you will only be able to see 8 players on the whole US (at least for now) Yes, 8 this is not your typical MMORPG where you see hundred of people. So keep that in mind if you were thinking about it

- Lack of JDM cars: Only three. Ain't gonna describe this much, just three, the rest is almost entire muscle cars with some european exceptions.
_______________________________________________________________________

Story is entertaining, not much to add into this part, characters are fine, not precisely boring, but nothing out of this world :]

Cops are incredibly fast, think about artificial difficulty, just like that, a crown vic can catch your LaFerrari full throttle, something like Most Wanted, but way more aggresive, if you like challenges, then i guess you will like it, but sometimes, it's a bit unfair, and they don't share the same physics as your car (you can't slam them offroad, they are like anchors)

One important thing, people tend to whine about the boat handling like GTA IV. It gets A LOT better on the mid-end game, the starter cars are the problem, and the fact it's a MMO, you NEED to level up to get better handling, speed, and so on, and it is highly recommend to play without assists.
Cars are all the same performance wise when you upgrade their parts to max, this means that if you are not a 16 y/o bugatti fan, your favorite $50k grand car will be able to compete to an Agera R and not remain obsolete in the the early levels!

Cruising on the states is an amazing feeling, at least that's what i felt since im kind of NA enthusiast in the future. Just keep in mind that this game is way better with friends, so you better get someone in with you. It will make the exploration feeling incredible, and there are plenty of stuff to do. From Skills, to PvP, and Co-Op missions (races up to 2,5h and maybe more!)

To finish this quick review, my final words:
I think the game is on sale somewhere (christmas season maybe?)
Is the game worth it's full price? If you ask me, i do not regret it. Is it fun even in solo? It is, yeah pretty much. Will it be supported for a long time? It's a game that doesn't have a direct competitor on PC, so think about it :]


See you in the States if you decide to give it a try! Claxon me up if you see a Gun Metal Gray R34 rocketing on the roads ;]

It'd doesn't feel like an MMO. It has a few poorly designed UI elements that appear directly mid-screen while you are driving, which screws up the flow. The police are completely unrealistic. The storyline is one dimensional.

Awesome, but I'm not going to do it.

reviewText:
This is going to be very long, but I am very passionate about this. Long story short, I do not think this game is worth $60+ I would consider it closer to a $30-$40 game. Very stable, especially for Ubisoft, and I enjoyed myself.

When this game was first announced at E3, I was so excited. It appeared to be close to the game I'd been hoping for years ago. I have always been a fan of racing games, and over the last few years I've been underwhelmed by the options on PC. I was quick to pre-order The Crew despite my displeasure with Ubisoft and Watch_Dogs especially. When I played the Beta for The Crew, I was met with a stable game which was nice, but there were little things that bothered me. First and foremost was their approach to many of the landmarks of the US. I live in Las Vegas, so once I finally got there, I was underwhelmed. I feel like GTA San Andreas had a better looking Vegas than this game does. I then noticed that Mazda Laguna Seca was on the map also. Laguna Seca is one of my favorite Tracks ever, so I had to see it. After my initial woes with Las Vegas, I was mildly worried. My fears came true, and this point I was legitamately upset.  If you are going to take the time to put a track as Iconic as Laguna Seca in the game, at least do it justice. The Corkscrew, a sweeping S curve, with a 3 story drop, is flat in the game. plus the bump just before the corner turns into a jump at any speed greater than about 50 mph. I understand they can't capture every single part of the US but for tracks, especially those like Laguna Seca, at least make them like the real thing. Car selection is very limited comapred to most other racing titles, but you can go through the entire game with your starter car. there really is no need to spend money at all. I beat the game only spending 2200 on mirrors for my Ferrari, because the Italian flag decal didn't really fit withthe rest of the car. All class upgrades are paid for and individula parts are awarded from skill challenges. unless you want to drive a different car, or make the ones you have prettier, there is absolutely no need to buy anything. I am not very ggod at games in general so I found some missions to be very frustrating. The takedown missions in particular were an annoyance for me. trying to chase someone down and inflict enough damage was very difficult for me. As were the Smash missions, hit a certain number of container within the time limit. it would take me over an hour just for those missions, mostly due to physics (more on that later). The story was pretty much what you would expect from a racing game. Not super indepth, lots of random missions that you have to do with no real explanation of why, but it does have a rather logical progression, and moves at a decent pace. I played through the entire campaign solo, and the only time i interacted with other players was occasionally having a head on collision mid corner. now that I beat the story I might look more into Faction missions, but for now, I found the online function to be more of an annoyance than anything useful.  Overall, I would say that from a game play standpoint, I wasn't really disappointed.

From a technological stand point I was.... I'll say satisfied. In 24.6 hours of play the game only crashed 3 times. As far as servers go, the only time I had trouble connecting was when they were performing server maintanence. Visually, this is actually a very good looking game. If it weren't for the 60 fps lock, and the strange Depth of Field effects I wouldn't have any complaints. Honestly, playing at max settings (motion blur and depth of field off) I was playing at 3140 x 2160 on my  GTX 980 at a stable 60 fps, and gpu usage was only at around 70%. I would have liked to be able to fully utilize 144 Hz that my monitor is capable of, but for whatever reason they locked it to 60. Not a deal breaker for the vast majority of consumers, but it was mildly irksome for me. Normal road driving is quite satisfying, once I turned driving assists to hardcore, I was quite content with the handling. The collision detection baffles me though. there is no consistency as far as what constitutes a full crash and what is just a glancing blow. I had times that I would ram into the back of a pedestrian vehicle by more than half of it, and my car would just glitch" to one side and I wouldn't lose more than a couple mph. other times there would be a couple of feet between my car and the pedestrian vehicle
date: and I would crash. I tried to figure out why

reviewText: This game is pretty decent. If you were a fan of test drive unlimited you'd love this game easily. Ample amount of customzation with a sizable campaign to boot. Handling was a good experience to me, but I can see where some people have their complaints about it being a little loose. There is rubberbanding with the AI drivers which is very annoying in long races where you can build a big lead. Cops are ruthless and will trap you easily if you're not careful. Overall there's a lot to do in the game and can sink hours and and hours into it easily. Very fun with friends. Fun to travel and tweak cars to constantly improve them to see that car level rise. Highly recommend this game!

reviewText:
First of all, Use Voice chat, vent, skype TS, whatever, just communicate with people.


Probably one of the best arcade racer I've ever experienced. that's something.

Let's get something straight. Arcade racers are racing games that have selective physics to allow fun things to happen.
If you are like me, someone who clocked 1000+ hours into Gran Turismo, played every racing game from F-Zero,CTR,Top gear,F1 simulators, to Racing lagoon. you don't expect anything to ever blow your mind again.
Heck, after NFS after NFS, I started to believe arcade racers have nothing to deliver.

This proved me wrong. Fantastically crafted balance of doing what's expected of a racing game, and taking itself seriously without being pretentious.

> Physics

The physics are well crafted to do what it's supposed to, The hitboxes are somewhat forgiving as they will let you scrape past a crash or dodge trees from time to time, (unlike Forza where entering a corner wrong is kinda...fatal) It doesn't make you OCD about keeping your car in control like GT, and is both a relaxing and exciting experience.

> Visuals

If you have a good PC, the visuals are quite decent, the topper is the cinematic value of an active racetrack. The game is light and easy enough for you to enjoy the cranes and planes, and steam leaks, strategically placed to block you from seeing stuff ahead is a nice touch.

> Story

The storyline? I didn't care for it at first, but it started to get better, unexpectedly good for something so cliche and dead on hollywood scriptwriting theories, The characters have a lot of depth for a racing game. It demonstrates there's nothing wrong with cliches, if it's done right. The end feels fulfilling and I'd totally get DLC for some of the character side stories

The game is meant to be played together, the story is written so you can talk ♥♥♥♥ about it. It's not groundbreaking but it does the job right, something I haven't seen in racing games in a long time.

(Willing suspension of disbelief regarding driving fixes problems" is required. though much less than a michael bay movie)

> Gameplay

It's broken the line of pathetic cops game after game

reviewText:
With some initial rocky troubles with updates and stability, this game had me swinging from exhilarated to furious and back to exhilarated again.  Right now everything is working fine and its the best damn driving game i've played.
I've been a major fan of the Need for Speed series, especially the free roaming, free agent types of Most Wanted and Hot Pursuit.  With those previous titles, they pioneered many features of free driving and competitive co-operative play i've enjoyed.  With The Crew, I get to experience all of that with added elements of full co-operative support, an unprecidentedly open free roam world, well balanced cosmetic and performance modifications.  I'm still getting into the game so i'm still looking forward to the real PvE and PvP experiences along with the action the faction system will bring.

For now it definitely gets a thumbs up, though as with any launch title it will have bugs and problems, so be patient (or wait a while before you buy).
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I just spent two and a half hours driving from Chicago to LA along Route 66, obeying speed limits and stopping every now and then to admire the beautiful scenery. Most of the locations in the game have this authentic kind of feeling to them. While the level of detail doesn't match that of GTA V, it's still high enough to make you keep on playing and exploring the vast open map.

Apart from that, well, it's a decent multiplayer racing game. The amount of cars to select from isn't exactly whopping, and there is no photo mode to capture the scenery I mentioned earlier. The AI traffic can suddenly take to the skies and Boeing 747's spin around wildly while airborne.

But overall, it's an enjoyable experience if you can ignore the servers shutting down every two hours. Hopefully the developers will manage to get rid of that soon.
Simply put, if you liked TDU, NFS:MW, Burnout Paradise, MC:LA and the likes, you will most likely enjoy The Crew as well. You might want to wait for a few weeks before getting it, though.

8/10

PS: I wouldn't mind an offline mode.

reviewText:
There are car games out there that look better, sound better and handle better, but none of them can stand up to The Crew's sheer pleasure and romance of the open road.

The Crew is the finest driving - not racing - game of 2014 and probably the very best this tiny subgenre has to offer. Outside of the baffling and bafflingly stupid plot, the game serves up an idealized approximation of the life of a car enthusiast who has nothing better to do but buy great cars, drive them to hell and back... and then drive them some more. With literally thousands of miles to wander across on a map reportedly close to five times the size of Just Cause 2's, The Crew is a paradise for free drivers and explorers, a game that makes the hours pass by at alarming speed in all senses of the word.

If you've dreamed of cross-country road trips, this is as close (and cheap) as it gets. If you loved Test Drive Unlimited and its oddball, mildly disappointing sequel, you should stop reading this and buy The Crew right now as it is essentially Test Drive Unlimited 3 in all but name.

reviewText:
The Crew, one of the best playing, and looking racing games i've played in a long time. All in all not the worst $60 I've ever spent, but if I were somebody else I would try to get this on sale for $40 or less.

TL,DR and cant live without a scorce?
7 1/2 / 10 will play for another 21 hours

reviewText:
T-Boned a car, whilst going 323km/h down a road, launching it vertically 20 meters in the air and 30 meters down the road.

Respawned from the crash, car is still in the air

10/10 would Crash again

Edited Proper Review as of 11/12/2014.

Warning 'The Crew' is not a Simulation racing game, it is an ARCADE Racer.

if you are looking for a decently fun racing game to play. 'The Crew' is a considerable choice for this.
There are few issues however with the game such as.
The Cops and pursuers are OP, especially so in the earlier levels of the game. Later on as you become a higher level, they do become less OP, but are still OP but not to the same level as they were when you first begun the game. The cops aren't that hard if you know how to use the Specs of cars properly. There is a large number of people complaining about this issue, most likely a majority of these people, have no clue how to drive each of the specs of cars correctly. (Don't be one of these people, learn the specs correctly).

Warning, this isn't a Racing Simulator don't be like the Racing Elitest like those that are prowling the Forums.

'The Crew' does have some other teething issues, such as occasional lag during co-op missions, Lack of connectivity to other players and difficulty connecting to friend when attempting to join each others crew's (I'm from a country that the national average internet speed is 10 mbps, and the lag isn't even that horrendous for me) .  These issues, are considered to be Teething issues, as the game hasn't even ben out for 2 full weeks yet, the people ♥♥♥♥♥ing about all of these issues aren't taking this into consideration, and these people aren't taking in to consideration that almost no games at launch are 100% Glitch Free / 100% Bug Free / Balance correctly / have no lag and connection between players is working correctly.

This being said 'The Crew' is actually quite an enjoyable game to play, as summarised, there are a balancing issues, connectivity issues, etc

If you are thinking of purchasing this game, honestly if you don't mind not playing with some friends or dealing with occasional OP AI pursurer/cops, then you should definitely purchase this game.

If any of these issues do effect you eg occassional Lag, connectivity issues with friends or you get really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the cops for some reason, as if you have a deep seeded issue with all forms of Law Enforcement. Then i would wait a bit for these issues to be fixed by ubisoft.

7/10 (would be 8.5 or 9, if the connectivity issues and balancing issues were corrected :D )

reviewText:
This game statisfy what a good online racer game is supposed to be. most players that did not liked this game plays realistic racers such as Forza or Grand Turismo. as for the other portion of players they will really be pleased whit this game since it have a NFS: Most Wanted and Test Drive Unlimited taste, witch is pretty good for a release from ubisoft, even tho, its true that some bugs remains, as other big games had before when they got out, but we know they will get those bugs fixed, so thats not a big suprise or a big deal about it and it can happen, at least those bugs are noting major, (unless you have a crappy internet connection)

For the Interested, here is the Pros/Mids/Cons of the game.

PROS+
+ Racing coop (up to 4 player max per mission or pvp game)
+ Very detailed environment (Working NPC's, a lot of Wilflife and alot of map details)
+ Better graphics than Test Drive Unlimited 2
+ Detailed leaderboards and statistics for everything
+ Good car handling and controls (with a few exceptions since its a NFS styled game)
+ Polices Forces that can chases you almost evrywhere. (give challenge somtimes)
+ Open world where you can drive wherever you want (Even discover some easter eggs in the world)
+ Good transition between game cinématics and gamplay (So you fell like you gived control of it after mission movies.)
+ Posibility to send your friend do faction missions for you. (so you can save time instead of doing a 2h mission for a bit more of easy game money)
+ 50 Cars for first release batch (Witch is not bad for a game that features quite detailed car interiors)
+ Offers car customisation such as pre-fab vynils/stickers, Rims, Spoilers and some chasis mods. ( Alot more visual customisation to offer compared to TDU2)
+ Day and Night Cycle System

MIDS~
~ Servers are down for maintenance sometimes. (yes it can happen, its an online game)
~ Uplay Launcher (at least i can be used / merged whit steam tho)
~ Storymode is a bit short. (but is still entertaining to watch)
~ Missing Mirrors Animations for Cockpit view in some Cars. (they already working on it already for next patch )
~ Weather conditions changes only when you go the mountains where there is snow (they might could use a bit rain but its not that bad)
~ Can have unblanced AI (depending if you and your crew have to high level gap)

CONS-
- No offline mode (you need a internet connection to play this game)
- No possibility to add your own Music (but you can customise your playlist atleast)
- Microtransactions

So as so far for the rest for the game and the gamplay itself, the pleasure of free roaming those cars with friends is pretty Neat, if your one of thos players who dislike this game, just go back to driveclub or what so ever other racing sim game you were playing, otherwise if your looking for car tunning, driving everywhere from road to montains, and like fast paced races for the fun of playing it, this game i what you are looking for !

All together i would say, The Crew" is a cool game to play for cruising around with Friends or even to play alone i would say
date:
sure the game have some bugs and have a litle lack on MMO since its more concentrated on the NFS genre gamplay but is worth the price when we know they will comme up whit more !

(10 thumbs up)

Continue the good work Ubi we know that you can do it and update this until perfaction as other titles did before !!
(Afterall They made Driver San Fransico a great fun game so why not the crew !)"

The game is good, but its not great. There are certain things that need fine tuning in this game and there has been literally no fixes, just more car packs etc every month.

The day i can look out of my wing mirrors in first person... The game play is really very glitchy since release and still now. Its fun to play with friends but its deffinatly not a serious racing game which is a shame because i really really wanted it to be.

The game improved when i started racing in Hardcore you do actually start to feel things differently, but things like when im racing online i get stuck in the floor and my car shoots 50ft in the air is just not ok for how long its been out.

Iv recommended this to many of my mates and we have had our fun but just repeating pvp races over and over does get boring pretty quick.

reviewText:
I would recommend this game for the driving, seamless map integration, various skill objectives and missions, and all around car tuning and handling.

I would not recommend this game for its useless PVP system, its repetitive grind, no end-game benefits, its censorship, the absurd story, or its custom car designs and micro-transaction model.

Overall, if you enjoy racing games and play them often, this game ranks up there with some of the greats. But, on the down side, there is no inclination of ultimate purpose other than to repeat what you have already done in the past. Not having a beneficial PVP or Faction vs. Faction system takes away one of the main key factors that would keep you playing this game, rewards. There is simply no motivating factors in the game that would make you stockpile vehicles or outdo yourself on the skills circuit, unless you have absolutely no life or are a completionist.

6/10

reviewText: Just finished the single-player campaign, or whatever you wanna call the story missions, cause you can do them in co-op as well. Anyway, the game is not finished, yet enjoyable for a very specific crowd. Let me explain. At a very technical level, the game is not where it should be. Laggy and stuttery even on an FX-9590 and 290x, tendency to cook a water cooled processor that doesn't go past 58 in Prime95, and almost unplayable on a mobile platform with an A10-5750M and M290x. If you can muster better specs and get it to be playable and responsive, you'll run into their side of the hardware issues, meaning the server. It might not pe hardware though, but still technical. On some networks it works, on others it doesn't, and it will disconnect every now and then in the middle of one of those hour long races, and you'll have to do it all over again. So, if these are things that you think you can look past just to get a glimpse of the sunset from the Grand Canyon behind the wheel of a LaFerrari, this is the game for you. It looks amazing, the cars sound fantastic, and on hardcore driving mode the driving model is brilliantly tuned for a very good mix of arcade and sort of simulator. Not a simulator in the actual sense, just that it follows a few rules that arcade racers usually don't. Say you're in a controlled power slide, or a drift, and one of your back wheels hits the dirt on the outside of the bend, or the snow, or even a wet patch, you will lose control of the car, because the back end loses grip completely. That is a very nice touch. So, driving model not bad at all, but not a full on simulator by any means. The story itself is a cliche, obviously, you've heard it a million times if you're into this culture, or have ever played a NFS game or seen an FnF movie. Bad guy kills/betrays your brother/mother/sister/any other signifcant family members and then you seek to get revenge by driving fast and breaking the law almost all the way. Nevertheless, this story is told well, with good quality cut-scenes and voice acting. Also, the missions themselves are quite fun, at least at first, because later on the same challanges are presented for the lack of more then 3 or 4 modes. You get the normal checkpoint race, checkpoint time trial, a sort of destruction derby against the clock, where you need to catch and bash into the opponent several times until a health bar hovering over his/her car is depleted. This one is quite interesting and fun, until they pit you against a prison bus that can keep up with a modified Mustang that can do 300 KM/h. Funny, but frustrating after the fifth try. Also has the health or relisience of a prison bus. There's another mode which I shall call touch the package" because it can be interpreted in several ways
