reviewText:
Online racing RPG, if you like realistic racing games, stay away from this one, it's an arcade racer.

Level up your cars and customize them, be sure to look up guides on car handling settings for one that fits your style.


+ Huge world, drive to Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca and then drive off to the mountains, you can go anywhere
+ Dirt, mud, grass, snow, sand, icy roads, roads, highways, cities, circuits...
+ Fun handling, burn tires, drift, jump unreal heights and reach speeds of over 400Km/h
+ Great graphics and highly detailed world from one end to the other
+ Over 40 cars with unique visual parts, bodykits, over 100 rims, and a lot of paint jobs
+ Great sounds, from car to environment
+ Many skill challenges to do all over the world
+ Unicorns

- Short story, boring and senseless
- No single player races except for the story ones
- Only supports about 10 players per online session
- End game is all about farming car mods and it takes forever
- Weird things happen sometimes when jumping and flipping over

reviewText:
People say a lot about the Crew. That is good and fun and others swear that it is next to terrible. For me the Crew has been a lot of fun, but I have no interest in being with a group of people tearing up the country-side. I personally like the idea of the crew and the changing of car styles and it forces you to play with all of the spec's (Street, Dirt, Performance, Raid, and Circuit) through the Campaign. Overall if you like driving around a massive open world in any car you like doing random skills, races and occasional pvp it is a lot of fun and worth the cash.

---->The campaign in general is alright, it is enough to keep you interested in how the characters work as a whole, but it nothing compared to Ubisoft's other story lines. It was written by the same writer of Red Dead Redemption, but was given a limited window in which to write it. The story feels rushed and a little bit like the fast and Furious, but it is a racing game and the Fast and Furious franchise really set the cliche and standard for many years to come. It is best to think of the Campaign as an interesting Tutorial rather than any form of story.

---->The game play is very fun in my opinion. In the open world you can drive anywhere you want with ease and have a multitude of things to do along the road trip. With five different types of cars you can go anywhere. The races are fairly easy in solo, but can pose a challenge in Co-op. The servers are lacking players though, because of the recent political and social mishaps that Ubisof has had, but I have had no problem getting into races in PVP. There is a large gripe about the handling model with this game. *IMPORTANT* It is a little difficult to understand, but this is an arcade racer with a logical handling model. The handling is actually quite realistic; its clunky, difficult, and sometimes very difficult to control, but this is how real cars work at high speeds. (I have two performance muscle cars and race them on the weekends, so trust me when I say they can turn at speed worth anything. One is a 1970 Camaro SS Z28 and the other is a 1970 Dodge Charger R/T) Use the brake and don't just slam on the gas the while time is the key to racing effectively.

---->The Customization is more than extensive (except on the Circuit cars but they are supposed to be race cars so I get that.) I have had a lot of fun personalizing my cars to be something that I like and find attractive. I can happily say that they have attempted to find looks and styles that suit everyone's interests. The visual parts can all be bought so you roll out of the tuner with a badass looking Mustang, Camaro, or whatever else. Althought, the performance parts are sometimes frustrating to acquire, but are rewarding after a challenge.

---->My frustrations;
-The occasional lack of players in the open world
-The tiny chance of level 50 parts
-The traffic spawn distance is very short sometimes giving you no chance to dodge them when you are ripping along the desert at 250+ mph.
-The expense of some of the parts. (Now this is a little bit more specific. Because it is so easy to make money it doesn't really matter anyway.)
-The fact that there isn't a circuit spec for the Agera R.

---->My Joys;
-The customization for the cars
-The little things, like overheating brakes and over-spin.
-The graphics for the cars and damage models.
-The auto-repair for the exterior of the car so you aren't forced to look at a car the is half destroyed.
-The Performance tweaks to the driving models that are a little difficult to notice.
-The Spec differences and play style choices.
-The ease at which you can make money.

All in all it is very good. Not perfect by any means, but enjoyable. Worth the money, you ask? There isn't an easy way to answer that. For me I have played a lot and plan to play more so it was for me, but for others who knows. It is really one of those; I love it" or "I hate it" games. The hype it got really hurt it. I like it better than GTA five

reviewText:
Updated: This is my final review. All of my review on thia game are base on gameplay and its features except story plot, as I always skip them like I do in other race game (except Split Second <3 ).

If you have experience in Need For Speed Underground 2/Most Wanted (old), then you might have a same experience in The Crew, with different styles of course. Graphic is ok actually, and the control or handling car aren't that bad. So far it is good, it's cool to see other players during roam mode.

Basicly the PvP (non crew pvp) is just same like other race game such Dirt 2, however, instead require host create a a lobby and organize the event, The Crew players that joined the lobby will vote which event they want to try. Haven't try yet the Crew vs Crew PvP (aka team vs team). Event after try I wont update anymore. xP
Do caution that server in co-op/PvP is really terrible, most of time you'll get disconnected issue, not sure is this is really base on player's internet connection or it's the game's server issue..

There's no rubberband Ai like those negative said, it's just normal Ai like other racing game. There's no perfect and logic Ai. It's yours skills to how you deal with them. Here's my screenshot. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=487074554

Here's about Ai info I've been meet:
Racer:
•Like other game they sometimes can bit speedy or slow, even they speed is same as your. But as I said before, it's about your skills. For me, most Ai racer are very easy to handle.

•Most of them stick into they waypoint, lika a train rail. There's a mission that I saw the same car hit on a truck twice (I retry the mission and yea, it occur on same place, same time). But meh, I play other race game before so its just normal.

•A Take Down mission really annoying. Dunno how to explain lol.

Cops, Police:
•All right.. So far I only see two way to trigger chase. 1st, hit anything inside 'Police Watch' area, until they trigger chase. 2nd way is, hit the police car if you see them. If you guys know other way (than mission), please let me know coz its fun trolling them xP

•All police just do is only ramming you. The star wanted level seems only increase number of police chasing you, road block and heli. Seriously roadblock is pretty ridiculous, only 1 police car block, with signal obstacles, in any wanted level. Please do not run from them by trying taking offroad, they'll chase you with dirt specs, also with heli, which is really difficult to escape if your car were using non raid/dirt spec. It was hell for me to run from them using Golf inaide forest but it was fun. xD


Note: For those people who is don't have a clue about trial issue, copy your CD key in Steam Library and paste it at Active Product on uPlay.

Please also do note that the trailer is too promising. I suggest you to try demo 1st. Well, it's still fun and cool racing game I ever played, 2nd of my fav after Split Second.

Here's my review so far:-

Pros:
Big detailed map

Able to see other players roaming around. It's cool!

Nice graphic

Somewhat it's challenging. Seriously, sometimes there's too many cars (obstacles) on traffic

No cut-scene crash/accident like Need For Speed series (if you think this is cons it is pro for me. I hate when speeding in race or in free roaming, or while eescaping from police you got crash and then a cut-screen, slowing down you).

Support are nice, I guess.

Most time update

Great community

Crew vs Crew PvP system

Great car customization. You can tune your car to into various specs which is street, dirt (rally actually..), raid, circuit. You can't tune Stock specs but you can customize its visual on your HQ.

8 players on each roam map is great, I guess.. Assuming enable more players will make the map lag, like most online game I played. Even though the map is very super large scaled getting lag will make player frustrated and stop play. This is my experienced in most online game. At least for me.

Cons:
Crew Credits systems in-game, in PAID games. Some car cannot bought through bucks. This should not happen. (Note: ingame progress you'll receive free 100k crew credit once. But as I said, Crew Credit supposedly not exist since this paid game, also can make game unbalanced.

Season Pass benefit kinda unfair for me. Plus it is expensive, not worth for its features. DLC also expensive.

Kinda unrealistic physics.

Must have internet connection to play.

Ingame player's profile avatar are using uPlay avatar, and can't upload/customize ingame profile avatar like the trailer.. This is so frustrating, stupid, and horrible..

Thats all from me. :)

My rate: 8/10

Is this game worth playing?

Yes. If you like a average story which is something you just have an addition cause you do the same thing on every mission anyways.

Yes. If you like a game which only way of saying ♥♥♥♥ you, you are not going that way is by ruining the physics (hilarious and pathetic at the same time)

Conclusion: This is a really, really fun game. I had some issues at first, weren't minor. Ubisoft support wasn't helpful at all but that doesn't change the fact that this game is fun with friends or atleast the right people.

reviewText:
I highly recommend people to get The Crew if they like arcade like racing, fast cars, customization, and openworld driving. This game gets a lot of hate and people begin to compare it to games like Forza Horizon, NFS, Burnout, and Test Drive Unlimited 2 and also begin to compare to the 2 top racing simulators like Forza and Gran Turismo. I think people forget that this is not a full on simulator, this is a arcade type game where jumping things at 150 mph wont destroy your car. The Crew features about 40 cars with maybe 10 more coming on the way with DLC and there are 5 car spec's that you can chose from. Street, Dirt, Perf, Raid and Curcuit. You unlock each of those 5 specs as you play the game and level up and not all cars are able to have all 5 specs for example, A lambo only has Perf and Curcuit, a Dodge Charger only allowes Street, Dirt and Perf and so on for most of the cars.

For customizing you are only allowed to customize Street, Dirt, and Perf spec cars and each car for each spec has its own uniqe customization options but the Raid and Curcuit spec cars are already preset to a certain look and it cannot be change expect for the color, stickers (as they call it), rims, and the interior.

The game covers the whole USA but made into a small version to fit the game. You can get from New York to San Francisco in about 40 minutes - 1 hour. Some citys have been included but not made fully to scale as that would probably be impossible to do and would take too much time to do everything to scale so what is included in the cities is enough to make it recognizable.

The story is a simple story that is not so original but then again what can be done with a racing game? You are framed for murdering your brother when someone from the inside killed him with the help of a dirty fbi cop. So you are sent to jail and are offered to go undercover to seek revenge for the murder of your brother.

There are microtransactions in the game but it is useless because you still need to unlock every part to own it and cars are not that hard to buy with ingame money. I remember seeing that the Devs said they took actual car sounds from the actual car but that is not true. Every car sounds generic but at least each car has a different pitch and sound to it.

Pros:
+Car customization
+The whole US to explore
+Can play the whole game with 3 friends
+5 secret cars to unlock
+Everything can be purchased with ingame money
+Every car has a different sound, even though non of them are the actual car sounds its enough for each car to have its own sound
+each car has its own detailed interior

Cons:
-Only 40 cars to chose from
-Lack of asian cars to chose from (only 2)
-Police are a bit too aggressive
-Skill Challenges get really repetative
-Cheaters, no chance to gain a world record on any challenge
-No working rear view mirrors
-Microtransactions

reviewText:
When I first tried to read up on the scale of The Crew I had found forum posts talking about the time it takes to cross the map. Hearing times ranging from an hour to over two hours I was disappointed when I made it from Northeastern Maine to Malibu, California in just under 40 minutes.

But it isn't just about the quantity of width, it was about the quality that expands to the north and south as well. Whether you even choose to do the campaign missions, there can be dozens of hours of pleasure found in traversing the country in Street spec cars. They did a great job capturing monumental structures such as the Golden Gate Bridge and Mount Rushmore or landmarks like the Bonneville Salt Flats and the Grand Canyon.

The map itself doesn't feel copy and pasted either. Each section does seem to have its own unique features. Whether it be the snowy roads of the Rocky Mountains or the winding and elevating roads in the Giant Sequoia Forest, or Las Vegas towering over the horizon, it is worth going and seeing what The Crew has to offer.

reviewText: the crew. its kinda like Test Drive Ulimited. but much better,\nits a great looking game trully looks great. and most of the time it feels great. it really depends on if you like to use a wheel with force feedback or not. i think people who got the game and never played it with force feedback wheel will never have any complaints. but the force feedback issues are still around.\ni have to say i really like most of the force feedback feeling in the game its very good. but sometimes it can get too stong and i think mostly thats been sorted out. or so they say it has. i still notice things i really dont like about the force feedback. like the wheel going light on you and all of a sudden strong force again. i wish they had put more time into the force feedback because they did half a good job. its just a massive shame they did not do a fully good job. it would have really improved the game for me. even with the xml file you can find online for extraconfig xml.. it still doesnt feel perfect. and is messy. i just find it such a shame. because the game itself is very good. especially for a ubisoft game. its great game. but they messed up the force feedback and they dont seem to care much about getting it right. or listening to the gamers issues.  but its playable and fun,

reviewText:
Wild Run addon is disappointing to me. For cost of half of basic game you get in fact nothing. Oh yea, you can still pay further and buy motorbikes but even this is not possible straight on Steam - you are redirected to other page which does not belong to Steam. I am not a die hard fan of this game so I am not into spending tens of hours to slowly earn game's coins to be able to ride a bike. At least one bike should be accessible straight by buying the DLC, otherwise, for me it is waste of money.
And one more thing: why the game does not turn off when I quit? Steam hour counter for the game still works and I can't get rid of it until next PC restart, so in fact hours count spent with this game is false.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Hey, this is the best open world driving sim so far. It's like TDU but better, prettier, more exciting. I would also really like to see usable Petrol Stations, Motorbikes as well as radio playing my own mp3 songs, GPS that looks like the real one, playable slot machines. I hope future DLCs will bring us some of these.

reviewText:
I genuinely like the crew as long as you make sure you purchase Wild Run this dramatically improves vehicle handling and adds motorbikes and monstertrucks to the mix as well as dynamic weather and visual improvements. The map scale is truely impressive and the car models are of very high quality making ownership of these cars a real joy to cruise around in.

The sigleplayer Story expeience is always down to the wire with nailbiting races and the AI can screw up although not as much as a human will.

The Multiplayer option is good and encourages competition as well as working together to finish that hard as balls mission.

The in vehicle views and bonet views are very well done and add to the immersion.
If I had anything negative to say it would be about inapp-purchases. NO Ubisoft NO. I want to be able to earn my vehicle and drive against players that have earned their new rides instead of people who can just buy the best vehicle and get all the advantages from that.

PROS :

Graphically stunning as long as you have Wild Run.
Incredible scale and detail to the map it truly is MASSIVE!
Vehicle Models are of the highest quality.
A genuinely fun and exciting story fo the campaign (although generic)
AI vehicles can screw up making it more realistic.

CONS:

INAPP-PURCHASES gives some players unfair advantage over a player who earns their vehicle in game . I don't expect to pay any more when Iv'e supposedly bought the whole game. Get rid of inapp-purchases for sanity's sake it cheapens the whole product.

AI drivers can be TOO smart never missing corners and seemingly completing courses with ease they also recover way too quickly as opposed to the player who is heavily penalized for screwing up.

voteText:
- Crew Love (Feat. The Weekend)

Great arcade racing game! Not some serious Narcar game based on realisim. Not alot of cars, but that doesnt take away from the fact that you are probably going to spend alot of money on 1 car. It's going to take you a good while to aquire AT LEAST a 3rd car, assuming you dont spend CC on a better car.

The map is really big. Long freeways/highways for showing off how fast your cars can actually go, and nice city streets for smaller races/drifting.

The only problems i have with this game are that

1. Large sums of money are hard to come buy, especially  if you keep spending money on paint jobs and stickers.

2. Connecting with your friends is a pain! For me at least. Either there are no other players being shown for me, or when i try to join my friends crew, it says he is already in one, which is claims is flase.


Past those things though, its good fun to just freeroam in your $1000000 car though the USA!

reviewText:
PERSONAL OPINION

Well, I'm going to tell you that this game needs a friend. Unfortunately, it doesn't come with one guaranteed.
When I played this game/ both alone and with a friend, it is the absolute best racing/driving game I have ever played.

No, I don't understand why there's so much hate. What do all those haters play, Need for Speed Rivals?
All jokes aside; this game is definitely better than its competitors at its gen.

I enjoyed this game thoroughly, and would rate it 98/100 (1 point minus for minor connectivity issues, 1 point minus for bad ending)

Let me start with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ map. Yes, the freaking huge map. And its not just 90% emptiness, no no no no....
Its probably one of the largest maps in gaming history. I'm pretty sure it could go par against Guild Wars 2 in map size.

Next up is the main story sequence. Overall, the story was NeedForSpeedMostWanted(2005)-ish and really pushes you to want to know more. Its not shakespeare but hey, I found it to fit okay.

The cars in the game are well modeled (except their bottom; but who the hell looks there), and there is a pretty good level of car-modding. Okay, not Need For Speed Carbon/UG2 level, but at least around NFSMostWanted(2005) level. The paints choices are great, and the vinyl choices are not bad. They should make more though.

I don't think there is alot of cars in the game, and before people start chirping the game because you can purchase cars; you can finish the game and get the best car without paying a single extra dollar. Just don't pay heed to purchasable cars and you're good. I personally liked their car choices; despite the low car count.

The AI in the game (which some saw glitching) was actually flawless for me. They are pretty smart, and I'm pretty sure they are much better AI than that of older racing games. This is because the AI will not let you grind onto them or use them as padding" as you make a sharp turn with them. They will speed up or slow down to make you screw up. It makes the game have a level of challenging in it.

Okay

reviewText:
Game is really fun. If you like arcade racing games it is a must have.

Pros:
-The way the car drives is pretty customizable and even though you can't make huge changes like making it a sim, you can definitely make it drive to your taste (as long as you enjoy arcade driving).
-Game creates the perfect challange. You can win most races with relative ease, but getting that gold medal definitely requires some skill.
-People have been bashing the graphics, but for an online-focused open world racing game the graphics are really impressive.
-Online experience seems pretty stable. One problem I always have with online racing games is how crazy things go when playing online, cars popping out of nowhere, suddenly stoping or accelarating, etc. So far I have experienced no major problems while playing coop events.
-Variety of car classes and events for those classes. There are car classes build for different terrains and conditions and events for those different classes.
-Don't like playing with other people? You can go completely solo. Even though the game is online-focused you can ignore everyone around you and play it like if it was a singleplayer game.
-Even though it's an arcade game you can feel the differences in handling of each vehicle with ease, making car choices come to preference.
-That huge map! Travelling from one city to another is already a lot of fun and there are kind of mini-games in every road that include jumping, slaloms, driving fast and on the road, etc. All to keep you busy on your travels while also rewarding you.
-The performance is flawless. Some people may be worried about performance since it's a Ubisoft game, but I have a pretty old computer and can still run the game flawlessly with mixed high/ultra settings.

Neutral:
-There are not many visual customization options as I though there would be, but customizing your car is still pretty fun, even though I feel it could be better.
-Soundtrack doesn't fit the game well. The songs don't give you that adrenaline that make you want to drive fast and recklessly. But I believe no one cares for game soundtracks anymore, since most people just mute the game music and use an external music player.
-The story feels kinda dull. The story is amazing the first minutes of gameplay, but once you hit the road it doesn't feel like a big deal anymore, but all online-focused games are like this. I haven't completed the game yet, so take this one with a grain of salt.
-Cops are lazy. You have to do some real ♥♥♥♥ for them to go after you, just driving a clearly illegaly modified car 100Km/h above speed limit won't do it. Some people will love it, some others will hate it. Sometimes they also appear during races and don't do anything. In events where they're the main deal it's a different story, of course.

Cons:
-The car sounds are pretty bad, they just don't sound reallistic. Sometimes I feel like hearing an engine that came from a 2005 game.
-You win performance parts in every event, which completely makes the performance shop useless allowing you to make a lot of money very easily since you have to spend very little of it to progress through the game. Remember that I haven't completed the game yet, it may change at some point.
-You can't play the game offline, as far as I know. People who don't have access to a decent connection all the time must be very careful when buying this game.

Some people have been saying this game is horrible, it is not. I haven't experienced bugs, lags, freezes, ctds or anything like that. The game is just great, even though it's not amazing. It's a great game that will give you a lot of fun specially if you play with your friends, but there's nothing really groundbraking about it.
Also, don't pay attention to those people saying that the game's handling and physics are horrible. It's an arcade game and it was designed to be so, so don't expect reallistic collisions, steering, car damage or anything like that. It has very good mechanics for an arcade game. It's not just an accelerate and steer game" and you can still make mistakes in it
date:
considering that you're playing on hardcore mode.

I give this game a solid 7.8/10

If you have any doubts if you should or should not buy the game
recommended: feel free to ask me any questions ; )"

reviewText: PRO TIP: If you are having trouble enjoying the game because of the handling model, you can fix that by changing the Control settings in the options. Changing it from All assists" to "Sport" will make it feel like you have much more control over the car. Setting the steering speed factor all the way to the right will make it feel a lot less sluggish when turning. Setting sensitivity a bit to the right can also help.\n\nDuring the beta
date: I found the handling to feel much better after doing this and enjoyed the game quite a lot. Currently playing the full game

reviewText:
Well I will keep it short and sweet. This game is hands down a lot of fun. When I say fun I mean sit on my ♥♥♥ until it starts to sting and hurt because the cushions on my chair are so worn. NOW THATS FUN...

Anyways, This game is a HUGE open world. Anyone complaining its not to scale or a exact copy of google maps or something can go shove it. The graphics are great and with the MMO structure there is endless room for improvement with later content patches.. even to the very items and cars of the game to gamemodes. and for a Ubisoft title on PC the launch did very well haha.

I have no problem finding 2 or 3 players to do a few missions with. I have already made a few friends in game. The gameplay is simple yet extremely satisfying. You complete missions and get essentially loot" from doing it and level up. There are also random missions along the roads and paths that give you parts and upgrades.

Also there is tiers of levels and factions for end game. I mean this game is huuge and for 60 bucks its totally worth it to me. I mean its the most fun ive had on a game in a while.. I mean it had me out of my chair screaming over voice chat with 2 other guys after 4 trys on the same hard mission for the gold and then we did it and it rocked.... sorry for rambling

BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW! it rocks.



PS... add me up if you join up always looking to expand my roster of friends to play this game with :]"

reviewText: This is a very fun game.  While the storyline missions are forgettable, there are tons of side activities to accomplish and are very fun to play with friends.  The map of the U.S. is awesome.  You can go ANYWHERE on the map.  You can drive up the side of a mountain and overlook big cities such as LA and NYC.  The atmosphere of the game leaves you with a nice comfy feel.  Nothing beats driving across the U.S. in your favorite cars with your buddies.  All the cars are fun to drive and feature many details.  There are some bugs with AI traffic and some technical difficulties with Ubi's garbage network 'features'.  Overall would recommend.  8/10

reviewText: The game is fun, don't get me wrong, but it has its drawbacks. The costumization is great, the cars are sweet, and the variety is great. I've never played a racing game that has a Ferrari 458, and a 2010 Chevy SIlverado. The map is awsome. Instead of being stuck in one city, you can cross the entire U.S. The cities aren't perfect, or even close for that matter, but if you play the game in the right mind set, where nothing is perfect, you'll have fun. I enjoy the game, it's not the best game, but its good. It's an arcade driving game, not a simulation racing like Forza or Assetto Corsa.

reviewText:
Awesome game.  Thats all I have to say.

I was debating buying it recently, however when it went on sale for 50% off, I decided to purchase gold edition because of the bonus items/features it came with.  As soon as I opened the game, I knew I would enjoy it because of its beautiful graphics and sweet soundtrack.  The story line also makes it even more enjoyable, and the fact that you can play it online with others if you want.  The map is massive, which also adds to the enjoyment of even just driving around with no reason.

Yes, there are a few flaws to the game, however they have not negatively affected my personal experience playing it.

I can guarantee the dedication of many, many more hours to the game.

9/10

reviewText:
It's a great game with lots and lots of space to play with (literally), with a really clichee based story and a really bad syncronisation in my language (german).
The game itsself isnt a mmo, but the way you get addicted is the mmo way.
The graphics arent the best compared to other next gen games, but much better than last-gen.
When you drive for the first time, it feels very unresponsive, but if you found the best settings for the controller (+hardcore mode), you can really shoot away from many other more powerful cars (only on a circuit).
Im impressed by the size and the detail of the map, I never got bored by the landscapes, unlike NFS Rivals.

reviewText:
There are some reasons to dislike 'The Crew' but one that makes the game a recommendation – it's fun.

Pros:

- Enormous map of the U.S.A.
- Very interesting, long campaign, almost like a movie. IMO best story ever in a racing game. 65 Missions
- Some extremely long races. 2.5 hours from Miami to Los Angeles via New York!!!
(Perfect to turn your head off after a long day at the office)
- Nice graphics (if you find the right settings)
- Many ways to improve your cars.
- Cars can be tuned into street, off-road, performance, race or rally cars.
(some cars can only be tuned into some of the types)
- Visual tuning
- Performance tuning
- Co-op missions
- Cockpit view
- Different radio stations
- Country side looks fantastic (cities not always)
- Total open world, also in all races
- All cars feel different
- Police (but too easy to escape)
- Tons of mini games
- All kind of animals, the crocodiles in the New Orleans swamps look fantastic
- day/night cycle
- addictive

Cons:

- Frame-rate sometimes drops, especially in cities. Changing graphic settings does not prevent this.
- Car handling isn't the best in the beginning of the game but gets better after improving individual car settings
- Very hard to make money, but you need money to buy cars. After 40 hours of playing I only have like 10 cars. There are about 50 cars in the game but you have to consider the different race-types (race, rally, etc.) So you can have like 200 different cars if you have the money. (not all cars support all types)
- You can buy game money with real money :-(((
- Some cars can only be bought with real money :-(((
...but you do not need them to win in MP
- Permanent on-line connection required
- Game takes long to start
- Upgrading cars is time consuming and can be frustrating. Every car can be upgraded to max level 1299. You need to play tests (hill climb, slalom, speed test, escape, etc.) to collect upgrade kits. But the game randomly decides which upgrade level you will receive. So even if you successfully complete the test you might not get the upgrade part you need. If you attempt to upgrade a car that already has a high level you can repeat tests like 50 times without being granted with the missing part, although you succeeded the test 50 times. Alternatively you can buy missing car parts but only if you have already earned the desired upgrade level and the fact that the game keeps you low on money makes upgrading by buying parts a painful decision.
- MP race selection can be frustrating. Before each mp event every player can select their favorite event. Players can select the track, the car type and mp event type (racing, king of the crown, etc.). They can decide to activate or deactivate contact with other players and activate or deactivate traffic. A random selection carried out by the game will decide who's player selection will be played next.
- High influence of luck in MP if you play with crash kids. You can lead 90% of a race but if someone pushes you into a field at 300 kph you're almost certain to become last. IMO it's best to select races with deactivated player contact but it's a matter of luck if you will play such race or not because the game decides which event is going to be played.
- AI is too easy most of the time
- Not a MMO. Eight simultaneous players in free drive mode
- No rain, no snow, no weather conditions
- Uplay
- If Ubisoft servers are unavailable you can not play.
- Sometimes mp players seem to cheat, but very rarely.

'The Crew' is not a serious racing game like 'Dirt', 'Grid' or 'Project Cars'. It's an arcade fun racer in a cozy, feel good world that simply looks fantastic. The star of the game is the enormous and beautiful U.S.A. and the story.

reviewText:
Well this is the 2nd time i bought The Crew becuase EA delayed their NFS 2015 for PC, and i need to fullfill my Racing Game addiction so i bought this game again. Because this is the only decent Arcade Racer game yet on pc, and im sure when NFS out on PC it will knock the ♥♥♥♥ out of this game :D

Short Review: Good Story and Large map to play with + BIKES!! , Lack of Cars + Bad car Costumization. So get this game only when it goes on Sale, i dont recommend you to buy it at full price,

Now for Pros and Cons:

+ Preety good story that can keep you playing for 1 week just for the stories. I say this because i have completed the story for 2nd time and it still enjoyable :D

+ Large map you can travel across USA and it takes roughly 30-50 minutes to travel from Chicago to Miami. Imagine going from side to side :D Really fun for cruising around good scenery.

+ Have diffrent kind of weather, like Rain, Snow, Thunderstorm, Sunny. If they add Tornadoes it would be so cool!

+ Monster Trucks, Dragster and Drift spec, Lovin It!

+ BIKES makes your game more easier to beat hahahaha

+ Decent graphic after the Wild Run update.

Now for the cons:

- Bad costumization option.

- Lack of Japanese car and some old European cars. Too much supercars here.

- PVP not so good right now, but still enjoyable though.

- Online feature in this game still kinda meh. Like Crew feature is kinda useless here which is they promised to #NeverDriveAlone but for me its #AlwaysDriveAlone.

So you may ask Do you Recommend it?" then My answer is
date: If you REALLY REALLY want to play an Arcade Racer then get this game. Becaus its currently the decent Arcade racer game you can get for PC right now
recommended: When NFS released i wont recommend you to get this game tho."

A nice game fixed (terrible launch)

reviewText: The Crew is a really fun game. Its takes everything I love about driving games. Now I will say that it was stupid that they didnt say anything about 'you need to buy the Wild Run'. Which was really bad on there part, I have seen people writing bad reviews in this game because it didnt say you needed to the wild run. Becuase I think they didnt get far into the game. Which i have completed and put many hours, and more to come. So I wanted to write a proper review about this game and what I think about it. I think the game is great besides the thing about it not telling you need the Wild Run. But anyway the game is great because how much content and how big the world is. After the Wild Run update they made the game look great and feels great. The cars are great to ride to grind for, you get the feeling after playing hours and hours of grinding and then get the car you really want is rewarding. Which is a great feeling to me, the story is decent, its not the best story but not a bad one at that. There is also online which is okay, and theres PVP gamemode which you vs other players, which was fun but not a lot of people were playing. Leading to my topic, players, there arent many people playing this game, the hightest I have seen is about 1000. But overall the game is really fun and great, the only problem really was were they didnt say anything about you needed to buy the Wild Run, Which is quite bad. If I had to rate the game, I would give it a 8/10 because I really enjoy this game, and like I said the only real problem is that they dont warn you about needing to but the Wild Run. But the game is really good and I hope more people will play this game which would be awsome.

reviewText:
The Crew is a game with so much potential that it actually upsets me playing it at points. There are a few main points of contention I have with the game.

#1. The car list.
Maybe there were licensing issues or something along those lines but the car list in this game is a massive disappointment. If you're making a game set in the entirity of the US give us some good American cars. I'd love to see classics like your C2 or C3 Corvettes, Pontiac Trans Am, Impalas, '60s Mustangs and even weird obscure stuff like a Buick Grand National. Another thing is that for a game released in late 2014 all the 'new' cars seem to be a few years old. For example you have a 2010 Camaro, a 2010 Challenger, a 2010 370Z, a 2010 Continental Supersports, a 2009 Corvette ZR1, a 2010 BMW Z4, A 2011 M5, a 2010 Focus RS, a 2011 Mustang, a 2012 V8 Vantage,a 2010 Viper, a 2011 Grand Cherokee, a 2011 F150 Raptor and a 2011 McLaren 12C. Maybe it was due to a lengthy dev time but it just seems strange to have a new racing game with a car list this slightly dated. Another thing that annoys me about the car list is that there is an R34 GT-R V-Spec that is Left Hand Drive, they only ever made them RHD that's why Americans who are into JDM" (That's another rant for another time) go crazy for them.

#2. The customisation.
The vehicle customisation in this game is odd in that it's very in depth but also very limited. An example would be that I can put a stripe on my car but I can't change the colour of that stripe. All I want is a purple Camaro with a green stripe to give other players their daily dose but because of the arbitrary restrictions in the customisation menus I can't. All they had to do was emulate Forza or one of the PS2 era NFS games but Ivory Tower screwed that up.

#3. The vehicle classes.
When this game was hyped in pre release and during the beta it was shown that every car could be used in every class (Street
hoursPlayed:
Raid and Circuit) but when the game was released there were restrictions and limitations as to what car can be used with what class. For example a Golf GTI can only be used in Street spec which sucks because Street spec is garbage. A Dirt or Perf spec GTI would be fantastic but it can't happen because the game says so.

#4. The Physics.
Not necessarily the driving physics
voteText: they're fine but they do start out pretty terrible (they improve as your car improves) but the crash physics and impact physics are screwed up beyond belief with my cars commonly performing physically impossible maneuvers. Another thing that isn't entirely physics related is that during the start of every race an animation plays where you cars rear wheels spin even if you have a front or all wheel drive car
helpfulPercent:
as someone who likes detail in their driving games this upsets me greatly.

#5. Crew Credits.
They're a currency you buy with real money. Need I say more?

#6. The "MMO" aspect.
This game is not an MMO. Ubisoft are lying to you
votesHelpful: it might be multiplayer but it is 8 people per server and with a map this large you are spread out most of the time and barely have any interaction. The 'Never Drive Alone' tag was a lie as I spent most of my hours in this game driving alone.\n\nWhat this game needs is a sequel made by more competent devs and with more attention to the little details. It also shouldn't be marketed as an MMO because it isn't."

reviewText:
Let start off on a very clear thing, I like the crew. I have loved it ever since I heard of it, when it came avalible for pre order, I bought it, then went out and bought parts to make sure my computer could handle it. I still like it, getting into a car and just driving across the huge landscape is just extreamly relaxing and thrilling at times.

With that being said, I highly recommend you -DO NOT- buy this game. Ubisoft has been for some time trying to be worse than EA in jackassery, and they have somehow suceeded very well. As pointed out by the other reviews, season pass effects nothing with Wild Run, a forced update and major expanshion that the game now prettymuch relies on and costs as much as the normal game, dispite only giving you limited content. [Four new class types and new event zones mainly]

If you are able to pick this game up dirt cheap, sure, go for it, the aimless driving is fun, but that is all that this game offers now, aimless driving. I hate Need for Speed, but you'd be highly better off buying one of them, and that hurts for me to admit that. I really believed in this game, and if it wasn't for ubisoft, I believe this TDU3 could of really shown.

reviewText:
As an owner of The Crew, with the Season Pass, it would cost me more to buy Wild Run by itself than it would cost a non-owner to buy The Crew-WIld Run Edition, as they would be paying just $9 for Wild Run whereas I, someone who bought the game at Full Price when it came out, have to spend a GREATER amount of money, $15, to get Wild Run. This is punishing current owners, even if you don't account for the drop in price or the discount, because it means that as someone who actively owns the game it effectively is more expensive for me to get to the same point than it is for someone who doesn't get own it.

If you compare gained content, rather than raw price, I am gaining the same amount (Wild Run) for $15 that someone who buys the Wild Run edition gets for $9.

I wanted to get Far Cry Primal to play with my life-time coop buddy, because I love Far Cry. I own FC3 and FC4.

I am never buying an Ubisoft game again. Ever. Because I know this company direction is going to continue forever. Ubisoft used to be fantastic back when they first started making Assassin's Creed. Ubisoft has become more loathesome than EA.

reviewText:
I would say I absolutely do recommend this game if you like games like Test Drive Unlimited, and Need For Speed, that being said, there are some MAJOR downsides to this game but overall I find it a rather good game.

Let's start with the cons to get that out of the way.

-Hard to Start Out
As in it's rather hard to get money for actual good vehicles. I feel as you progress more, it'll be easier but when you have to go and get performance vehicles.... be prepared to spend lots of your time grinding for money if you want an actual decent car.

-Ranked
I feel as though they let you go into ranked WAY too early as I went into it (Not at all knowing what I was doing...) and was matched with the top of the top players (Platinum, Gold, Etc.). While they had level 1499 Vehicles, i sat there with a puny level 300..... As that may be my own fault for rushing it, I just recommend if you play to wait a LONG time before playing ranked.

-Street Challenges
As this may just be my own personal opinion, I find as you're driving down the road, the excessive amount of Street Challenges are way too much. They typically cover the entire road, and frankly try to force you to do them. You literally have to swerve off the side of the road to avoid them... Personally, I just find them annoying as they hardly reward you anything and are quite dull, typically trying to force me off the path I was originally going.

-Wild Run
As this isn't nessicarily a con to me, I find lots of people complaining since the season pass didnt include Wild Run. As I didn't pre-order or buy the Season Pass expecting it (Due to me buying the game far after the big fuss about it happened) I don't find this really a con since it's only $10 more. Though do be warned, season pass doesn't include ALL dlc like most games have it. It lacks a big item that the game basically requires and tries to force onto you, Wild Run.

-Basic Story Plot
I won't spoil anything for you but, if you have ever played Need For Speed: Undercover.... This is basically that game. It has pratically the exact same plot and will give you extreme de ja vu.

-Bad Graphics...
As this isn't such a big deal to me, the graphics for some things do make me laugh. The graphics for scratches are incredibly cheaply made... That's really all I have for that one... It's just rather funny how horrible they are.


Now Onto the Pros

-Long Story
At the time of writing this, I am 10.3 Hours into the game, and still not even halfway into the game. It seems to be VERY long which I absolutely love, something most games nowadays seem to lack.

-Some Nice Cars
There are some very nice, detailed cars in the game. Though expensive.

-Entertaining
I've always been a big fan of Racing Games and I can say, this game I absolutely fell in love with. It's one game that I can actually sit down and play for a long while without getting bored, which is very few for me.

-Controls
Okay, This is moreso to personal preference but - The Controls for this game is rather different compared to most games. If you're using a controller, it may seem a bit weird just to how the handling is, but I can say after a while you will get use to it. I personally fell in love with it.


I would probably rate this game 7/10... It could definitely be better, but It's still rather good. A nice relaxing game to come home to if you have nothing else to do

reviewText:
This game was quite a letdown, to be honest.

The physics are awful, every car handles like it is front-wheel-drive, any collision will send you into either a cutscene, or will shove you into oblivion,
Traffic will spawn randomly causing more collisions and annoying cutscenes,
The story is flimsy at best,
Objectives are repetitive,
Map is large, but sparsely populated with cities, and the cities that do exist in game are much smaller than they should be.
Police chases lack any real substance (all they do is follow)
Lack of cars
Lack of customization
The customization that the game does include feels like it came straight out of F&F

The Crew almost feels like it should have been released about 10 years ago with NFS: Most Wanted, because that is exactly what this game reminds me of.

reviewText:
The CrewThis is a game I played briefly in Beta and really like the concept of a racing game that lets you travel across the US.  The open world environment allows you to compete in races across the US or just take off and drive anywhere you want from coast to coast without any loading screens. The freedom and choice is yours to make.  Follow the story, venture out and explore, and/or compete in challenges and races. The game feels a lot like Watchdogs if you never left the vehicle only on a larger scale with less people walking around. The vehicles handle similar to the vehicles in Watchdogs intially, but moding them greatly increases performance as you level the car.  Street, dirt, and track veriations of car modifications can be made for all different types of races as well as a large veriety of cosmetic options to customize your ride.  You will not get the sim race track feeling here as the cars are not heavily based on true physics like you would find in the Grid series.  This is definately an arcade style racing game more in line with Need for Speed that provides hours of fun!

Not Just a RacerThe Crew is more than just a traditional racing game.  It is a MMO racing game.  The game is designed to play with other people by joining crews so that you can work together in missions.  Playing with others in your crew provides extra incentives such as experience and cash.  You can put skill points into your bonuses to increase rewards received from playing with your crew members as well as benefits to enhance your car such as reduced repair costs, better breaking, etc. However, the game can be played solo with just as much fun.

Weak LinkageAnd here is the weak link in the design of The Crew.  People expecting a MMO will immediately notice that there is no need to join a community to play the game.  The option is there with some rewards but there is no real push to do so. There is also no voice chat built into the game to communicate with your crew members and the pop-up screen is usually hidden to get it out of the way. So even when you do choose to type to crew members, you will seldom get a response.

You will find PvE and PvP races/challenges but the need for a community feels absent.  The PvP is fun and I honestly have a blast with some of the game modes.  You will not find any large raid like content here.  It would have been nice to see large cross country races pitting  multiple four man crews against crews or larger 16 plus members competing together in a large scale race against other crews or AI; but what we received was on a much smaller basis for those that want to play solo.  What you will find is a huge open world where you can see people and choose to interact with them or not.  The choice is yours to make.

ProsHuge map to Explore
Open World
Variety of Race types
Variety of Vehicles/types
Vehicle Customization
Graphics
MMO Community

ConsPhysics are more Arcade than Sim
Weak MMO Community
No voice built in voice chat


Final ThoughtsAfter finishing the game, I still enjoy going back and creating new cars and leveling them up.  I am personally having a blast with this game and recommend it to anyone thats like racing games.   I did not do a first impressions video of this game so I have linked a few videos to give you an idea of what to expect.

New Expansion UpdateThe Crew: WIldrun is a DLC expansion coming to the crew with a free overhaul to the graphics and physics engine for all as well as the DLC packed full of quests, races, new race types, vehicles, and vehicle types (monster trucks & motorcycles). It looks amazing!  I cannot wait until November to play it. If only I had a Beta key...

For the story:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351697011

For vehicle modification:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351697009

For gameplay:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=394438020

reviewText:
Score: 80	 Author: geekl33tgamer	 Test Drive Unlimited Reddux?
http://www.geekl33tgamer.co.uk/reviews/198-the-crew-review

From the outset, the core concept of the game seems very appealing to anyone who has ever picked up a copy of any recent Need for Speed title, or the poorly executed (but great idea) Test Drive Unlimited game. Here we have a huge sprawling online world, filled with literally thousands of players, all going about their own thing with a Need for Speed and Burnout inspired driving model.

The games career play is a very cinematic affair, and within the first few minutes of starting the game you’ll soon start to understand how this game’s style will play itself out. You start off with some cut-scenes of a chase which you get thrown into, this is basically your tutorial. You need to race to the checkpoint marker whilst keeping the vehicle pointing in the general direction. It was certainly a very entertaining start to a game if ever there was one.

You get taken to a garage, meet some key characters who set the scene for the plot in the career play, and you need to buy a car. To begin, you only have a selection of 4 cars to buy, and once you have chosen one your given brief tutorials to the tuning system, car upgrades, perk points and such. There’s not a lot you can buy at this stage, but it’s handy to remember where these things are for later when you have enough cash.
You then begin your journey, working undercover for the FBI whilst infiltrating the 510 car faction. So as not to spoil it for anyone, we shall not go on any further about the plot within The Crew as may are still playing through it, or may not have purchased it yet.

When you have a required first few events of the tutorial / prologue out the way, you are free to play The Crew however you wish. You can crack on with the career play, or so exploring. This is where you get your first look at the seemingly huge map that you have to play in. It is littered with icons of all the events you can do, your friends positions are shown as well as the major cities.

Our first thoughts were that the map is very, very large – however we quickly found out that it isn’t. Despite appearing large, we can drive from the east coast to the west in a little over an hour. Missions as you play them will move you over most of it, but we felt a little disappointed it wasn’t as expansive as the map from Test Drive Unlimited for example. It doesn’t feel too small neither, but isn’t as unwieldy as it first appears to be.

As you explore the world, between events on literally every road are skill events you can just drive into at full speed to activate a mini-challenge. This helps break up the monotonous task of driving long distances between places, and gives you extra cash to spend in-game as well as car parts and experience points. Once you’ve explore enough areas, the game has a fast travel feature so you can easily jump back to anywhere you’ve previously been. If you discover the airports and train stations, you can also use these.

The major US cities litter the map, and the world is busy with jots of NPC traffic filling up the places. The cities never really feel big enough, but we understand the compromises that they had to make here to a point. Each city has a unique vibe and appearance. The mountain sections look particularly impressive, as does the games day and night cycle. It creates a great environment overall.

There are 4 cars to start with, but you can purchase any of the others as you discover new garages on the map. New garages unlock new classes of cars, but for a car game the total amount of cars we counted was only 45. We know Ubisoft plan to add more (with a season pass, sold extra), but the amount in the game does seem disappointing.
Of the cars that are in there, they are nicely replicated visually. Each car you buy can be upgraded and tuned into different cars to suit your environment or event. Almost all the cars can be upgraded to street spec, performance, track, dirt and raid classes. The latter 2 are heavy duty modifications that make your car great off road, while the others lend themselves well to road racing. You can customize most visual areas of the car, upgrade its engine parts, and add decals. It adds enough to the car customization to make the cars to make them feel like they are personally yours, but the tuning options do not go deep enough for some. The upgrade parts are fixed, so you can buy varying grades of better brakes, or a differential, but you can’t tweak them if you wanted to say shift the brake bias forward.

Perhaps the limiting of the granularity in the tuning area is deliberate so the game is more accessible. We don’t mind it as it does offer enough, but I know from speaking to players while racing, some were not happy with it. They equally wasn’t thrilled by the cars handling model. It is very much in the arcade category, but we expected that. It makes the game enjoyable to zoom around and have fun without needing to pay too much attention to corner entry lines and braking – Instead you can hone your skills on seeing how high you can jump off the ski-slope for example.

Now, this is perhaps the game’s biggest selling point, and in Ubisoft’s own words they say “You’ll never drive alone”. I need to make it clear from the get go that this game does not have all the Uplay problems that come with Watch Dogs at launch, or any of the other recent titles released – However there are still problems.

We had no problems getting into the servers on launch day, despite the large surge of traffic, but the connection reliability has been ropy from time to time while playing. Without any warning whatsoever, if your connection drops for even a second, you’re returned to your desktop with an error message about the servers not being reached. That is coupled with the fact that every time it does this, some of your game progress gets lost. When you re-load the game, you will invariably find yourself many miles from where you actually were when it threw you out. This unfortunately happens with varying frequency, but it is something they are aware of so we hope it improves.

Another widely touted feature was the ability to form a Crew on the fly from either your friends or others who are in the world with you. Crews are important to help with the co-op options available in most missions – Some are quite difficult to do on your own, so pulling in others is an easier way to beat that one mission you may have been stalled on.
Sadly, we encountered several problems with this that could easily take up most of this review. We had problems adding friends into Uplay first off, and getting the game to recognize them in the game so I could add them. All too often friends in Uplay would not appear within the game itself. When they did, getting them added to the crew is simply an exercise of luck. Constant errors and timeout’s hampered forming a Crew on the fly as intended, and I found myself driving around by myself a lot of the time as a result. It’s currently near impossible to add players who are in a different country to yourself too, and this frustrate me further.

As a final nail in the coffin where online play is concerned, if you have the game in Steam as we do, you can’t invite your Steam friends into a game at all. You need to ask your friend for their Uplay ID, try and add them and then go through the process above.

I feel players who buy into the game expecting a racing simulator should steer well clear, but if Need for Speed and Burnout style games are your thing, we think you’ll love The Crew. We do.

reviewText:

I start it up and skip all of story and such.  After some races I get into freedrive. I get about an hour until i need to go.  Its okey. I hate my Mucle car.  Next day, let me get to a car dealer, pick up a Ford Focus. Spend all my money to upgrade it. And think lets roll.  Well the next 5 hours is a blur of streetraces, cops trying to kill me,  players trying to kill me and alot of jumpes.  I havent had this much fun in a car game since the last Midnight Club.

I think this game will be great, i certainly had alot of fun in the beta, and can not wait until realease.

reviewText:
I cannot reccomend this game in its current state. It's in a obvious beta form, which is unthinkable given how there were 3 open betas before release. It's like Ivory Tower has never made a driving game before. And it IS a driving game, not a racing game. It's all variations of 'point-a-to-point-b' in this game, unless you're being chased by the police or a gang.

The AI racers rubberband incredibly badly, the AI police/gang chase vehicles are moving brick walls that can go faster than you on any terrain and can only be outrun through sheer luck. Totally unplayable to people who don't min/max. Sometimes in Freeroam a cop will glitch out and try to arrest you, even though you don't have a wanted level (though him ramming you will cause you to gain one soon enough).

The car handling model is hellishly bad when the car is low level and either fun but challenging or boring as hell at high levels depending on the car.

The graphics are outdated and has a fair share of bugs. The antialising (aka the anti-pixelation stuff) is pretty much nonexistent, which makes areas with lots of foliage an eyesore.

The instances flat out don't work. You can't ever connect to friends or even your crew once you've moved out of the instance you met in, unless you get rematched together out of sheer luck.

PvP isn't balanced at all. If you crash once, you lose. If you don't have a fully-specced supercar, you lose. Simple.

Money is attained primarily through a system wherein people on your friends list can be used as ammo to start a 3-hour timer to do faction missions in order to get 1/4 the award of the normal payout. All other moneymaking is completely moot.

The endgame is an interminable grind to max out your favorite cars whilst also micromanaging the above-mentioned grinding system.

The cars are not very varied- the majority are american muscle cars and random supercars, with a few european tuners here and there.

The car parts system is not very well explained (what each part do, etc.) and boring as hell, especially given how to get the best parts you must gring the same jump, speed or hill climb 'skills' for around twenty minutes each for each part for each car. Alternatively, you can spend money to buy parts you unlock for one car for the rest of the same spec. This costs a lot of bucks (ingame cash) but not much crew credits (microtransaction money). Hm...

Visual customization is pretty varied for each car but you can't ever equip the stock parts of the Fullspec vehicle. Annoying.

Specs are not well thought out. Circuit, Perf and Street are all for road driving in descending order of effectiveness. There's no downside to using a circuit over a perf or a perf over a street. Just straight upgrades. Dirt and Raid could have been rolled into one without an issue (Raid goes better off road, dirt goes better on dirt roads).

The story is one of the worst I have ever seen, with extremely cardboard characters and a boring revenge plot that has a totally contrived happy ending and no direction whatsoever. Attempts to be heartwarming or funny fell flat, except for one occasion that made me crack a smile; one Chinese 'Vaas' expy in big debt once enthusiatically said simply 'Money money money money money!' to remind me to do a mission to help him.

Story missions are cookie-cutter from something like four or five types but with arbitrary additions, i.e. a 'A-to-B' (they actually call them that) could be 'don't take damage' or 'you've got a time limit' or 'you have to escape pursuit before you reach the destination', often without even any in-story justification. Sometimes an NPC will be in the car, giving you an infodump that you probably won't pay attention to while you haul ♥♥♥ trying to complete the objectives. Or maybe they'll just yell at you every time you bump something using the same three lines.

Ubisoft and Ivory Tower failed on every count reguarding this game. This is despite the Betas and the fact that we know Ubisoft knows how to make a good racing game from Driver: SF. It's incredible how bad this game is. I only play it because I want to get my $85's worth, and I'm hoping they'll fix most of these issues in due time. Knowing Ubisoft, it'll just be more DLC and mircrotransactions, but just maybe...


TL;DR This game has literally every bad element of every bad driving game ever. Don't buy it.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I was a big fan of TDU2 and this looked a lot like it, which sold me enough to pre-order. 20hrs later and i am as bored and restless as a kid without his ritalin. There is simply nothing to really do in here. There is a story line and little mini trials to get better parts to put on your car, and thats about it. What I really loved in tdu2 was setting up races for the community by going to the street, laying out the checkpoints then racing it to establish a time to beat, also had modes like follow the leader so you and your buddies could enjoy racing against a course as a team instead of just against each other all the time.

I found the car selection to be very limited compared to tdu2 and the physics of the cars didnt feel tight like when you are pushing your own modified car down the street at 100+.

It is a beautiful game that runs well turned up to full 4k resolution, but if you have ever had a pretty girlfriend that sucks to talk to and do stuff with then this game should make you feel like you are right back there again,. Have two friends that bought and played this and everytime we talk about playing or do log in, we just kind of sit there and feel like, what now?

This most disappointing part is you are probably really looking forward to going to somewhere you drive all the time and checking out how close it is. Ill save you the trouble, it isnt. Im from utah and the entire state looks a bit like a generic park city. Many of the places i have gone and traveled to from here i tried to recreate unsuccessfully.

I really want a good driving simulator that does a good job of recreating states, this wasnt it.

reviewText:
This game has a lot of potential.  The biggest problem I have is the AI is ridiculously overpowering when running from police.  They are like tanks that accelerate faster than any car you can buy.  They will push you right off the road but are impossible to be moved or budged themselves.

Also, the handling on some of these cars is whack.  Not so bad that the game can't be played, and I really like the game even with the ridiculously hard to kill cops.

There aren't very many people playing this game, dare I say 'yet'?

This game seems to be one of those game where you buy it and get hooked, and then they start releasing more stuff at extra charges.  It'd be nice someone made a complete game before they sold it to people.

All in all, I like the game, and will keep playing, but only because I've already got it.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Massive in-game world

+ The disparity between people of different level cars isn't huge - it's totally doable for someone with a LVL 1100 car to beat someone with a LVL 1299 car if they play better. This makes progression feel really slow and nonexistent, but in multiplayer it's extremely nice that the gap between vehicle levels is quite small, so you don't have to grind out max level parts.

Mixed Bag:
~ Graphics look pretty good on high settings, but optimization is not what it could be... even if you can run games like Battlefield 4 on ultra settings, you might not be able to get 60 fps in The Crew without lowering some. And this game looks really bad with low textures, geometry, ambient occlusion and environment mapping... like worse than racing games from 2008.

~ The vehicles are well done, but there is a very limited selection of them.

~ Customization is alright. On some cars there are tons of options for visual customization, and on other cars there's nothing beyond a paint job. Different specs" of the same car also have different customization options

reviewText:
This is more of a first impression review of the game in the first day of the Closed Beta!

In short: if you like to customise, an open world game, nice graphics and fun co-op/online this is the game for you

Pro's:
- nice graphics
- the handling is smooth (though this is more an opinion, also, expect arcade handling over realism)
- various music genres (which i dislike when they stick to one genre, give something for everybody to choose; also, you can change between radio and sountrack in the options (if you want to add drama to your races)).
- a HUGE open world driving
- very social/competitive: you get constant updates whats going on around you, there are always players nearby
- much custom, such wow: you can change appearance of your car (which doesn't affect it's performance). it's nothing in-depth (not sure if it will come in the final release) but there is plenty to choose from to make the car look like you want it to look.

Cons:
- buggy sometimes (i encounter some slight freeze (for 5s) when a race enters and i get swapped to the next screen))
- (not really a con, but quite strange) the need for uplay (which loads quite easily together with the game)
voteText: 60 of 118 people (51%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have played a lot of racing games from sims to arcade racers, and I have not found a better racing game. This game truely has it all; two tracks, bayous, jumps, cities, MILES upon MILES of roads. The scope is simply amazing. I have seen some people say that this game lacks detail because of the size, but I simply don't think thats true. Going through my neck of the woods (Michigan area) I can clearly see they nailed the look and feel of the state, and I think the pure size only enhanses the experience. As for the handling think heavy Need For Speed influence with maybe a hint of Burnout. Definitely not a game for the people who are simulation master race, more of a fun game for everyone else who just loves driving for the enjoyment. There is nothing more satisfying than logging in with some friends and just cruising across the Rocky Mountains or flying through the Vegas dunes, and thats why this game is so good.

As for the bad, there isn't a whole lot. My main complaint would be with the AI being able to hang with you even if your car is rated over double theirs. However this makes the game more challenging, so its not really much of a con. Also the disabiling missions aren't very fun. They are all doable since the AI takes the same path every time, its just annoying the first time you hit them and they have 6 health and you have to chase them for 60 seconds only to love tap them and kill them.

Pros:
- Great arcade driving feel
- Huge world
- Cruising with your friends across America

Cons:
- AI rubber bands hard even if you have an insane car
- The disabling missions aren't fun

Overall: 9.5/10

Anyone who gives this game less than a 7 missed the point.

reviewText: So I'll start off with saying that this game was not at all what I expected. The little research I put into the game gave me the impression it was more of a Gran Tourismo/ Forza fell rather than the Need for Speed game that it is. The tuning system is very simple and easy to use. In regards to customizing performance there isn't any adjusting specific specifications. The entire system is based on part 4" is better than "part 3" by xxx points. Simple and effective
date:
just not what I expected.

The games racing phsyics are probably my biggest complaint. It has a very arcade feel. Say there is a pebble in the road. We'll call it 'bob'. Say you hit bob on a run with your front left tire at +100mph plus. Bob may just nudge you a little bit causing you to have to steer and correct course. Another run you may clip the same bob at 40mph on your rear right and find your vehicle 30ft in the air while spinning like you were shot from a canon. Then your next run bob decides to take your front left tire at 80mph and throw you into a spin where you may travel over 50yards off road before being able to regain control. Now I love my wrecks but some sort of consistency in the games phsyics would be expected of a game title like this.

All in all the game is still fun. It even has a ton of acheivments to unlock
recommended: plenty of vehicles for your specific taste
hoursPlayed: visual customizations are abundant also. End game gameplay is fun and they offer various styles of events to enterain your mood what ever it is.\n\nI'll keep playing it so look for me in game. Always down for a pvp event."

reviewText: I would highly recomend this game to everyone who has not pre-purchased this game yet, i played in the recent beta that just ended today and my god I had already put in 21 hours in this game! i never expected it to be an exact replica of the U.S but the huge map is quite impressive especially with no loading screens freaking road trip central!!!! Yeah there were bugs but nothing to serious and if you love to drift like I do then your sort of in luck it may change for the better, but at first I was sad because I could not drift the corners on the street with the street spec vehicle but soon found out that the dirt spec on snowy/dirt mountains both up hill and down hill were like heaven. Also its just fun to drive around and see a group of people and just roll with them without even having to join there crew, I did this a couple of times and the experience was like none other, it was almost as if I was with a family or a group of friends just traveling across the country free as can be! remind you on both of these experiences there was like 8 to 12 of us!

reviewText:
Simple the most awesome and fun making car / racing game I have seen for PC for years.
Even doing simple road trips is highly enjoyable. The cop chases are intressting and there a neat variation of race types.
And the car personalisation is wonderful. There may some games with more visual costumization options but there also many that ignore the topic. You should have no trouble to get your car to your personal tastes.

And then there the car list with is wonderful, there something for every taste in there and for diffrent type of driving as well. (On road, as well as offroad, there something for everyone).

And ultimativly its a car game that has car interior view. How many other games are trying to avoid that for the sake of saving money and time?!

In Short this game is just awesome, and if you like driving / racing and cars then this is defintly something you should consider to check out!

reviewText:
Big Game industry is full of hype. Don't believe what you see on the trailers, I tell ya! (..at least that's true in most cases)

It's harder to know these days if the game is good or not. Many people get amped up by the hype of salesmans and their trailers with awesome music, superb graphics (which in many games  are from cutscenes and no actual gameplay) and all that stuff. Emotions sell. That has made me think a lot harder on what games to invest in.

I thought about buying this game a couple of days, during which, I watched a lot of youtube early access videos, read some reviews and so on. And finally decided to buy it. I'm now very happy I did.

Many times with big releases, there comes the feeling of money gone to waste. Not in this case. THIS GAME is, simply put, AWESOME!!

Actually I can honestly say that it's the best racing game I've ever played. I really can't compare it to the good old racing games, because it's been so long. I was a hardcore carmageddon fan back when it was the new hot stuff. Also need for speed since the first game of the series, and enjoyed them very much with maybe one or two exceptions of the NFS series later releases. I also liked Flatout 1&2 very much and Gran Turismo 5 was my the only racing game on PS3 I played a lot. And thought bugbears new Next Car Game on PC looks good, it seems to be pretty much same the formula then Flatout2, just with minor upgrades and graphics upgraded ofc - nothing this major as we see on The Crew.

I'm listing these just so that you know, what I'm rating this against, and what kind of driving games I usually enjoy.

I haven't bumbed to games like that in a looong time and was starting to worry that they're gone extinct. Luckily my fears were unjustified. The Crew really delivers!

The part I've read some critique is the phrase never drive alone". Well

reviewText:
simply the best driving game that i ever played... not the best RACING game maybe, because there might be pure racers with better/ more realistic physics... but there also are ALOT so-called racing games with far worse physics...

non of them gives you the rush of driving across the Rocky Mountains on snowy sideroads while heading down to Nevada and suddenly (after a good while) seeing the skyline of Las Vegas... none of them let you drive SEAMLESSLY from New York to L.A., passing smaller towns on country roads, highways and even offroad tracks...

The Crew does all of the above and more... i spent hours during the beta test just driving across the USA, sometimes being chased by the police because i crashed into some AI traffic one too many times.. sure, it´s not a photo realistic grafic, but i don´t need that... although on an older PC, it looked great and ran smoothly, i expected it to be too much for my machine given the sheer size of the open world, but it wasn´t... some people say the handling of the cars is bad, but i can´t confirm that... it took me some finetuning in the control settings and then it was no problem ... it also perfectly matched my low-budget Speedlink Carbon GT racing wheel, so you won´t need a G27 or similar to enjoy this game...

the story seems to be good, although in Beta 2 it just went up to lvl 10, which is just the beginning more or less... the races where challenging at times, but all of them beatable with the right car level... car level? yes, you earn parts for your car - by doing races, skill-challenges and such - with which you increase the level of your car and  - obviously - improve it´s performance...

summary: huge, living world, nice grafics, alot of stuff to do and explore (other than NFS World, where you have an open world but not much in it) , nice cars, cops, tuning (optical and technical) and many many more... i love it, because it´s THE type of game i was waiting for since NFS U♥♥♥♥nd i would dare to say, that´s the Test Drive Unlimited 3 i wished for :D

reviewText:
For an RPG/Driving game this is a decent game. In terms of execution... oh dear.

Beefeing up your ride to twice that of the AI one would think you'd win easily, yeah, not so much. You can ONLY win if you wait for the script to let you win. Don't even think of overtaking cars with pure skill. You can drive like an asshat and win since the AI slows down and lets you win... right before the end. Or, you could drive like you're paid to do it... and loose since you had to break in the last curve. Lets get one thing straight, your skill as a driver has 0 impact wether or not you win races. All you have to do is to wait for the script to let you win. And that is even before the AI starts to cheat.
Then there's the police...
Going from 0 to 300 in one second - CHECK
Breaking suddenyl in front of you at 300 kmh and taking no dmg nor moving whatsoever - CHECK
Taking turns at breakneck speed without braking - CHECK
doing a 360 at full speed and then just continue in the opposite direction - CHECK
Being able to send you into a spin just by nudging your car - CHECK
Being able to do precise manouvers EVERY time without fail - CHECK
Being able to catch up to you when you drive the fastest most badass car in the game, and they sit in a normal" car - CHECK
Being able to pass through other cars with nothing happening - CHECK

In short
