reviewText:
A Disappointment
TL;DR

Pros: Large map, interesting exploration.
Cons: Awful driving physics, repetitive.

Full Review

I grew up playing open world racing games like Need for Speed Underground 2, Test Drive Unlimited and, more recently, Forza Horizon. I consider myself a car enthusiast and tend to be more meticulous when playing games in this genre. The ability to create my own fun within sprawling open world of games like Test Drive Unlimited allowed me to spend endless hours cruising around. Thanks to solid underpinnings such as: satisfying driving physics, beautiful car design, and accurate engine sounds, I didn't have to rely on other lacking aspects of the game like: bland writing, mediocre voice acting, and tedious missions to support the enjoyment. Unfortunately, Ivory Tower’s attempt does provide a platform that satisfies this balance.

I'll begin with one of the focal point of Ubisoft's advertisement campaign for The Crew - the map. As you probably know, it's a scale representation of the United States and it's huge. It consists of four distinct areas and smaller regions within. The diverse biomes of these regions were a treat to explore due to subtle differences in foliage, climate, and even the way a car handles. However, I feel that it’s a case of quantity over quality. On the whole, the road systems are uncomplicated, resulting in driving any distance becoming monotonous. It feels as though they were designed using tools from a city building game – “copied and pasted road assets” would be the answer to every I-spy question on long journeys.

So will the handling redeem The Crew of its boring highways? No. To put it bluntly – it’s bloody awful. I have spent so many hours fiddling the various settings to find a set up that would work. The Crew turns the joystick on a gamepad to a D-pad. There’s no chance of a subtle adjustment to steering mid-corner, you get full steer or nothing. This is particularly frustrating because, in 2011, Ubisoft’s Driver: San Francisco showed that their arcade-esque take on car physics could actually provide for a really satisfying drive. But seemingly none of this charm rubbed off to The Crew in 2014.

On somewhat of a side note, The Crew was not a shambles of a release like some other Ubisoft titles of recent. It runs frame rates as would be expected and glitches are few-and-far-between. There were some initial multiplayer issues which seem to have since been resolved.

I won’t spend long attending to the story line of The Crew. Does anyone buy this sort of game for the story? Being brief, it’s mostly bearable and easily forgettable. Engine sounds are nothing special. They’re different for each car but many sound badly synthesised and have no grunt to them. Car design is generally decent and aesthetic customisation options are plentiful. However, the performance upgrade system is based on simple units, the scale and progression of which seems to have no bearing on the outcome of races anyway. And there is a severe lack of cars to choose from – the selection is really poor. Pairing the irrelevant upgrades with an uninspiring grid of AI results in races becoming a chore. The other chase and takedown style missions are tedious and downright frustrating at times. Though far from being the MMO Ubisoft suggested it would be, The Crew does allow for a handful of friends and strangers to join your in-game world. The most memorable moments of my playtime will be synchronous drifting through Yosemite National Park with two strangers in convoy, or improvised drag racing meets on the Bonneville Salt Flats.

That’s exactly what I hoped The Crew would be, and there are faint glimmers of it throughout. Open world racing games should be a setting for enthusiasts and casuals of any age to create their own fun. Sadly, The Crew doesn’t lay these foundations. It sits alongside recent mediocre Need for Speed games in my rankings and I will probably not return to it. If I had to give it a rating, I’d say 6/10. If you live in the US, pick it up on sale, drive around the area in which you live, then go and buy something like Assetto Corsa or Project Cars for a proper race experience.

A few quirky issues that I had with the game but didn’t feel warranted a point in the general review:
The steering wheel on the cockpit view doesn’t do full 900 degree rotation. Come on! Driver: SF had this feature and it was glorious – especially when using a wheel.
Mirrors don’t actually reflect anything. Seriously, all developers, please start implementing this.
Whilst driving, the user interface feels incredibly cluttered. There seems to be a constant bombardment of notifications, noises and flashing on screen. Shut up and leave me to drive!
When in manual transmission mode, shifting at anything other than the red line will cause a short rev limiter bounce sound to occur. It’s really annoying and I can only speculate it’s laziness on the developer’s part.

reviewText:
As usual there are pros and cons in this game.

Pros:
- Good looking graphic
- Very detailed environment and cars (the environment feels alive, even if you set it on low)
- Great game mechanism (leveling up)
- Very optimized game engine
- Good on steering wheel (Logitech Driving Force GT)

Cons:
- Not good on controller and keyboard (i thought this is an arcade game?)
- Difficulty is a bit tough especially on the hit and run type of mission (not enjoying, more to stress)
- You can't change difficulty
- Some issues with connection, during car selection on the board the screen will freeze and lost connection (happened to me for now)
(edit) - If you have max your level which is on level 50, you will not received any skill points. Instead you have to buy using crew credits (cc) if you don't have cc you need to buy it using real money. This is stupid.
- The prize money you received in game is very little in amount, so you have to wait longer to buy lamborghini or ferrari but if you're impatient you have the option to buy crew credits in order to buy cars without waiting (to me this is a little bit unfair, because people have already paid for the game and you need to pay more in order to buy cars in-game because some people could not afford to buy the crew credits because they have spend it on the game itself)

Overall verdict:
I recommend this game to those who like cars and exploration type of game. Who enjoys playing with friends and strangers, competitive driving and enjoy site seeing in their dream car on a virtual world. The issue for me is that, the difficulty for this type of game is kinda difficult. It is suppose to be an arcade game, people supposed to enjoy not stress when doing story line missions (especially during the hit and run mission). The fact that you can't change the difficulty is stupid to me. It reminds me of Midnight Club Los Angeles, how hard it is to win races, you have to be focus and not able to enjoy it. It put my stress level high.

The next thing is that you can't control the car properly on a straight line if you use controller or keyboard, it is utterly impossible to corner and keeping the car on a straight line. This is an arcade game, ivory tower should make the car controllable on any gaming peripherals (keyboards, controllers and steering wheels). I hope that they fix the control issue and also the difficulty settings, let the customer or user choose their own settings.

(Edit) this is my second thoughts on this game 6/10 for me. I hate the internet connection issues. #0_24, #0_34, #0_1..i mean what the?. They should have fix these problems before launching the game. Apart these issues i have no problem.

reviewText:
Think Need for Speed: Most Wanted combined with Fuel. Think Test Drive Unlimited combined with Driver: San Francisco. Think Need for Speed: World combined with Burnout Paradise. Think…ehh, you get the point. If any of the games I’ve listed so far tickle your fancy, or even combinations of them, then The Crew might be for you.

The game has its quirks and its rough patches, but it is generally an alright game. The story is bland, the graphics could be a smidge better, the car handling takes time to get used to, and the claim that it’s an MMO is kind of false. I’m not saying the graphics are bad, they just have their moments of making me say “that could look better.”

The car handling, at least for a 'keyboard racer,' works but feels somewhat odd. I've yet to try The Crew with a controller or steering wheel. At times I feel like I'm not in complete control of the car. Playing with all the assists off just made the game harder, not so much more enjoyable. I now play with all assists on because I'm already tapping the left and right arrow keys twenty times per second. Vehicle collision bugs me. Sometimes you'll tap a wall or car and bounce off unharmed. Other times you'll nudge the same entity and do a full 180 and come to a screeching halt. The AI of the other racers and police are painfully scripted. Cops have near infinite acceleration and top speed at times. Opponent racers haul ♥♥♥ off the line leaving you in the dust for a bit. And towards the end of a race, the AI gets tired" and basically coasts for the remainder of the race
date: allowing you to finish first almost every time.\n\nCalling The Crew an MMO is incorrect. The roads aren’t full of other players. In fact
recommended: they’re almost completely void of other players. The Crew only ever boasts 8 players on the same map at once. If you’ve played other multiplayer racing games
hoursPlayed: I’m sure you’re used to the whole “drop-in

reviewText: This game I have to say is one of the best and most anticipated racing games I've come across thus far. It's nothing like iRacing or Assetto Corsa as in a simulation. This is a Need For Speed Underground 3 with a massive open world driving experience. The car customization is impressive. I started off with a Nissan and finished with a Ford Focus fully tuned with street and dirt specs. Doing challenges was a blast, reminds me of the old Trackmania days competing for a better score/time. Physics are great too. The better the parts you get make a noticable difference in the handling of the car. Not to mention the perks you get as you progress through the campaign. Racing with friends was a blast. The 4 of us beat the campaign, got our dirt tuned vehicles and went cross country up and over hills and into canyons. Traveling from Florida to Washington. From NY to LA. Took quite some time even doing 180+ most of the time with a few crashes. We ran into multiple players and ran them off the road (They were pretyty slow) xD The cosmetics are amazing. Back when NFSUG2 was the game to play, this is the baby of that. A big baby though. Years of research and development going into a large massive MMO racing game that has topped my expectations.

reviewText:
I don't really recommend it, it was way over-hyped and is terrible in many ways. The beta was way better. After the beta and release, the AI rubberbands and it's terrible, the servers suck, and the car health and damage was taken out.
------------
Pros: - Huge World, variety of envrionments, cockpits are nice, some envrionments look nice.
------------
Cons: - TERRIBLE physics, terrible AI, Terrible races, cop chases, the cities are tiny, a lot of copy and paste, could use more cars, customization was over-hyped, boring story and campaign, poorly optimized, servers suck (NOT AN MMO), micro-transactions (After spending $60, really?), speedometer is off, roads feel like ice, damage physics are bad and weird, Uplay, and the fact it's published by Ubisoft.
------------
It would of been a cool racer, but all of these things make it quite boring and very over-hyped and dissapointing. Ubisoft probably pushed the game so it screwed up.
------------
Even on sale, don't purchase, you'll be dissapointed.

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game?
Yes, I had a lot of fun playing it

Would I pay full price for it?
No, wait until it's on sale. It's good and I enjoyed it, but not that much.

Note: It's an arcade style game so I've judged it accordingly. IMO a lot of people are judging the car physics and handling etc like they would for simulators, but it is an arcade game so judge it on it's merits. For an arcade style game I think it does really well.

Pros:

- Fun single player: Combined the typical Need for Speed" storyline elements with the GTA style open world roaming allowing you to pick and choose your missions
- Co-op can be done on any missions
date: you can do everything on your own or with friends
recommended:
you don't need to be alone for some missions or with friends for others
- Graphics are great
- Haven't encountered ANY issues with the game at all
- Hidden cars are found by exploration and unlocking areas of the map
hoursPlayed:
not just winning races and earning money

Cons:

- Story Mode isn't very long
voteText: I've finished it in 18 hours and I didn't use quick travel at all so spent quite a long time driving to some missions\n- Limited selection of cars
helpfulPercent: possibly because they decided to make DLC but would've been better if they were available as part of the core game\n- Not many "customisation options" at all: This is for both car customisation and audio/graphics/display settings etc. There's really not that much at all compared to other PC games out there\n- Limited replayability: There are some bonus missions and "skills"  and stuff for completionists to do but other than multiplayer with friends and a few longer missions

reviewText:
The Crew is basically what people wanted after black box got fired. It has a big map that can take minutes to hours to explore with a lot of variety when it comes to terrain and climate. There is hidden wrecks that you can find across the map with different specs such as Street Dirt raid perf and curcuit. Most of the wrecks are hot rod based and they have a lot of features when it comes to customization.

There is a lot of customization in the game such as bumpers spoilers skirts vinyls rims paint but there is something that has been bugging me and that is that some cars doesn't have that much customization options if not anything at all. Like the maserati gran turismo s you basically have no options here except for changing the OFFICIAL rims or the OFFICIAL colours. You can't customize the gran turismo s. And in curcuit spec there isn't that much options either you basically get a big body kit but with no options to change it. Just like raid spec you only get that 1 body kit.

Also there is a lot of cars / specs from the trailer missing in the game and cars that I would love to be in the game. there is only 2 import tuners in the game and that is the 370z and the skyline R34. Where is the Evo's or the RX7 / RX8's Supra's GT86's ETC? The 2012 Dodge charger has mitsubishi evo parts but it isn't the same.

The story is very short and very difficult trough the end most likely just to make the gameplay longer. I'm not sure if this game was rushed or they just lost their creativity but if you bought this game just for the story you will be very dissapointed. It feels like the full game didn't include the full story and it just ended too fast.

The physics are very weird in this game. Sometimes you will get random cutscenes where your car flips and crashes which is skip-able but still can get annoying at times. ESPECIALLY during missions or pvp races.

After exploring almost every part of the  crew bought and customized almost every car in the game and found almost all of the wrecks there isn't that much to do anymore. Sure it is fun to do road trips at times but it can get very repetetive.

Overall: Awesome game for cruising and customization but it lacks some features such as fenders specs and cars. Especially japanese cars which highly dissapointed me because there is only 2 japanese cars in the game :S Huge map with a lot of different areas to explore and cruise with your friends.

8/10

reviewText:
完美的赛车游戏。有一整个美国供你探索，虽然肯定会有大量的缩减，毕竟才14G。但是现有的地图仍是我玩过的赛车游戏里面最大的。如果你没有X1，但是又想玩Forza Horizon 2.。那么毫无疑问这款游戏绝对是你的最佳之选。
玩了8个小时了还在底特律城转悠。大量的任务，优秀的合作模式，排行榜，各种地标建筑，即使作为旅游指南都足够。一切的一切都让你不自觉投入大量时间。
城市的刻画也非常到位，可以看到人，还有消防车，卡车，火车，总之地图做的非常精致。，比欧卡2丰富太多。当然两者本身投资肯定也不能比。。
极其丰富的改车系统，虽然目前似乎只有10辆车提供给你改。不过每辆车都可以改成多种类型，以适应不同的赛事和跑道。新车型可能会在DLC里面再出，我已经有想买季票的冲动了！！
剧情简单明了，作为赛车游戏已经算是描写最好的剧情了。
担心UBISOFT服务器的同志们，反正我到现在就掉过一次线，能看到大量的其他玩家。至于别人愿不愿意和你COOP就是另外一回事了。。我到目前为止COOP过三次。。
总之，目前来说这60刀花的非常值。还有大量优点需要你自己去感受了。我也说不完。。
9.5/10.。0.5分扣给画面。。只能说这画面中等，算不上次时代的感觉。。不过大概画面上去优化又渣了。_(:з」∠)_。。所以这样也好，反正我一直车内视角。。

reviewText:
The size and beauty of the world is fantastic, and easily bests Forza Horizons.  But that's really the only positive thing I can find about this game.

The driving controls are beyond awful.  The controls feel like pushing around a bar of wet soap at the end of a 6 foot long Pool noodle.

Have you ever wanted story missions, and assinine cutscenes in your racing game?  Yea me either, but this game is full of them!  Good luck ranking up or earning money without playing through the nonsensical story mode.

You better like American cars, cause that's 80%+ of the vehicles available.

Also why is UPlay still mandatory for a STEAM game.  No one cares about your crappy publisher specific game launcher.  Take a hint from Games for Windows Live and just abandon it already.

Lastly, I can't take a racing game seriously if it has a dedicated Nitrous" button.

4/10

reviewText:
The Crew is a fun racing game and has a good online experience -when it works-.

The controls are good, they manage to feel responsive under the arcadish style of the game. Each upgrade does have an impact on the car's handling. This is not a driving simulation game, i don't know what was the popular belief in the game but i never seen it as a driving simulator type of game. The way the cars feel reminds me instantly of the old need for speed series, which is something nostalgic and fun. Progression through the game will allow you to unlock different specs for your cars, being able to tune up your favorite ride with up to 5 different specs: Street, Dirt, Perf, Raid,  Circuit. Each spec has an immediate impact on the car's handling.

The story is not the most ingaging one though is not too tone down to be silly or childish. Its just there for you to follow.

The AI feels cheap, which can sometimes ruin part of the experience. You can indeed outrun them and get some nice distance as long as your driving skills are up to par, but they still somehow manage to keep up a speed that their cars shouldn't be able to have. Not sure if this is working as they intended or a bug, but it would be better if they didn't use cheap tactics to make it challenging". The cop AI is -okay-. It sure makes me chuckle when i run inches away from a cop at 180mi in a 50 zone and they don't seem to give a damn

reviewText:
the crew is really cool tho no controller support (there is some but i had to restart the game 3 times) irks the ♥♥♥♥ outta me; there is wheel support tho but who the ♥♥♥♥ has one of those anymore thats so 1999 gaming jfc (im tempted to get one just for this game tho but :/ )

its fun but having to replay missions like 5 times to win cuz the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ keyboard is so weird to drive (arrow keys not WASD, you can change but wasd already is mapped to the camera?? why tho)

the prologue is annoying and meh, graphics are great tho and lots of customizing right from the start (after the prologue)

also ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Uplay is just as bad as Origin knocking u off the whole game when it loses the server somehow :////

this game i got solely for the huge map and endless driving not the racing and mini games and it hasnt dissapointed in that aspect at least

i think the biggest thing about this game is the ‘if u see it u can drive to it’ aspect

there arent fake backgrounds anywhere its amazing its soo different from all the other games ive played esp since it doesnt keep u trapped in the starting area, u can literally drive to new york or LA if you want nothing will stop you, no invisible walls, no lvl blocks its amazing
i love driving in this game its so relaxing this game is exactly what i wanted in a car simulator

needs more people on tho, i run into a few guys every now and then but the games population is so small starting out

also collecting hidden car parts to build hot rods and other unavailable cars HELL YEAH

this game actually rewards u just driving around and exploring and i LOVE that

reviewText:
UPDATE: The game is an absolute desert right now, It fails as a multiplayer-only game, it fails as a co-op game and it absolutely fails as a MMO.

This game will be dead before the end of 2015, although the fact that only 5.000 people were playin this game on a saturday night tells me that this game is DOA.

What a shame, this game could have been amazing.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The game was already good in BETA, but now that it's finally out I have to say that ubisoft has delivered, I admit that due to recent events (ACU) my expectations were very low, but still, the game has improved considerably from the beta and in all the right areas, handling has received a major upgrade, graphics are good (for a MMO) and the game is running very smoothly.

Reviewing a MMO is a very difficult and in some ways unfair since these kinds of games tend to be improved upon with time, however as of right now, the game deserves praise IMO, If you loved the old NFS games like NFSU 1 & 2 and the 2005 version of NFSMW (the greatest racing game of all time), then this game is for you.

Score: 6/10.
voteText: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I was skeptical at first with an open world MMO Car PG and thought there would be server issues on release and in general.  However, after playing for over 3 hours I got disconnected twice.  This game (especially on PC) is great! The graphics are awesome for an open-world game with no load times while doing fast travel.  The civilian and their cars are not as bad as many people pointed it out to be.  The environment looks great! Your car looks great!  My friends and I travelled from Chicago to Seattle through the mountains and never got bored.  There are side achievements/quests to keep you busy and if that's not thrilling enough you can bump into a cop car and have them chase you through the mountains.  The season pass was worth the buy. You will not only receive  12 cars (later on in 2015) but the Ferrari and Mclaren are fun to drive!\n\nAll-in-all this game has a lot of modifications, unlockables, and is truely an awesome experience.  I can't wait to join a faction and put more hours into this!!  The hype is real :).  Hope to see everyone on the road!
voteText: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is like Need for Speed Underground 2 and Testdrive Unlimited 2 that had a baby and made this game. IF you like those games get this game!!!

Steering First people had problems with the steering in this game being to arcadey. Its not at all you have 3 types of steering options in this game and plus many more options on how you turn ect like TDU2.

Cars Not many cars in the game just around 40. But I can see alot more cars in upcoming DLC'S

Map The map is huge!!!! The traffic in this game is insane there a bit too much to too little and some do crazy stuff too. Its funny to see what the AI will do next though. There also could be a DLC for a new map in the near future.

Customization and Tuning You can basicly tune and customize any car to your hearts desire. There not much of customize options but it's way better then the new Need for Speed games.

Other The game has soo many nice options in the menu but too bad the fps is limited to 60. Thats the only bad part of the game. If thats even bad.

Theres so much to do in this game its insane!!! You can chase people, get chased by cops and even do story. Story is alright for the racing game. It takes around 30 hours to beat the game and thats if you want to rush threw it. There some bugs and glitches that need to be fixed but it's not game breaking. Servers are having some trouble but its launch day. For being an mmo you have 8 people in session thats 2, 4 man crews. But theres alot of people playing. Thats my review.

My suggestion:If you do buy this game add me I will play with you.

Also the game takes 40 hours to complete. That being said 10 hours of game play = $10 of money that you spent on this game. Therefore 40 hours = $40 and the game should be worth that.

I still have more hours on this game then anyother new Call of Duty game. That says alot

reviewText:
The Crew is a fun racing game and has a good online experience -when it works-.

The controls are good, they manage to feel responsive under the arcadish style of the game. Each upgrade does have an impact on the car's handling. This is not a driving simulation game, i don't know what was the popular belief in the game but i never seen it as a driving simulator type of game. The way the cars feel reminds me instantly of the old need for speed series, which is something nostalgic and fun. Progression through the game will allow you to unlock different specs for your cars, being able to tune up your favorite ride with up to 5 different specs: Street, Dirt, Perf, Raid,  Circuit. Each spec has an immediate impact on the car's handling.

The story is not the most ingaging one though is not too tone down to be silly or childish. Its just there for you to follow.

The AI feels cheap, which can sometimes ruin part of the experience. You can indeed outrun them and get some nice distance as long as your driving skills are up to par, but they still somehow manage to keep up a speed that their cars shouldn't be able to have. Not sure if this is working as they intended or a bug, but it would be better if they didn't use cheap tactics to make it challenging". The cop AI is -okay-. It sure makes me chuckle when i run inches away from a cop at 180mi in a 50 zone and they don't seem to give a damn

reviewText:
I got into the beta, I put some hours into it too. So once again I'll give a Pro and Con list.

Pro's:
- MMO aren't usually my thing but something is just satisfying about ramming people off the road
- It feels like a new idea I love it
- Tons of Cars
- Randomly Awesome Effects
- Ubisoft didn't screw up on Optimization

Con's:
- The Map leaves out some cool place that would be fun to explore (It bases 3 Important cities in a region)
- The Beta World just felt empty (i'm sure this will be fixed when its released)
- Map is kind've small (I know, Small!?!?! But it really isn't the size many people expect)
- Needs some kind of Mini Games (not the small events)
- Remove Crew Points, I can see this going really bad
- Cars aren't very customizable
- Perks are very limited

Neutral:
- Well Worth my $60
- No Monthly Subscription
- Decent Story
- It was a GREAT beta, Thank you Dev's

reviewText:
What an amesome looking game.  Initially, I was worried it wouldn't be able to run on my computer but with all the graphical settings on low and 720p resolution it runs smoothly.  The controls had a minor but noticable amount of latency.  I was amazed at how good it still looked amazing even on low settings.
This has the most impressive open world I have ever played.  Each geographical region is immersive enough to get lost in.  The cities are all absolutely excellent and really capture the layout and aesthetic of their real world counter-parts.  As San Francisco is my own local city, I was a bit disappointed to find that it was probably the weakest of the representations but it's certainly still passable and still a lot more accurate than the versions in the Driver SF, or GTA San Andreas.  The way the world loads around you as you drive reminded me a bit of the game FUEL though the map was obviously less repetative.  Your car seems to be surrounded by a radius of detail and the rest that's on your horizon is a bit vague.  This could also be due to the graphical settings I was playing on.
I didn't really bother with much of the story.  I skipped cutscenes and completed enough tasks to unlock the freeroam driving, then played on my own terms.  I'm saving the experience of the story for when the full version is released.  There were a few bugs in the beta that I expect will be fixed before November.  Buildings and stationary cars are overly-reflective to the point where windows become blindingly bright.  The GPS line sometimes seems to not realized that you ARE following it and then givs up on you.  Some of the lines, crosswalks, and street signs same a bit out of sync.  The collision engine with plants is also very inconsistent at this point.  Crop fields have an excellent effect of folding up underneath your car but shrubberies in the deserts will not respond at all.  There's one bug that I actually found rather delightful and would be happy to see left in the final game.  When you drive through the Bayou, some of the alligators walk on just their front legs.  It's really funny looking.
Overall, I highly recommend this game.  I think it has a lot of potential and it really deserves a lot of praise.  It is vey ambitious and I am eagerly awaiting it's ultimate release.  If rumors are true that more cities and regions will be added as DLC, I woud love to see Boston, and some expansion done to the Bay Area.  It would also be great to drive through some of the U.S.A.'s great amusement parks such as Disneyworld, Magic Mountain, and Cedar Point.

reviewText:
Heres what you should know about The Crew:

Tuning

The Tuning Garage is more of a bolt on parts shop. You dont actually tune anything. You select a part and put it on. These parts are unlocked through races and events. I was a bit let down on the whole 'tune your car' thing, since you arent really tuning your car.

Customization:

There are lots of colors and vinyls to choose from, but it feels lacking in the customization department. Again, a letdown. Yeah, its got body mods and stuff, but it fails to meet expectations set by NFSU2. For instance, you can pick a wide array of stripes, but not choose their color.

Multiplayer:

This is NOT an MMO. Yes, there are thousands of people online. However, you will only see a few at a time. At no point will you ever see 100 other drivers at the same time. Ive seen a few people, and we have largely ignored each other. 7 other drivers is the maximum it will ever show you at once. They wont always be the samer drivers, but that it the limit. Thus far Ive done everything alone, though Im still pretty new to the whole thing.

Now, the game is fun. Especially with a wheel, pedals and H shifter. They will require about 1/2 hour of tweaking to get just right - but its very enjoyable when done. People said not to use manual and hardcore driving assist (which is zero assists such as traction control and stability) but quite honestly, I find this the best way to drive. Granted, I have just under 20 years driving experience and have had my fair share of street and drag races IRL. Manual transmissions are natural to me. The vehicles simply act slightly more natural with everything off. I think the visceral experience of shifting and turning a wheel really add to the experience...Im not even sure Id enjoy the game half as much without it based on the lack of customization available.

The game's storyline plays out like a cheap ripoff of a FF movie. Given the arcadey nature of the game, thats ok with me. Cheese is good sometimes. There are tons of short mini games involved such as hitting as many targets as you can, jumps, 'go fast and stay  on the road' races and such. There are plenty of odds and ends to keep you busy for quite some time if you are a completionist. The races and storyline events can be tough, requiring a few shots at it to learn the track before a victory can be eked out most of the time.

My most major complaint is the lack of actual tuning and customization. Everything else seems to work as it should at this point. After some hours of trial and error, I have the steering wheel decent enough to handle the game and feel pretty ok with it. Its not perfect by any means, but serviceable.

If you want a game with a storyline like a bad Fast & Furious movie, driving style along the veins of NFSU 2, and just a [fair] bit of customization, this might be what you are looking for.

If you're looking for realistic handling, deep customization, in depth tuning, and a more serious/sim style experience, this game is not for you. It has none of those things.

Im going with Recommended because its not super broken out of the box. Everything works, its fun, but its still a bit of a letdown. I was hoping for real tuning and deeper options for customizing your ride.

8/10

reviewText:
Everything Test Drive Unlimited should have been, and almost like Horizon on steroids... It's not very often we get a racing game like this on PC, if ever.

The Good:
-Handling far improved from the Beta, especially if using a controller
-Tuning/Customization is one of the most fun aspects of the game, it's not perfect and I'd love to see some more options like airride and ornamental lighting, but a very well implemented system none the less
-Huge Open World, drive wherever you want with no boundaries, tones of US landmarks and official Race Tracks, one of my favorite aspects
-In-Game Purchases: Now you may ask why is this listed under the good?"

reviewText:
This game is awesome, I'm hooked. The launch it seems went off without any problems as far as I could tell and there was lots of people driving around. The way coop missions are done are pretty nice because you can send out a request to people in your general area. Also if your in a crew, they could be like off in a different city for example then start a cool co-op mission and it asks if you want to accept the mission and then you both just start it up seemlessly from wherever you happen to be. So when continuing missions, if you are like sidetracked at the car vendor, they can go on and drive to the next mission progression and start it up. Also, you can see your team mates like line in the sky showing where they are headed next (its shown on the map as well) so you can sorta instantly see if your both heading toward the next place.
I'm not nearly covering all the different cool things but one more thing that really stood out to me. In all driving games before where you could explore a city such as grand theft auto for instance, its always been where you go in one direction and eventually you are going to hit a wall and have to make a right or a left then another right and another at the edges of the world. I must say, it was sorta of a weird sensation where I never hit that wall, I just could drive in one direction for a REALLY long time and never reach that invisible wall at the edge of the world. The scenery changes and all of a sudden I'm seeing new landmarks in the distance. Its quite a trip, of course there are eventual walls at the border of the USA but you literally would have to be on a mission to reach it. While just driving in one direction on like a 1 lane road I was also very surprised because quite often I would go through a mission start thing where all of a sudden I'm trying to get the most air off a jump or go as fast as possible for as long as I can staying on the road. It was like a total bonus to me just joy riding off into the sunset.
Last thing, there is an option in settings to put refresh rate to 60 FPS. Boom, on Ultra graphics its gorgeous, not sure what some people were saying how it didn't look new gen, It does.
Buy it, its worth it.

reviewText: I thought The Crew is a great game. I will admit that it isn't  for everyone and i have a few complaints, like the lack of cities in the game, i would've liked to see Atlanta in there, which is where i live, but i digress. It is still very fulfilling to drive across the country and see all the major American sights. My last really good racing game was Midnight Club LA and that game was very frustrating, but extremely fun with friends. This game has a bit of a different feel, since there aren't any game types like there were in Midnight club (I realize they are completely different developers) but I would like to see Some gametypes implemented, like keep-away. But anyway, The Crew is addicting, And from a developer's standpoint, as i am, for a game of this scale, the graphics are pretty insane. The world is massive, but it still looks beautiful and runs very smoothly. Even the little things, like reflections no the cars. I see all these people complaining about visuals  and AI catching up to you. Firstly, what do you expect from the police? a cake walk? and secondly, It would be too easy without auto-catchup. I personally prefer a challenge. It's a good game, and I am optimistic for new features and DLC's. In the meantime, see you on the road.

reviewText:
Basically, what i did, was complete the story, get a freaking Aventador, because that's the only car, that can maintain high speed, while staying on the road smoothly, and crank that sjit up, like a mofo.
And basically, afterwards, you just farm cars, and show them off.

But that's not all.
The scenery is SO GORGEOUS, i can play this game, and still be discovering amazing things.
I already uncovered all the hidden cars, which were pretty fun.
I was pretty dissappointed with the Agera R, it isn't what i expected.
The game needs alot more cars! Are you kidding me, a game this HUMONGOUS you definetly need a ton of different cars! But if all the cars turns out to be DLC, i think that's pretty dissappointing, and i may stop playing, because thats just ridicolous.
The game is essential when it meets up, with multiplayer. I love driving with my friends, and meet new friends, to ride along with.
I would like to see some more options, and definetly, more ways to earn money, other than doing Faction, and grinding missions.
I'm sooooooo maaaad, because there is Season Pass... Are you kidding me? Aren't this game based on the community, and not our money? I saw this game a year ago. I like what i saw, and i actually hoped and hoped and hoped, that this wouldn't be a failure, but, as for that matter, i would call it a train wreck in its state right now. Connections issues, gold diggers, SO ♥♥♥♥♥♥ EXPENSIVE DLC COMING UP, and no future plans published... Please. Even Bandicoot did better.
But to be honest, the game is overall okay, but i definetly didn't live up to my expectations.
Ubisoft may be ♥♥♥♥, and if they ♥♥♥♥ this up... I'm done.
